First off, I want to say this is easily one of the best rhythm games I've played. I am quite experienced in the genre by this point, and this game had me hooked in seconds. Not only is it incredibly stylish and charming with its visuals, but it just feels great to play. Even in the base version, there is a decent amount of customization when it comes to UI (the Guilty Gear skin definitely made me very happy). Aside from the classic "free play", the other game modes provide a rather unique and fun way to enjoy songs you might not be familiar with; "AIR" naturally stands out in this case.

Now, despite having the potential to actually be one of my favourites, you should be wary. For one, it's online only, even outside the "online" modes. When I bought the game, the servers happened to be down at the moment I decided to open it for the first time, so I couldn't even play it until things were fixed. Awful first impression that was! I actually refunded until I was sure everything was up and running again. I was stubborn and willing to give it a second chance, but that would have been it otherwise. Another thing is Clear Pass. Especially for a game that is not free-to-play, I hate this. Personally it seems negligible enough, but that's not the point. This game will already get expensive if you're hardcore enough. Anything akin to a battle pass has no place here.

It pains me that I can't shout to the heavens to just "shut up and give them your money". It came real close to being what I would consider pretty much perfect. Indeed, if that doesn't deter you, then you are in for probably one of the best rhythm game experiences there is. Otherwise, I unfortunately have to say you should probably look elsewhere.

Hey reviewer, why do you have so many hours in this game and still don't recommend this game? Why do you own so much DLC, enjoy it so much, and still believe people shouldn't buy this game?

It requires an internet connection, for ALL game modes. If the server goes down, so does the game. If the developers ever decide that they don't want to support this game anymore, or shut down the servers, you no longer get to play this game. And frankly, that's such a big middle finger to its player base that I cannot recommend this game in good conscience. 

I will love it and have fun with it, but creating a game that's not future proof, that generations don't get to enjoy, just sucks. Considering that the game is completely invalidated on a Steam Deck because of this one developer decision, despite the series of DJMAX having a long history on portable platforms like the PSP, betrays their roots.

If you ever want to touch this game, only get the game and its DLC when on steep discount.

"DJMAX Respect V," the latest installment in the celebrated DJMAX franchise, is a rhythm game that combines challenging gameplay with an extensive library of music tracks spanning various genres. Developed by NEOWIZ, it brings the series to the PC platform for the first time, offering both veterans and newcomers a polished and immersive experience. This review assesses "DJMAX Respect V" based on its gameplay mechanics, music and content variety, graphical and audio presentation, multiplayer experience, and overall entertainment value.

Gameplay Mechanics
Rating: 9/10 - Excellent
The gameplay of "DJMAX Respect V" is tight, responsive, and highly rewarding, presenting players with notes that scroll down the screen in time with the music, which they must hit accurately to maintain combos and achieve high scores. The game offers various difficulty levels and note patterns, catering to players of all skill levels. The addition of a new keyboard-centric play mode and the adjustment of gameplay mechanics for the PC platform ensure a fresh and engaging experience for both series veterans and newcomers.

Music and Content Variety
Rating: 10/10 - Masterpiece
One of the standout features of "DJMAX Respect V" is its expansive music library, featuring over 150 tracks that include fan favorites from previous entries and exclusive new songs. The genres range from pop and rock to electronic and classical, ensuring that there's something for every musical taste. The game also regularly updates with new DLC packs, further expanding its already impressive tracklist and keeping the content fresh.

Graphical and Audio Presentation
Rating: 8/10 - Good
"DJMAX Respect V" boasts stylish and vibrant visuals that complement the rhythm gameplay. The music videos playing in the background are a mix of animation and live-action sequences, enhancing the overall experience. The user interface is sleek and modern, though it can feel overwhelming to navigate for newcomers. On the audio front, the game shines, delivering high-quality sound that is crucial for a rhythm game. The tracks are masterfully produced, and the sound effects on note hits are satisfying, contributing to the immersive experience.

Multiplayer Experience
Rating: 8/10 - Good
The multiplayer component of "DJMAX Respect V" is a significant addition, introducing competitive online modes such as Ranked Match and Friendly Match, where players can challenge others worldwide. The game also features an innovative Relay mode, allowing players to team up and play through songs together. While the multiplayer experience adds a competitive edge and social element to the game, occasional connectivity issues and matchmaking imbalances can detract from the experience.

Overall Entertainment Value
Rating: 9/10 - Excellent
"DJMAX Respect V" offers exceptional entertainment value, combining challenging rhythm gameplay with a vast library of high-quality music tracks. The game's range of difficulty levels and modes ensures that players remain engaged, striving to improve their skills and climb the leaderboards. The inclusion of multiplayer modes and regular content updates further enhances its replayability and longevity.

Overall Summary and Score
Overall Rating: 8.8/10 - Excellent
"DJMAX Respect V" is a superb rhythm game that stands out in the genre, offering an extensive selection of music, polished gameplay mechanics, and a visually appealing presentation. It successfully caters to both hardcore rhythm game enthusiasts and those new to the genre, providing a challenging yet accessible experience. The game's minor issues with multiplayer connectivity do little to detract from its overall quality and appeal.

Highly Recommended for rhythm game fans and those looking for an extensive music game library. "DJMAX Respect V" is a must-play title that delivers an engaging and rewarding experience with every beat. Whether you're a long-time fan or discovering the series for the first time, this game promises hours of rhythmic fun and musical exploration, a Must-Buy for music/rhythm game genre fans.

If you need a simple rhythm game for your PC that introduces you to 200+ songs just from the base content throughout four playstyles to challenge your limitations, this game is the way to go.

The DJMAX has been an addicting staple since the PlayStation Portable days. The day that I heard that this series was going to be revitalized on modern consoles really brought a ray of hope to me, which consolidated all of the previous DJMAX versions into one, along with a lot more from the various DLC collaborations. The base game, defaulted at $49.99 at the time of this review, along with the allotted DLC packs, is also frequently discounted up to 70% off, which is basically a steal at this point.

Although there are more QoL changes that I would love to see in this game, such as how many MAX COMBO or PERFECT PLAY grades I have, or even sorting/filtering to only include charts that I have not played, this game is always keeping me busy after pouring a couple hundred hours into the game over the course of years. I don't see myself stopping any time soon either.

Very good entry into the DJ Max series. Tons of great songs in the base package. Most of the DLC packs are also worth getting, although i recommend waiting for a sale.

I do have some issues with certain things that this game does but even then i would still recommend it.

minor gripes are:
- Results screen is kinda lackluster in design.
  > while it gets the important information out of the way with no problems, it feels kinda empty still.

- Themes are limited.
  > I have no problem with how they are just it would be nice if the themes applied to more then just music in other menus / screens

- Songs are not tracked unless you clear them.
  > Sometimes you just wanna know how many times you tried a chart without passing it. 

- Timing speed thing gets in the way.
> Not even optional. you cannot turn it off.
> Distracting during play.

Major Issues:

- You can no longer fail on Normal/Hard charts in freestyle.
> Not even sure why they did this for. Game feels weird when you know you should have failed but dont when your life bar hits zero.
> It's not optional. you cannot turn it back on.

- The "SEASON/BATTLE" Pass system
  > contains mostly cosmetic/avatar items. except with season 10 they changed how the Pass system works to also include gameplay content within it. 
  > its FOMO. meaning theres no way of getting the items you miss if you do not clear the pass. this now includes the song they include with the new passes if you choose not to buy into a season
  > basically killed my interest to constantly play the game as i would have. 

- Always online required. 
  > Yes, I get its to prevent cheating and score tampering. But it would be nice not to worry if the game stops getting its servers supported in the future. I would also play this on my steam deck if i didnt need to worry about being connected to the internet.
  > I dont play in the online modes.

This is probably the best premium rhythm game I've played for console/PC.

The gameplay is smooth and feels good with fun to play patterns on both keyboard and controller. Each song also has background music videos which really makes playing every song feel fresh, with unlockable stuff to go after to reward playing.

There is a also huge amount of content, with over 500 songs now across all the DLC, each with 4 different button modes and up to 4 difficulties per button mode, so a song could have up to 16 different patterns to play. There's also regular free play mode, mission mode, ranked and open online play. There's just so many different ways to play, whether you're an absolute newcomer to vertical-scrolling rhythm games (like I was) or a talented full combo chaser.

The price tag may seem really overwhelming at first, but during sales you can get really significant discounts, and the amount of songs you get in each pack, as well as profile customization, is pretty good value for your money when picking up the new DLC.

I hate it. It hates me too. 

I think I'm a masochist.

TL;DR: Don't even think about it if you don't have a good internet connection with neowiz's crappy server.
The game literally kicks you out of it if "it sense irregular behavior", mostly are just connection issues.
Otherwise, I do think it's kind of okay for you if you are a rhythm game newbie and have never experience any flagship arcade rhythm game (e.g ; beatmania/SDVX/DDR), especially those that have keysounds for each and every song. 

-----------------------------------------------------------
Updated after the game added back fast/slow indicator.

At the moment of writing this piece, the PS4 has not yet receive update for V extension 5 or the indicator.

The new indicator is not like the one you get in the vanilla game on PS4, but it's basically the one in 2dx.
That is, unless you actually lower the speed and look down and take a look at the "MAX %" indicator you probably won't notice it's existence at all.

Hands down, the old one (the vanilla one) is just better.
But I guess they can't get it working on PC so this is the best you can get.

With this essential feature coming back, it's finally a actual working game (sort of).

Still, if you can buy the PS4 disc version, try to get that. The PS4 version has no live-service bullshit, no DRM-lock bullshit, game works offline and you can play local multiplayer with your friend. 

Playing the PS4 version, You don't have to worry about all those plus the following. Sometimes you cannot boot the game because it cannot connect to the server; sometimes you get stuck on a result screen because the game cannot sync properly with the server; sometimes the UI gets messed up because the game did not sync properly with the server; sometimes your in-game achievements got messed up because the game cannot......

You get the idea.
All those live-service bull-crap.
If crappy server failed magically, then you get the middle finger.

You can argue, at least when it works, it does work.
But that's not a compliment.

ANYWAY.

Now the game ranks the SC patterns seperate from other (Normal. Hard, MX) patterns. Well, does it work?  

Kinda.

Just a little example: 
Memory of Beach 8B SC, 3 star, Ladymade Star 8B SC 7 star.
How come 7-star is easier than 3-star?! Maybe the rank works backwards.
NOPE!
A 12-star SC pattern IS more difficult then an allegedly claimed 3-star pattern.
But a 15-star SC pattern won't necessary be harder than a 12~13-star SC pattern.
It's all over the place! 

This phenomenon outlines the biggest flaw of the game. It lacks consistency. 

The quality of the patterns or charts, and the music in the newer releases are VERY inconsistent. 
Quite a lot of patterns released in the V Extensions(1~4) are just key-spamming garbage, e.g. Plasma Sphere in V extension 3(I play the MX chart once on PS4 and never want to touch it again).

And quite a few new music tracks (post portable 3 & technica 3) can be categorized in the following 3 genres: straight run-of-the-mill bombastic ass, "elevator music" and "stream BGM". 

Even people who haven't studied music should notice the drop in the quality.

How does it compare to those flagship music games, like those BEMANI games, especially 2DX and SDVX?
Well, collab charts still don't get ANY keysounds (like, not even a simple tamborine SE ).
It does have a hard mode hidden in the Mission Mode (those Don't Make the MAX 1% missions, which is basically the hard mode on Black Square), but there's no way you can practice it because there's no such settings available.

But, you don't have to play like 15~20 USD a month (unless you are into those live-service "bonus").
And you don't need a dedicated controller just to play the game.

So this is basically, the more "pro" music games for novice players.
It's much easier to pick up, and it does have some curve balls throwing at you and gives you challenges.
But it's no where near the flagship experience.

You can say, the game makes you FEEL like a DJ.

And if you have any problem with my opinion, then,

You are nitpicking and biased, I win, bye bye.

Original post:

I platinumed the PS4 version and I purchased all major DLC there, except the two related to Rayark because F them, don't expect me to pay for anything that has less effort putted in than doujin BMS contents.  

For new comers, 

TL;DR: buy the PS4 version so that you don't need to worry about crappy server and XIGNCODE3.

I strongly recommend the PS4 version over this one since you won't be worrying about no being able to play anything because NEOWIZ is having troubles with their crappy servers. In terms of the contents, the exclusive songs on PC are mediocre at best, and most of the SC patterns add to the PC version aren't impressive either. 

Speak of pattern design, people seem to complain about the cytus pack a lot lately. But the truth is, the pattern design quality has already started to decline since Technika 3 pack. Most of SC patterns in the PC version are not more difficult than the MX difficulty, for some instances they can even be easier (e.g. ANALYS 8B SC, HAMSIN 8B SC, Nightmare 8B SC, Stalker 6B SC). The cytus pack got criticized because it crossed the line, plus it doesn't have keysounds. 

What about being able to play with a keyboard?  
Don't worry, if you're not good enough to handle MX difficulty with a DS4, you won't be able to handle the same or the higher difficulty with a keyboard either.

Last but not least, XIGNCODE3.  
It's one of a kind and it's one of the worst. What I really worry about is if it introduce any security problems after being installed. Unlike other kernel-level driver made by Intel or AMD or Nvidia, this thing will not get security patches even if somebody make an exploit out of it and that's horrifying. To avoid accidents, I made a complete backup in advance and install the game in a Windows guest, so the obvious Gotcha that I could think of would be somebody found a way to sneak inside the VRAM or the PCI controller through an exploit.

A game is only good as the developer/publisher support. Sadly this only has one.

This game like previous DJMax series is great. This is assuming you liked the game play from previous versions (minus the DJMax Technika series as I feel it is great series on it's own right, I feel like it's a spin off of the main series). Nothing too drastic has changed on the actual game play, just the scoring system, the fever automatically activates unless you're in mission mode and possibly online battles but I don't know since I never played online battle in any of the DJMax series.

No, I have nothing really bad to say about this game (when it works) besides these 3 things, that for the first time a DJMax game has made me frustrated before I even play the game.

#1: The game requires constant online access to even play the single player mode like Free Play, Mission or accessing benign stuff like changing things in options or to change notes, gears, ect.
But at least the performance doesn't suffer unlike playing Diablo III single player.
However one day this game will no longer be supported and who knows if the developer will release a final patch to let us play this offline for single player mode but I wouldn't hold my breath.
I would have thought thrice before getting this game if the description on the store page stated always online connection required and it also would have save me the problem dealing with #2.

#2: It uses Xingcode3. Some may call it a rootkit, a spyware. I call it an abortion of a anti-cheat system that frustrates legit players. Besides that, the amount of dealing with Xingcode3 with errors are frustrating to the point where the game is less frustrating than dealing with Xingcode3's shenanigans. I had to deal with 2 different error types when I was on my Steam Deck (via Steam OS) and now that I got my gaming PC, It is giving me hell on that possibly due to it. I don't know since every time I research errors for this specific error, I can't find it. 

#3: Now I've tried Valve to find a fix but they told me since I can get an error message in game, it's out of their hands and I must contact the publisher/Developer. Which then the website they gave me links to this site here. https://djmaxrespect.com/cs/index.html and after I filled out everything the site then tells me that the site is down due to maintenance and I tried every day for almost a week now and the same thing happened. So then my next option is their Discord page which I have to create a account for that I never wanted (due to that CCP has funded undisclosed amount towards Discord and we don't know what they have access to or have CCP members on the board as it's unknown to the public).
So I tried to access to their Discord but it seems like they're no longer accepting new members and I'm not going to set up another account to get a hold of them, as their track record is pretty spotty right now.

The only way I'm able to play this game is through my Steam Deck but I can't get steady 60FPS as it stays 45 to low 50's and it's not a steady as the frames is varied pending on what MV is playing. Here I was hoping to play this on my Windows gaming PC with 4k and steady 60 FPS but I got no joy and support is well lacking.

I owned many variant DJMax titles from PSP (I no longer have), PC DJMax Trilogy with usb profile stick, Vita Technica Tunes, I still have only because of KARA),  and the PC version of Respect V. However I regret buying the complete edition due to the headache involved. Only reason I bought Respect V is because I couldn't find my USB profile stick for Trilogy but found later only because I can't play this game on my Windows 10 Pro, but hey, I still can play my Trilogy just fine.

I doubt that I'll buy any more DJMax series for a while now due to lack of support (as in trying to contact them without jumping through so many hoops, just to find out the web page is broken and when they post that you can get help on their discord but can't access it. 
Look, I usually try to find out fixes through web boards, Google-fu my way to fixes that been posted but I haven't found the error that I got and getting help from the Developers are a joke.


TLDR: Game is great when it works (and that you don't mind that it's required to have constant internet connection to even play Single Player) but IF the console version allows keyboard then you're better off on that platform IMO because it works. 
If you have the PC version and if the error isn't what most majority have and semi unique then good luck to you on getting a fix or even letting the developers know about it because the avenue that they stated to find them isn't working or just broken. Don't make the same mistake I did by purchasing the Complete Edition. Even if it works for you today, somewhere down the line it stops working, you may be SOL.

Edit:
Well by stoke of pure luck, I found out what that mysterious message in Korean was. The game will not boot if there's no controller plugged in. Now I don't know why it requires it since all die hard DJMax players always used keyboard or 3rd party accessories for the PC version (including the defunct DJMax Online/O2 Jam). It could've been that I bought and started the game on the Steam Deck and somehow the configuration carried over the controller fixation to Windows. 
Anyways I will now recommend this game with a caveat.

1: If you believe this game will not become virtual binary paperweight when this game is no longer supported. And that you believe that Neowiz will patch this game so not to require always online to play for our single player content (which majority of us only play anyways. statistic wise) then read on further.

2: If you really really like the previous edition of DJMax in any sort and not bought this game, then buy the complete package when it's on sale. If the above mentioned did not happen at least you know you got it for steep discount and the OST is the one thing that they can't take away from you and plus real DJMax players must have at least one OST in their collection and for the audiophiles it does come in .wav format.
FYI, when you buy the complete package, it will not come with future updates and OST. However you still can get them at a reduce price. Also the default skin is the only one that works for me as all the rest will tell me that it's corrupted and it will switch to the default skin right afterwards. I haven't checked to see if they fixed it since the season 10 ladder match.

3: You, like your wallet like to live life dangerously, with no uncertain hesitation on supporting what you love, and what you love to hate. 

It's too late for me and my wallet, save yourselves.

DJMax has been a niche rhythm series similar to Beatmania, where a bunch of notes rain down, and you hit it with proper timing. If you don't know Beatmania/IIDX, think Dance Dance Revolution or Guitar Hero... most people who aren't heavy into video games usually still know those titles. There's quite a selection of music genres, and you might even get hooked on some songs that are not **** you typically listen to just because they're so darn catchy. This is a Korean game, so you will encounter Korean songs and some with broken English, but who cares. The music is very well done. This is the best release of the DJMax series thus far. It's hard; there are no gear effect compensations from previous versions (like protection from breaking your combo), so a full combo means much more than it used to. The song collection is MASSIVE, and they have been putting out plenty of DLC to cover previous game versions. Furthermore, they're doing DLC partnerships with Rayark, which is fantastic.

I am 32 years old.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and we adopted our son together. Both are now 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I felt lost and unhappy. I was self-destructive. One day, I was so angry with everything spiraling out of control that I punched a concrete wall in a moment of overwhelming emotion. This resulted in breaking my fifth metacarpal in my right hand‚Äîthe hand I worked with, played games with, and used to carry my children to bed‚Äîthe hand I desperately needed to ensure I could continue providing.

Upon learning the severity of the self-inflicted damage, I became almost suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man, with no history of depression or anxiety. I had never experienced anger outbursts, nor was I the type to break down and cry, but I was in a tough situation that truly prevented me from seeing the light on the other side.

With nothing better to do, I looked for a game I could play WITH ONE HAND while recovering. Somehow, I stumbled upon this game and read some of the comments. I decided it was worth a try... I must admit I didn't beat the game, nor did I play as much as some of you. In fact, I may have played this game for only a day or two. That being said, after doing so, I had a new joy and hope for life. I managed to leave behind the pain and suffering that had been thrust upon me. I could experience the joy and happiness of other people. I relaxed for 5 ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• minutes listening to this music, long enough to realize that I would be okay.

After realizing this, I turned off the game and went back to work. My hand hurt a lot, but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so sorry for myself and became the father I needed to be at that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving like.

Today, I am close friends with the mother of my children. We don't fight, argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents and friends.

Now I have 3 children. My third child is, wait, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my separation, and we just unexpectedly stumbled into each other's lives. We have been dating for a year and are very happy together.

Moral of the story: you never know what life has in store for you, and if I had given up when all odds were against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you.

best rhythm game ever made, blows osu! out of the window. it is keysounded, you feel like you are actually playing the music and not just clicking artificial patterns made by some dude in his basement that thinks more things to click=better experience and then blurts out charts that dont really vibe with actual music. lots of content in basegame (can easily get at least 100 hours out of it and thats when you ignore most of the shit you can do) and dlcs are actually fairly priced (if u want them - just get them on sale and/or in bundles, ignore dlc that only adds skins), theres just lots of them which may paint an image of a greedy dev. most icky thing about dlc purchases in this game is the battlepass, it doesnt affect the experience that much but it sucks nonetheless.

only other thing that sucks about this game is the anticheat/drm that wont let you play offline (not present on ps4 ver, you can play offline on console).

the soundtrack is absolutely legendary. great variety, its not a rhythm game that focuses just on weeb sounding stuff.

charts are AMAZING, the overall feel you get while playing them is immaculate. keysounding ftw

iirc there is literally over 250 tracks in the basegame and like at least 4x that amount of charts. you are literally getting like at least 4 games worth of content in one package, without any dlc. and then dlc is there if you want even more. dont buy it if u dont need it (and u probably wont need it for at least few dozens of hours)

Other than some rough DLC practices, this is the closest you'll get to a traditional Beatmania experience since Konami refuses to localize classic Bemani stuff on any accessible US platform.

Ignore most of the negative reviews for this, they're from Osu zoomers who don't understand the concept of paying money for things. Game is fantastic and is one of the most polished rhythm games out there for PC. Nothing else comes remotely close to matching the amount of love that went into Respect. Huge variety of music, even just in the default song list disregarding DLC entirely.

Between my playtime on Respect V and plain-old Respect on PS4 I easily have over 300 hours of playtime with this game. Also the DLC is fantastic and you should buy it! Don't turn your nose at spending money on content that's infinitely more polished than most community stuff in other free games.
Worth it for the amount of music it has.
Rhythm.
Very great place to start off from. And for higher skilled players, they have just hard enough charts. Their charting style is also my favorite.

REVIEW EDIT 2023: The game is in a better state than ever, and they just announced even more long-term support for years to come. The DLC choices and charts feel better than they have ever been, and the original tracks in the base game are still fun after hundreds of hours. It is a fantastic time to be a DJMAX fan right now.

REVIEW EDIT 2022: They actually did it!! If you slept on this game because of some of the reported timing/keysound delay issues, they have been GREATLY improved with this recent patch!

An essential rhythm game finally back on PC. Early access was a nice idea; the devs have been pretty responsive patching so far, and the tracks are really varied. Lots of play styles and charts, and more updates (including ranked multiplayer) to come. Can't wait for the DLC to start popping out.

A lot of people mention timing issues, and I see the effect: you do have to hit a tiny bit early to register solid scores, but this hasn't been too tough to adapt to, with most of my scores even for MX charts in the 99% range. Turning Vsync off seems to help this problem a lot and now I don't even notice it. (EDIT: See above, they drastically improved this as of mid-June!!)

(Also, it's 2020; I don't know how people can still complain about clearly labeled anticheat software. XIGNCODE is fine, really not sure how this is still an argument.)

Great rythm game

Yeah its okay as far as rhythm games go, but not for me. 3/5.

Has all the bells and whistles you could want as a PC player for a paid rhythm game played on keyboard. Good optional depth too (speed, change how game plays & lanes look, etc.). Not a fan of the artist selection personally, but if Korean and US music appeals to you, then you'll be right at home. Very wide variety of genres available here too (rock, lullaby, vocal pop music, etc. instead of just EDM). UI, visual direction, and presentation is very slick.

Only gripes gameplay wise is that on high lane speeds screen suffers significant screen tear even on high fixed framerates. A better v-sync option would've been beneficial. The difficulty selection & visualization is poor, represented by a line with dots instead of a generalized number like 99% of other rhythm games use. The game doesn't really explain SC difficulty either, or why its harder for its class compared with similar star songs. Song navigation is also extremely primitive with few sorting options and no fast way to navigate. The game lacks an obvious "life bar" for whether you'll pass a song or not as well, which is confusing for the highest difficulty songs.

DLC policy is frankly kind of ridiculous at first glance, but in reality is par for the course for these kinds of games. Sound packs are how these games stay afloat. If you don't want to pay artists for the music you play, or at least want a strict budget option, I honestly can't recommend this. The default music selection is 90% generic filler. Pretty much just mainstream sounding crap and deep as a puddle in terms of quality. It appears all the good music is in the DLC. I'd look elsewhere for all in one type games (ex. Muse Dash) or free alternatives (which I won't name here) if you want specific and higher quality music.

Finally, I can't recommend this game as a Bemani player. That is, if you already play arcade quality rhythm games at home and can afford the live service + a dedicated controller (IIDX Infinitas, SDVX Exceed Gear Konasute), there is really no point in playing this title even to supplement them. Let alone to replace them. At best DJMAX is poor mimicry with different music. I'd wager you'll spend just about the same amount of money in the long run. Honestly, just splurge the money you'd spend on this for a dedicated Round 1 arcade trip and it'll change your life.

If you love rhythm games, you'll probably love this game.
It's not an easy one, that's for sure. The learning curve can even be a little steep. But if you ease yourself in, you'll have a great time. There's a good amount of songs, and I find *most* of the DLCs to be worth your time (heads up though, they are pricy, and I do recommend getting them on sale!). They upload all the songs to YouTube so if you're on the fence about what you'll like, I definitely recommend checking it out. 
I do have a few issues (always online- cannot play if you're not connected or if the server goes down). But I do feel like the fun I've had an the hours I've put in have absolutely been worth it.

Just an absolutely wonderful experience of a game. It's a high skill ceiling style of music game. Keep in mind if this is one of your first rhythm games it will destroy you, but it all flows into improving your overall skill. 
Also has some of my favorite music available in terms of stuff made specifically games.

This game is definitely not worth it's price, If you're gonna get this game, get it while it's on sale, Imagine spending 50 dollars on a game and then having to buy more content for said game, and the initial songs you start out with are mid. Imo you're paying for the game itself and the pre-packaged songs, which imo is definitely not worth **50** dollars.

The gameplay is fine, as someone who's competitive in rhythm games, it's pretty okay. My only issue with it is when a lot of the elements are very distracting, like the animated lane and note skins. But I really like the style and the animation in the opening cut-scene is amazing.

This is definitely more of a semi-casual rhythm game and not a competitive one, I get the feel that it's kind of trying to be meta with some of the modifiers and ranking system, But I really think this game is really more visual appeal and fun rhythm game instead of something more competitive.

As for If I recommend it or not, I don't know, it really depends on the person. For 50 dollars? no, on sale? well sure. If you're looking for a competitive, difficult, and fast pace rhythm game, this is probably not the best option, but for more casual rhythm game players (which I'm assuming most people are)  you should probably check this out.

The quality is astonishing for rhythm game From the music,BGA,UI everything really shines and feels polished. It's AAA grade and i can see why they put a bit of a price tag for the game

The base game have about 160+ song in it and it will keep increasing as the season changes

The core gameplay are basically DJMAX but with a twist called side track, it's basicaly total Button + 2 side tracks ( for example 4b play will be like 6b because if the side track so 8b play will use you whole hand because 8b+2) but overall its really fun and i keep dumping more hours in this games

the game have a lot of dlc for sure but im ok with it because how much content you can get from the dlc itself and the production quality behind it. and it's still cheaper than most of the mobile rhythm games if you count price per song

This game is online only some people hate it some people don't
for me personally im ok with online only with anti-cheat and tight online check because its basically the thing that keeps the game alive because the PS4 Version is very dead

The game have 4 game modes : 

!. Freestyle mode that basically just choose the song and play to your best. You will spend most of you time here because this is the core gameplay of DJMAX, grinding for achievement or training your skills

2. Air mode is a mode for people who just want to play a random song from a random rotation even if you dont own the song DLC you still can play it

3. Mission mode is self explanatory. Complete challenge from very easy to borderline impossible because how hard it is

4. Online mode is separated into 2 modes. Ladder match is a 1v1 ranked match for player who want to test their skills especially accuracy and normal march is 7 player casual online mode where you can choose a song for you and other people to compete with

Overall the game is good and the content is worth it

Playing DJMAX Respect V here on PC for a while, its a nice and solid port from the PS4, with a few differences. AIR mode replaces the Arcade mode (I miss Arcade mode), its not the best thing, but its a OK new addition to the game. With it being more focused on online/multiplayer modes, the Online mode is really fun to play. Online Open matches are easy to join in and doing Ladder Matches are a Fever Trip to play. Ladder Matches are some of the most Intense games to do, you never now what will happen during a Match. The songs this game offers are the best, from old legacy songs to new originals and even collaboration songs from other popular rhythm games, there is a song and genre for everyone to play here. Aside from that, The Clear Passes are another thing. Not a big fan of it, but its mostly optional so its not a BIG loss, but it does offer new original songs and DLC previews. Not the best way to try the New/DLC songs, but what can you do. Overall, Respect V has ALOT of content. If you don't want the Clear Pass, you can skip on it, its not necessary to have, but I do recommend getting the game with its DLC during a sale, It get really cheap and it's worth every penny. So if games like beatmania IIDX, EZ2ON, and Sound Voltex are your style, add DJMAX to your list. A game worth having, Fast and fun button mashing to the Extreme! ÔºØ(‚âß‚àá‚â¶)ÔºØ

Allow me to preface with I got the game and two DLCs on sale for around $20 all together. I do however see the reason for the price being where its at, tho I disagree with the DLC prices so I would 100% only grab those on sale. Game tho is worth the price *In My Opinion*, TLDR at the bottom for those like me.

If you like Rhythm games, you'll love DJMax. If your new to Rhythm games, You'll love DJMax. The game is very customization both in difficulty and visuals. Theres a good track list with the base game and the DLCs simply add more songs to play and try to Max.

Theres an online multiplayer with a ranking system if you're interested in that, I personally have not touched the online portion besides the other mode, Air Mode, where songs rotate out every few minutes and you can leave a comment for other players to read durring that song [kinda weird but it fits as the game autoplays while u type]

You can set the scroll speed, you can add a fade to the notes, if you hate yourself you can hide the notes completely to attempt a blind run. From what i can tell all songs have a video attached with it and if you find the video too distracting, you can either turn the transparency for the board down to block it out or you can simply turn them off completely.

TL;DR: Whether you are good or bad at Rhythm games, you can tweak the difficulty to your liking, base game has a great pool of songs to start and theres plenty of content for all partys. 8.5/10

Update: I nominated this for the Steam Awards 2023 Labor of Love. The devs have released multiple engine updates and DLC song packs every year for the past few years, and they have a DLC roadmap for 2024 and probably beyond.

Original review: During the free weekend way back, I was gonna pass on buying as it seemed like Yet Another vertical scrolling rhythm game to bang keyboard keys to.
But then I tried playing using a controller - a Dualshock 3 in my case.
DJMAX's charting plays phenomenally with a controller. I like rhythm games designed around unique peripherals (dancepads, guitars, etc), and I had a ton of fun playing DJMAX with my DS3. Bought the game at the end of the free weekend, and have since gained an appreciation for the game's presentation and content.

Also keysounds are really neat - every button will play a sound from the song, such that playing on time makes you feel like you're actually "playing the song".
But be warned, keysounds demand that your setup has minimal audio latency - no wireless, no enhancements.
There's zero calibration features either (note output is not a calibration!), so hopefully your monitor is low-latency as well.

The game & DLC go on sale every few months, and every sale so far has shown deeper discounts than the previous, so keep an eye out. Deluxe edition is the best edition to start out with.
It's always fun pressing keys in time to the music.

Beautifully crafted rhythm game in the vein of Beatmania IIDX with a wide array of excellent music, high quality BGAs, and 4 different button modes each providing a wide range of difficulty for players of all skill levels. :-)

If you are looking for a "premium" rhythm game for PC (besides arcade rhythm game home ports) this is most likely your best bet. It has a standard vsrg mechanic but it makes it feel innovative with the addition of the Side Tracks and the interesting way they implemented 8k into the game. It also has VERY much songs with a lot of variety in genres. Naturally, you can gain access to most of it via DLC but for beginners, the main game by itself has enough songs to keep you hooked. It also isn't that expensive if you wait for a sale. I got almost all of the DLCs with the base game for like 60-70eur max. The full game offers a lot of variety with songs and gameplay mechanics which are very unique. You can pour a lot of hours in it and even after that you can still strive to push your limits. Whether you are an old fan of the series or someone completely new to this franchise (like me), if you like rhythm games even a little bit, you won't be disappointed.

DJMax Respect V is hands down the top rhythm game out there right now.
They've made some serious improvements, making the game way more stable, fixed up multiplayer, with better performance and some new top notch note charts!
The gameplay is satisfying, the music is on point, and the graphics are killer.

They've added "Seasons", which gives you more reasons to keep playing, but I gotta mention the price...
The base game and DLC songs can hit your wallet pretty hard.
Still, if you're a hardcore rhythm game fan, I'd say it's worth splurging on.

I love this game so much. I started playing on PS4 and even bought an Ezmax controller to play it. I decided to get it again on steam as it's now the lead platform and I love it, but it's such a shame it runs so terribly on steam deck.

There is no reason why it won't run well eventually but for now keep this in mind if that is the way you are thinking of playing. Performance hovers around 45-50fps which for a rhythm game is shocking.
Annoys everyone in my house with the loud keyboard taps. 10/10 recommend to anyone wanting to annoy their siblings.

I think the game is quite fun, and there are great tracks and very fun to play tracks and lots of varying difficulty for everyone to enjoy. However, I have two main issues with the game.

First is the steep price barrier to the game and the multiplayer experience. So many songs are locked behind DLC, as well as an ingame "Season Pass" that not only contains cosmetics, but I also found a song in my list that was locked behind this season pass which comes out quite frequently. Furthermore, friends can not access your DLC songs in a multiplayer lobby, and on top of that, there is no indicator of which songs they actually have access to, which creates a huge headache when trying to chill and play with friends when you have to constantly ask them "hey can you play this one?". I bought the game for a friend to play with hoping to show them some songs that I enjoy playing and the multiplayer experience was just really lacking with them being paywalled.

My second problem is the lack of a practice mode. Most great rhythm games I've played have a slowdown and skip to the portion of a song for training. It is extremely frustrating to try and push to more difficult songs in this game trying to sight read sections that are moving too fast to parse while just smashing keys trying to finish the song. It doesn't feel good to beat songs in this way, but no help is given to the player to learn the songs better.

I enjoy the game quite a bit, but I cant reasonably recommend it to anyone that's looking for more than a casual solo rhythm game.

First keyboard rhythm game. Know it when searching for Oblivion. It makes me love this type.
Pros:
1.Decent music library. Personally reckon it satisfies my taste more than Ez2on.
2.The art and the MVs made by themselves are extraordinary. They can probably win a prize for their BGA if they participate in BOF (if with a good piece of music)
Cons:
1. Expensive, for both base game and DLCs as well as season pass. Prepare to empty your wallet every 3 months!!!
2. UI and display. As there are very few competitors in this domain, DJMRV is a little bit lazy in improving UI when still using the design mode from 10 years ago, wasting your precious time on scrolling through a vast list of music. Also, not enough support for more recently popular display resolution (though I know in this case many artwork pieces need redoing, the price deserves such improvement)
Misc:
1. You receive loads of kawaii emojis in game and also those fanmade ones if you are in a forum or groupchat of DJMRV
2. DPC(DJMax Pattern design Competition) every year which is one of the very rare case in all rhythm games since it is embed in game and players get to vote for them by giving marks after playthorugh. The transparency and fairness are questionable though.

This game isn't for the free-to-play demographic, with its arcade roots. You can dump $200 in this game and it's still cheaper than dumping $40-100 per night into a beat mania arcade machine.

6 button play brings song-to-song variance for great replay-ability. Initial difficulty is challenging for anyone new to the genre but 4 button mode makes it more accessible. Song packs go on sale for 75% off regularly so save your money for a sale. The respect packs, muse dash, and cytus packs are all good.  Rest are so-so.

Some tips:

* Turn on ASIO if your sound card supports it, it cuts down audio lag drastically
* Do the calibration in the settings
* Turn your monitor brightness up for better visibility
* 240hz monitors definitely give an advantage, with clearer visibility (less jumping)
* Use the zoom buttons to zoom in a bit and get better timing
* Use a mechanical keyboard
* Take breaks.  Take many breaks.  Sometimes it's better to go a few days or even a week without playing.
* Play 6 button songs as soon as you can.
* Turn off the background animation for the 2-3 songs that have too much strobing, it makes it easier to see the notes

Old review:
This game is kinda complicated for me and I bet a lot who played think the same way.

Pros:
- 150 songs base game (decent amount although with that price tag, you kinda wish there would be at least 200)
- A great variety of music genres, from Asian to Western songs, from the pop. rock, rap songs to electronic, dubstep
- Charts are beautifully crafted especially in 6 buttons and 8 buttons mode.
- Online match have 2 modes: ranked and open. Ranked is stressful but fun, open matches you can play with your friends and beat the sh1t out of them :))))
- Key sound notes
- Amazing ORIGINAL soundtracks especially in the Extensions DLCs (recommended 10/10 have to buy)
- Beautiful and slick UI and you can custom the UI to your preferred theme.
- Vibrant and colorful BGAs 
- Controller supported from Normal to Maximum difficulty except SC difficulty (which makes sense since SC is only for keyboard play)

Cons:
- At full price, overly expensive from its base game to the DLCs 
- A lot of BGAs are in 4:3 display ratio due to its MVs are very old and not being remaked for modern 16:9 ratio display
- NOTE: this game runs on XIGNCODE3 - an anti-cheat/ online DRM. It's truly a slap in the face for a single player experience 95% of the time
- Some songs don't support key sound notes (E.g Cytus and Deemo DLCs packs)
- Air mode is just......meh, the comments show on screen are all pre-recorded and not live. It doesn't track your scores or your combos so why is this even a thing??????
- Overpriced season pass that gives you nothing but cosmetic items for....a rhythm game??? which nobody would look or care anyway because they're too busy beating your a$$ in a ranked match

Conclusions:
This is a great rhythm game but has some fundamental problems such as online DRM and a questionable price tag. Even so, I love this game for what it is and I CAN'T STOP PLAYING THIS GAME HELP MEEEEEEEEEE. I genuinely have a lot of fun playing it and this is one of the few that give that triple A feeling due to its huge support from the devs and its community

P/S: - Buy this game and the DLCs when it's on sales which happen every few months so wishlist it because the price will go down from 50% to 80% discount with the base game a 80% discount which is a more reasonable and cheaper price.
- Check carefully which DLCs you are buying because there are soundtracks, gear skins and song packs that are blended together pretty badly and easily get confused. 
- If you are going to buy the DLCs, buy the EXTENSIONS DLCS first no matter what you won't regret it.
- And for the love of GOD, don't buy the unlock songs pack because you will eventually unlock all of it the more you play (it's a progression system), why would you want to spend more money to PLAY LESS, think about it.
- If you only interested in 4k/4 buttons mode and not 5B, 6B or 8B then DJMax might not be the game for you since there are a lot of other competitions that have Mania style gameplay and you will missed out like 80% of what the game can give you.

I've played many rhythm games over the years. I would describe my interest in them as "hardcore" and my skill in them as "average." Additionally, most rhythm games I've played are free and fan-made, so DJMAX Respect V is one of the few rhythm games I've spent money on.

DJMAX Respect V was previously on Xbox Game Pass and I was immediately sucked in. DJMAX is easy to pick up if you're new to rhythm games, especially with both keyboard and controller available as inputs. I think this is important because it's very easy to try diving into a rhythm game and get dejected by a skewed learning curve. It can either be too easy or too difficult. The main reason I found DJMAX to be worth buying is because it is easy to start but the skill ceiling seems incredibly high. I can't confirm the veracity of that statement because whatever the skill ceiling is, I'm not even close to it yet.

Compare that to Stepmania (a Dance Dance Revolution clone) for example, where the increase in difficulty tends to involve adding more steps until you cross the threshold from something that is fun and challenging to something too intimidating to bother learning. I'm looking at you, 30+ rated Stepmania charts. That said, I acknowledge a lot of the complexity from those insane charts comes down to the open/fan-created culture for Stepmania's charts: "Let's just see what's possible lol."

DJMAX doesn't have this problem because you can choose between 4, 5, 6, or 8-button versions of the different charts. When you are nearing a difficulty plateau, you can decide if you want to tread into the most difficult 4-buttons or try something new with easy/mid-difficulty 5 or 6-button charts. If taking that leap was too much, you can always step a few steps back. There is always a fun, challenging difficulty available to you (or at least there will be for a very, very long time). You can get tired of using a controller and switch to using a keyboard or vice versa. After you've been playing a while, it's always fun to enjoy some songs that you can max combo easily as a non-challenging way to unwind.

DJMAX offers a lot for a rhythm game, and I haven't even touched the Challenges mode or competitive online play. However, I have dipped into the "Air" mode where you pick the number of buttons you want to play and a difficulty range and the game just plays one song after another. In a sense you are playing with others who can type in chat, but it isn't competitive. This is yet another mode that is great for either relaxing (picking a low button count or low difficulty range) or trying something more difficult without fear of failure (you can't fail in Air mode). And you can adjust your difficulty range/button mode after each song (but you have to change it before the next song automatically starts ~20 seconds later).

On Xbox/PC Game Pass, I made it to level 60 or so before the game was removed from that service. For scale, I'm about level 25+ in Freestyle (my favorite mode because I love to play with myself eyy) over the 8.5 hours I have clocked in at the time of this review. In reality, I've probably played over 40 hours of DJMAX so far.

Disclosures about my experience with this game:

A few days after this game was removed from Game Pass, DJMAX was on sale for $10. Even though I could have cross-saving and all of that other fun stuff buying the game on the Microsoft Store (maybe?), I'm a cheapskate so Steam was the place to get it. Getting DJMAX at a steep discount and knowing that DLC for this game also goes on sale was the best decision for me personally. 

If you've played this game already on another platform (Xbox/PS/non-Steam PC) you cannot transfer your saved data. If that is important to you, stay on the platform you're already using. It was less apparent on the Game Pass version that DJMAX is a game-as-a-service, which I have to admit I loathe. The Game Pass version did not tell you about the current season or tell you about which profile customizations you can earn (or attempt to earn with a season pass). The Steam version does, and that annoys me. But it's not annoying enough to ruin the game.

This *does* mean you can't play this game offline, which I think is absolutely ridiculous. These are the reasons I don't work in game publishing: I don't understand how any of this "season x," "battle pass," "enhanced live-gaming whatever-the-fudge," crap works. I was playing a moment ago and it appears that a season pass adds playable songs to your library, but don't take my word for it.

For hardcore rhythm players (that for some reason haven't played this game already), here are some details that may irk you about DJMAX V Respect:

-Combo leniency: this game really wants you to keep a combo. There have been instances where I know I biffed it by screwing up my timing--badly. But because I somehow still hit the buttons in the correct order, I kept my combo. Your overall score will still reflect your poor accuracy, but you still get the combo that feels unearned. However, this is mostly negated by:

-Note accuracy scoring: like most rhythm games, your scoring is based on accuracy, displayed by MAX n% for each note. You can get 1% accuracy on a note and keep a combo but your score will not impress anyone, especially yourself. Accuracy is measured in multiples of 10, save the 1% which I feel fits into the game's philosophy of being forgiving while being accurate for players that care about that.

-Key sound feature*: DJMAX has a feature/setting named key sound, that assigns musical sounds/notes/elements to the button you are supposed to hit in time. This feature can be annoying for players struggling because you can literally hear how bad you're playing, but it's a fun feature that increases the feeling you are actually playing the song. When replaying your favorite songs, you can hit extra notes to add sounds to the song that aren't actually there, which can be fun for making songs your own as you master them. Hitting extra notes doesn't affect your combo/score as long as those added notes don't interfere with the notes that are required.

*key sound is not available in all songs

-Background animations (BGMs): These can be extremely distracting or annoying (even if the BGM is cool). As expected, you can easily disable BGMs entirely.

-Freeze/hold notes: notes that require the button to be held down for a longer duration are scored with what some would consider extreme accuracy. If you hold the note longer than its required length, your accuracy is automatically reduced to 1% for that note. It can be a fun or annoying mechanic based on your mood.

In the end, DJMAX Respect V has enough content to be worth its full retail price. I knew that when I was playing it "for free" on Game Pass. However, I'm stingy enough that I waited for the right, giant discount to buy it. Although I occasionally have a waking nightmare about the day I can't play this game anymore because it's publisher/developer stops maintaining it (or the internet is out), it's worth it. 

If you love rhythm games and the full retail price is a drop in the bucket for you, get this game! Otherwise, wait for a sale and pick up this incredibly fun, time-suck of a game. 

Note: please correct any inaccuracies in this review with a comment! I don't know if I'll be able to edit this after posting because it's my first review.

Also, feel free to express your differing opinions in the comments. :)

Absolutely one of, if not the best Rhythm game ever made. The music and game play is amazing, but what sets Respect V apart from the rest of the genre is the amazing plethora of options. For starters, every song has 4 input options, in 4, 5, 6 and 8. (A few songs will throw in another 2 buttons in every mode, for heavily synthesized notes, but it's only a handful.) And there's at least 2 difficulties for each of these input options, with most having 3 or 4. If like a song, but the note layout is stale, there are two sets of modifiers you can apply. Some will switch which track the notes appear in, some will adjust the speed of the notes until you make a mistake. You want the screen to lose resolution until you mess up? Yeah, that's a thing too.

You can freely change the speed of the notes, even during the song. If the song's Background music video is too distracting, you can turn it off. You can move your note track to the left or right side of the screen, if you don't like the default center option.

There's a range of UI options you can pick from as well, even though the default is sleek. You can change the note appearance, track design, even the main menu. For me, I come from Deemo and Muse Dash, so seeing that there's collab UI and themes for both of those games was very neat. I occasionally pop on the Guilty Gear stuff too. The only things that don't have a changeable aspect is the song selection menu, and the multiplier activation sound (but there are unlocks for this in the battle passes).

The online is great too, a ranked mode where you can get your ass kicked by the guys who have been playing this game for years, and a casual room where you and some friends, or strangers can play the same song together. In this room mode, everyone picks their own UI, difficulty, and modifiers, and while you play, you can see what everyone picked as you play along.

There's a mission  mode that has pre-made conditions for you  to play through. Like "play these three songs but the notes  fade away halfway through the track." There's also a list of in game achievements not listed among the steam achievements that give you new music and UI elements.

There are only two things I dislike about this game. 1. No crossplay with PS4/PS5 as that version of the game is just "DJMax Respect" and not "DJMax Respect V" so if you have any friends with t his  game on PS, you can't play together unless one of you gets the other version. 2.No local multiplayer in Respect V. Despite the PS  version having it, there is no option for that here. Hopefully that changes, but this game has been out for a while and I don't see that happening anytime soon.

Playing a half of a guitar melody along with the approximate up-and-down pattern in the melody then switching three times per second to different drum sounds, vocal rhythm, chimes etc. on the same keys. I started the DJ Max series with DJ Max Portable on PSP.  It evolved over time, sometimes for better and sometimes for worse, but it's generally always been a good experience, including this one.

My updated list of issues with Respect: 
[list]
[*] The always-online DRM
[*] Songs being locked behind DLC packs, most of which I only want 2 or 3 songs.  (Just like when I used to buy CD albums.)
[*] The full combo sound cannot be muted, like the fever sound can.  Why?
[*] The usual Battle Pass system, which forced me to spend $15 to get a clear sound that's slightly less annoying than the default one (I didn't care about the other unlocks).
[*] Honestly, some of the re-mappings of songs have really upset me because they were fun on PSP and now they're gone or don't feel right.  Some of the reworks were for the better, but a lot of the time I prefer the original and go back to it.  I wish there was an option to switch over to the original version(s) of the songs in a "Legacy Mode" or something.
[*] On a similar note, I want to be able to set all the original BGAs for songs.  I know that there's "secret" BGAs that randomly will play the original for a few like Never Say, but I want those at all times.  I actually heavily dislike the new BGAs (sorry whomever created them) to the point where I don't even want to play the songs.  This is especially true for Dreadnaught, which I can't even play anymore...the original BGA is what made it and it just feels off without it.
[/list]
Overall, I enjoy it.  DJ Max is a series that I love very much for the song selection, note sounds on hitting buttons, and the general feel of playing it.  You play one difficulty level and/or button amount then try another and discover new parts of the song.  Often, you're playing multiple parts of the song at the same time, swapping between hands.  At first it seems daunting but when it starts to click, it feels really good to play.

I've heard good things about the DJMAX series on PSP, but never got around to play it. Having Respect V as the first experience, I must say it is everything I like in an arcade rhythm game.

It has the same base of rhythm games with colored buttons, like Beatmania or Guitar Hero, but if feels more modern on some design choices. The option to allow you to change the track speed on the fly during the gameplay? Amazing. The option to choose between 4,5,6 and 8 button play, each with its own difficulty modes? I love it, it adds so much to the progression and learning curve!

Also, it has so much content. Tracks (including songs from the previous games of the series), cosmetic unlocks, challenges, online ranked play... and Air Mode, which is kinda pointless, but you know, it's there!

It is expensive, but I've played a lot of the base game on xbox gamepass and got it on steam sale with 2 expansion packs, definetly worth it.

An excellent rhythm game in the style of DDR. Where other rhythm games try and do something new with the rhythm genre, DJMAX just does scrolling notes really really well, with loads of variety of music, difficulty settings, and patterns. Music ranges from metal or hard rock to K/J-pop, electronic, and just weird rhythm heaven-esk experiments. All are accompanied with an animated movie that are often kind of a trip. 

The skill ceiling for the game is super high, but that doesn't mean that there isn't a ton of content for the semi-casual player (like myself). I dip in every few weeks for a few hours, and I've slowly worked up to playing a lot of songs on 6B medium (occasional hard). It's incredibly rewarding to not only conquer songs I distinctly remember trying and immediately quitting out of, but to then go a step up on the difficulty and repeat the struggle/success cycle. 

My favourite part of the game is the quality of some of the note patterns. While not all the songs are for me, there are a good number that are both A) bangers and B) have perfect note patterns that really pull you into the music.

--- For new / struggling players (from a not great player):

I highly recommend avoiding 4 button mode, and instead try 6-button as early as you can as the patterns become more engaging and interesting and it's that interest that will keep you trying and learning and getting better. 

Customise the game to make it comfortable for you. The UI is customisable, although some options will be locked behind achievements or require DLC. Turn up or down the note scroll speed. When I started, I would tape a little arrow/divider to my monitor that split the chart near the bottom to help me learn the muscle memory of which hand is which (especially as the colours are the same for the two inner tiles). 

The game heavily penalises missing multiple notes in a row and doesn't really penalise hitting buttons without a note present, so if you are learning a new song/difficulty don't be afraid or embarrassed to mash out some of the intense sections just so you can finish the song. Every time you play it, those sections will start to make more sense and eventually you won't be mashing anymore. 

Pick & favourite some songs that you really like that are too difficult for you to complete comfortably. Even if you're just barely (mashing) getting through them, continuously pushing yourself to try harder songs than you can reasonably play accurately will drastically improve your skill in other songs more suited for your currently skill level. 

DLC's a bit pricey at full price, but regularly go on sale. Just get the base or deluxe version and then pick up DLC down the line. You can listen to previews of songs in DLC you don't own via freeplay, use that to decide which packs to get/skip. 

Have fun! Push yourself to try and fail harder songs, but also make sure to keep some comfortable favourites you can just jam to and keep the good vibes going.

I love rhythm games even if I'm not all that great with them anymore (I've developed neurologic issues in the years since I was playing DJMAX TECHNIKA in arcades,) and DJMAX RESPECT is a great way to relive this nostalgia. The base game comes with songs from Portable 1 and 2, along with new songs from RESPECT, which I enjoy a lot. I have a soft spot for the Portable Clazziquai Edition since I'm a huge fan of the Clazziquai Proejct itself, so I managed to get the DLC when the game was on sale. 

Even if you feel intimidated with the game at first, there isn't much of a learning curve, compared to similar games. The licensed songs (i.e. ESTi's work with Yukika) make the purchase well worth it in spite of less expensive alternatives. There's also something for players of the older games to enjoy, as some older songs received BGA updates.

For what it's worth, even as someone who doesn't play ranked anymore in rhythm games, there's a lot for me to enjoy. You can challenge yourself with Missions, or just relax in Air mode when breaking your combo in Freestyle might otherwise infuriate you.

Bought this while on sale and you definitely get enough base content for that price. I can't say that I can justify a full price purchase considering the amount of DLC content and its prices, but that's up to the individual. On the single player end, you get an arcade and mission mode. Fairly standard for rhythm games but one mechanic that stood out to me was in the online ranked mode. You're put into a 1v1 best two out of three win scenario. The scoring system is based on accuracy instead of bigger combos unlike other rhythm games, which makes for a more "back-and-forth" type of gameplay. Instead of relying on hopes and dreams that your opponent breaks their combo before you do, you can focus on your own efforts to keep a good accuracy and not be punished with a loss by missing one note. This make for more close call matches to happen, making your wins that much more satisfying and your losses that less salty. This refreshing gameplay being topped off with a clean UI, responsive inputs, and nostalgic visuals makes this a great addition to the rhythm game market and a must try for enthusiasts of the genre.

As someone who doesn't play many rhythm games, I wouldn't recommend this one. This is coming from an unskilled perspective. The beatmaps are really unintuitive, not lining up to any particular flow or instrument in the song. The lower difficulty settings are also excessively boring, but the next step up is always too fast.

The game doesn't really have an intended progression path. It just dumps you into an alphabetically sorted list of songs. You can play easy to start but if you're as bad as me you'll still Game Over on many "Easy" setting songs. I wish it had a string of specific songs to bring someone like me from zero skill to skilled. Atleast enough to enjoy the rest of the list.

Also importantly, the music only plays if you hit notes, and when you hit them. I actually really like this, if your timing is off you can hear it sounds wrong. And you don't get to hear the music proper unless you hit the notes with good timing. 
But if you're pretty bad at these games like I am it means you won't get to enjoy the music. I like the feature and it shows how much work they put into each song's map. But without some campaign or something to slowly ramp up difficulty, it means I'm left hearing messed-up music and Game Over-ing over and over.

Finally the music selection was not what I expected. From the trailers and material you sorta expect a lot of electronic genre, house sorta, etc. But there are more pop-music-like songs and frankly not much I liked. Also they lock a lot of songs behind progression, and charge money to unlock them if you can't grind out progression. Atleast one of the bangers they feature in the steam trailer was locked behind progression because I couldn't find it.

I can't recommend this to anyone with low skill like me.

There are a few things one can complain about, but by far the biggest issue is the fact that this game has massive sync issues on default windows. Some people say it's not a big deal. "Just sight-read". Yeah, no. Being able to slap your keys to the beat is the very reason these games exist in the first place.

The good news: You can fix it.

The bad news: It can take hours of fiddling with windows (depending on how merciful the machine god happens to be, and how good you are at solving tech issues). You have to install an ASIO sound driver, configure it, then go into the game and sync both, the chart flow AND the judgment timing. It's a pain in the butt, and you will likely go well past the 2-hour refund window dealing with it. You have been warned.

After that, it's pretty much smooth sailing.

For reference:
I use FlexASIO, with in-game timings set to 60 and 10, and Nvidia Reflex On + Boost (not sure it even does anything).

Usually, I'd dish out a red thumb for this, but the developer has at least made an effort to help fix the issue, and I feel there's only so much they can do.

Don't be fooled by it's high-roller collabs with LoL, this game fucking blows. I played it for as long as I did because I was between computers and I couldn't be asked to move my massive Osu! map storage from PC to PC as often as I would have to, and I needed my rhythm game fix.

Some people may enjoy this, but it has the weird "hold a key and continue to play the game outside that key" thing that was used on like maybe 4 beatmaps total on osu before 2020, like every single map. This isn't a strict negative but i fucking hate it. I personally prefer the tried and true method of pure single-key flow, with holds interspersed as appropriate. Skill issue? Almost certainly. Do i still fucking hate it? Yes.

Even putting that aside, the maps are all choppily made, approaching 0 flow, notes scattered haphazardly with no regard to what preceded nor what will follow. In the base game there are maybe 3 or 4 maps I loved, 3 or 4 maps I liked regardless of how good they were (the LoL ones, 60% of the reason i played the game to begin with) and like 60 ones that were shit and i played because i felt like i needed to, in order to get my money's worth.

TL;DR: download Osu!, download free player-made maps in-game, and even if every 5th one is worth playing, you'll still be getting more value than this dogheap.

I've amended my review to a recommend in a vacuum.
But if you just want rhythm game gameplay, try some free alternatives like osu!mania, etterna, or even stepmania first .

DJMax has a very polished UI, and while alternatives like osu!mania can be modded to a similar level, it will take some effort.

Main difference is 'key sounds' (i.e. hitting notes plays elements of the song instead of a set sound effect, for a more interactive experience), which can be off-putting to rhythm game players, but is mostly appreciated from the existing player base.

Settings are extensive, including offset timing, note speeds, keybinds, and audio buffer size. A very nice feature for veteran rhythm game players is the ability to change some of these settings like note speeds IN-GAME.

The whole package costs an arm and a leg, so get it on sale.
Gameplay and presentation are fantastic, but I cannot get behind these monetization practices. Get it while it's on sale like I did... or just play Quaver or osu mania instead (they're free!)

[h1]Heavily overpriced for the piece of VSRG, buy it when it's on sale.[/h1]
The base game offers decent visuals and good amount of songs that would potentially attract lots of novice players. What about veterans? I don't think so. This game fails to fulfill the cup of teas for veterans because there are insufficient amount of hard patterns to enjoy with only the base game. The majorities are locked behind the DLCs and they are way too expensive. They are not even worth their values. Even if you get them, I am certain that you would throw them away after playing couple songs so it's going to be an utter waste of money. The best choice is to turn around and go play OSU Mania or Quaver. They are both free.

Plus, the latest DLC songs give a lot of BGM vibes so it's ambiguous to tell that these songs are actually optimized for the rhythm game. It's like "why am I hitting notes for the background music?" Inspirations lost from this point, so it's nuh-uh for me.

The charts... are atrocious (I'm talking about the charts from the latest DLC songs). Most of them are legitimately piled with copy-and-paste, repetitive and unscrupulous patterns from top to bottom that can blow you away in twenty seconds. Devs are getting paid for making that, you know? Such an insult to the prestige of commercial VSRG.

The quality of charts started going downhill since the first Extension V DLC. Sad to see the good songs ruined by terrible charts. It feels like the devs lost spirits on charting patterns.

[h1]Performance Issues, random framerate drops[/h1]
It randomly stutters in the middle of the game, especially during online and ladder match. It barely happens on freeplay or missions. The slight stutter is already catastrophic enough to ruin the entire gameplay here and devs should know it very well, but they eventually neglected this issue for years.

[h1]Want to grow your muscles on your fingers for free?[/h1]
Like I said above, turn around and go play OSU Mania or Quaver. They offer better gaming experiences and charts than this game.

Title: DJMAX RESPECT V: A Melodic Masterpiece for Rhythm Game Enthusiasts

Rating: ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ

DJMAX RESPECT V, developed by Neowiz MUCA and released as the latest installment in the popular DJMAX series, delivers a mesmerizing rhythm game experience that is sure to captivate both veterans and newcomers alike. With its extensive music library, visually stunning presentation, and precise gameplay mechanics, this game stands out as a true celebration of music and rhythm.

One of the most impressive aspects of DJMAX RESPECT V is its vast collection of songs. Featuring over 200 tracks from various genres, including electronic, pop, rock, and more, the game offers an incredible amount of diversity in its musical selection. From well-known hits to hidden gems, each song is a carefully crafted masterpiece that immerses players in its unique atmosphere. The inclusion of both original compositions and licensed tracks further enhances the game's appeal.
