Now this is a pretty cool rhythm game, but it's not without its issues. First of all, here's the good stuff:

1. Probably one of the best looking rhythm games out there. The visual design is great with a ton of unlockable customization options that allow you to change your notes and play area and even the main menu UI/skin.
2. This one's subjective, but there's a lot of good songs to play here, especially if you invest into additional DLC packs. There's a lot of the songs that I like, but that's my taste -- look up the song list before you buy if you want to know what you'll be getting!
3. Game is super responsive and runs at a high framerate despite all the visual stuff! I'm running this on a GTX1080 and a Ryzen 5600X at the moment and I have not experienced a single performance issue running it at 1440p.
4. The game has multiplayer! You and your friends both have to have the DLC purchased if you want to play the songs from them, which kinda sucks, but otherwise, it's a nice feature. Each player has the option to freely choose their playstyle (the game has 4, 5, 6 and 8 key options) as well as the difficulty of the chart, which is great.

Now regarding some of the other things, I really have a bone to pick with this game.... Here they are.

[strike]1. KEYSOUNDS. This is by far the worst part about this game for me, although, I realize I might fall into a minority here, since a lot of people like them, but I HATE keysounds. They make no difference if you play good since you're just hearing the song as it would sound normally and if you play bad (like I do) they just throw you off because they make the song sound horrible. Worst part -- there's no way to disable them. I find this really upsetting and it definitely takes away from the experience for me. Having the ability to disable them and/or replace them with a generic "click" sound was something I was really hoping to find in the game, but unfortunately, it is not. [/strike] As of Season 9, there is now an option to disable keysounds, thank god.

2. Timing adjustment options are horrible. There's a weird option in the settings that allows you to change the offset in increments of 3ms (?!) but that's about it. When you actually play the songs it provides zero information how late or early your hits were. There doesn't even seem to be any sort of calibration mode where you can test your inputs for audio/input lag or any sort. Luckily, the game seems to be timed pretty well and I haven't had too many issues, but there were a couple of songs that really made me want to check the timing. Alas, I couldn't outside of just blindly trying to adjust the offset and seeing if I do better after the adjustment.

3. Health bar in Freestyle Mode is upsetting. It's very easy to fail a song in this game if you are as bad as I am, which is fine, but please give me a way to disable this so I can practice the goddamn song? Failing me on it every single time won't help me improve. Sure, make it so as that my score doesn't get submitted to the leaderboards, or whatever, I don't care - just let me play the song so I can practice it. That's how it works in multiplayer by default, why can't I do this in Freestyle mode? Maybe I'm an idiot and I missed an option for this? I dunno man.

I bought this game with some DLC during the sale and for the price that I paid I don't really regret it. The price of the game + DLC without the sale is a little steep and considering the game goes on sale for 60-70% off, I'd definitely recommend against buying this at full price and waiting for a sale in case you didn't manage to get it during the winter sale at the time of writing this!

Is it worth the price? a big fat [b]NO[/b], it's better to spend it on some other game. The price is so steep, you would've mistaken this for an EA published title, but it's not.

Is the game good? If you're looking for a traditional rhythm game that has varying number of keys, then this is the game for you, if you're looking for some groundbreaking innovation to the genre, then you'll be sorely disappointed.

Honestly you're better off playing OSU or something like O2Mania. If you're still looking to buy this, wait it at a discounted price.

DJMAX Respect V doesn't stand on much aside from it's foundation, but boy is it a solid foundation it stands on. Beatmania, Guitar Hero, Osu mania, every idol rhythm game, f***ing Piano Tiles; the formula of "press button when note comes down" is as old as the dawn of rhythm games, but I don't think it's ever been played straight (with no other gimmicks) as well as it has here.

There's no pointless story mode, no convoluted scoring system, no unlockable difficulties, or any of the other trivialities which weigh down otherwise fine games like this. It's just you vs the song, the frantic but controlled clicking of your keyboard a marker of your skill. This isn't to say the game offers no additional content; you've got Air Mode (which you'll never use), Mission Mode (which you'll barely use), and an Online Versus Mode (which you can use between 20-00 KST), but it's clear that the focus here was on making the core Freestyle grind as smooth as possible. All the features you'd ever need are there: note speed, customizable keybinds, offset, good song sorting, background dimming, hard as balls charts, etc.

If you're a veteran rhythm game player this is nice to hear. If you're not so familiar to the genre it might be intimidating, but DJMAX Respect V offers a really nice range of chart difficulties. Don't be discouraged if hard maps seem impossible, this is a game where the difficulties actually mean something, as opposed to a large number of rhythm games where true "hard" is limited to the last difficulty category. There's always a lot of charts which you can confidently full combo as a sign of your progress, a lot that push your skills to the limit, and a lot which seem absolutely impossible. In general, with up to 16 difficulties across 4 playstyles, most songs in the game will have at least one chart which feels right for you.

I've described DJMAX as having both the best and the worst song selection of all time. If you're not a veteran of the series (I was not), and especially if you are coming from Japanese rhythm games which are mostly filled with EDM, anime, and Vocaloid songs, the music here might come as a bit of a shock. A lot of songs, especially ones from older games, have some atypical charts with incredibly jarring keysounds. There's a big focus on older hip-hop and R&B, listen to something like "Get Out" on Youtube for a typical example. With time I've learned to embrace the difference, and some of the DJMAX OGs have become my favourite songs today, but it takes some getting used to. I obviously can't say for sure if you'll like the songs here, but what I can say is that there's a bigger [b]variety[/b] of music in DJMAX than in any other rhythm game on the market today (without mods). I don't think there's a single person who won't find a song they love here, just accept there will plenty of songs you think are garbage though :) If you're looking for a song select closer to the aforementioned Japanese rhythm game style, the V Extention DLCs and a lot of the Collab DLC have got you covered there.

Ending on the topic of DLC, you'll see this game has [b]a lot[/b]. Most of it is not new music, make sure you're buying the right thing (every song pack comes with a sick new UI so don't worry about missing out on visual flair). I think it's worth it, especially if you're finding the regular song selection is no longer cutting it for you, but please don't buy it (or the main game for that matter) at full price, everything here regularly goes on sale for 70%.

While the controls do get some getting used to, this game is probably one of, if not the best Rhythm games out right now. Mastering the hard charts is satisfying and the online multiplayer is fun and really intense at times

The one major criticism I have with it however is the price for the full package. Sure, over 150 songs are available in the base game to unlock and play but if you want not only all of the base songs unlocked right away but also every DLC pack, it is gonna cost you aprox $800 AUD ($533 USD) if you buy them all separately. Sure if you buy the bundle it costs 20% less but still... that is a lot of money for the full experience. Luckily, you can play the DLC tracks for free playing ranked matches but you can't chose the song or difficulty, and song selection is random.

Buy the base game and play it. The base game has enough content to keep you interested for hours and hours. However, if you want any of the DLC, wait for a sale because the base price of the DLC'S are not worth it

So, having played quite a bit of this, I can say... it's a rhythm game.  It has a lot of music, most of it is pretty good.  But also, some of it is really not.

My main gripe comes in their touted "online competitive" mode, which is pretty much just nothing but bots. 
 And the bots aren't even very realistic.  In even the bronze tier, where it tells me I'm in bottom 2% of players on ladder, and usually facing opponents who are "ranked" lower than me, I have yet to face an opponent who didn't max combo literally every song, regardless of difficulty.  I mean, c'mon, I don't have a problem facing bots in games if there aren't enough players for matchmaking, but it's really annoying when they don't even tell you (also looking at you, Marvel Snap).

Anyway, aside from that it's a pretty competently made game, if not a little basic.  I'd definitely give this a solid "meh" if that was a Steam option, but since it's not, gonna go with the thumbs down for sort of shady competitive mechanics.

This game is a very good addition to anyone's rhythm game collection.  Be warned, however, as there are some major negatives to this game that I will outline in my cons later on in this review.

DJMAX RESPECT V is a rhythm game that offers players a wide variety of songs to select from and allows you to play with several different numbers of buttons.  There's more to it than that, but I'd like to keep the in short section brief.  

In short, the base game offers a variety of songs, however, it is much less in scope than what you would get if you bought the DLC that comes along with the game.  Furthermore, you are limited in what songs you can select at first because of a level system that was implemented into the game.  As your level increases, more songs from the base game unlock, offering you new songs to play.  I'm not too fond of this system, as it leads to a player who is impatient to inevitably buy the "Unlock all songs" DLC that they offer.  The DLC as well are fairly steep in price for what you get and Neowiz has added in seasons and "season pass" systems into the game to further monetize the game.  I'm not a huge fan of this.  The game offers a great amount of customization, but a lot of it you have to unlock first.  While it might seem like I'm rattling off a long list of negatives in this in short segment, there are plenty of positives to go along with them.

Pros and Cons:

Pros:
+A wide variety of music to play, with a wide selection of genres to choose from.  Please note that not everything included in this game will be to your liking.
+Great customization options, once you unlock them.
+As with most rhythm games, the music itself must be extremely good, and this game has some of the best music that I've heard in a rhythm game.
+Offers online Open Matches and Ladder Matches so you can go head to head with players from around the world, or your friends on Steam.
+Offers a wide variety of options to help mold the game into what you like, including remapping keys to changing the offset and judgment timings.
+A lot of the tracks are keymapped, where as you play, you add parts to the song.  Basically, each key is mapped to a different sound which plays when you hit the key.  When you play the song and hit the keys in time with the notes that appear on the beatmap, the sounds that play add to the song already playing to provide an even more in-depth feel to the music as you play.  Note that not every song is keymapped in this fashion.

Cons:
-In order to get the most out of this game, you pretty much have to buy the DLC song packs, all of which are fairly steep in price.  You can usually get these DLC on sale during the major Steam sales for a good deal, and this is what I would recommend doing for most of the DLC this game has to offer.
-The game has introduced "Seasons" into the game, along with Season Passes (equivalent to Battle Passes from other games).  The Season Passes themselves are free, but they also give you the option to buy the Premium Season Pass, which gives you more customization options.  In addition to that, they've also started offering Clear Boosters, which boost the number of points that are added to the Season Pass whenever you clear a song.  All of these things makes it seem like they are trying to milk their playerbase out of as much money as they can.
-Not every difficulty is available on every song for each button mode.  Songs seem to have random difficulties assigned to them and have maps charted to them for just those difficulties.  Each number of buttons also has a different difficulty selection.  What this can lead to is a lack of playable content for those that either are really good at those number of buttons, or for those who are just starting out playing those number of buttons.  This point goes hand in hand with the next con:
-There is no 7K mode.  7K is one of the most popular key amounts in other rhythm games, yet this game doesn't offer 7K.  While I understand that this series of games usually do not offer 7K, I just find it odd that they don't offer it.
-The achievements.  Here's where things really start to get on my nerves.  First off, there are achievements for online game modes, which means once the online service is stopped, these achievements are no longer able to be gotten.  Furthermore, some of the online mode achievements are fairly difficult, which could lead to some players not getting them.  There are also achievements that either demand perfection from you, or demand a large amount of your time.  One such achievement that demands a lot of your time is reaching 999,999 combos.  In Freestyle mode, the combo you get in one track carries over into the next track you play and keeps doing so until you miss a note.  Basically, what this achievement wants you to do is literally not miss a note for well over 100 songs in a row.  While this can easily be cheesed by playing an extremely easy song with a high combo over and over, it just comes down to tedium.  There are also achievements that ask you to get a MAX COMBO on every song in the pack, which can also be very difficult if the easiest difficulty of a song in the pack isn't the actual easiest difficulty the game can offer.  There's also achievements for the overall score you get (every difficulty on every key number counts towards this, but replaying the same song you just played and gotten a score on does NOT count towards increasing this score unless you get a better score on said song).  Basically, this forces you to play a lot of the other key numbers in order to be able to increase your max score so that you can get these achievements.

While I do think that this is a great addition to any rhythm gamer's library, there are caveats to this.  The first is that I only recommend this game if it is on a discount, and I only recommend the song pack DLCs if they are on discount.  I would also only get this game if you plan on playing it a lot and you've actually heard some of the songs on offer with this game beforehand so that you know that there are at least a few songs in this game that you will enjoy playing.

Pros:
Very good rhythm game overall.
Songs are well-mapped
Very well polished in a lot of areas.
Most songs are keysounded, which makes playing them feel a lot nicer.
Lots of very nice original songs made for DJMax from previous games.

Cons:
Most of the previously mentioned original songs are only availeable as overpriced DLC
Always online. If the servers ever go down for good, you no longer own this game.
Xingcode 3 anti-cheat and DRM, extremely invasive.
Base-game has an arguably low amount of songs for the price.
Regional pricing has made buying the game and/or the DLCs in some countries a good way to not be able to pay rent.


I want to recommend this game, it's been very fun, but it's really hard to look at Neowiz and just not think they're being greedy. 
DJMax Trilogy was originally the game that got me way back into rhythm games a long long time ago, so this franchise does meet a lot to me, and unfortunately it has always been like this. It's just a bit sad, really. Worth noting you can't easily play DJMax Trilogy legally anymore, due to that game's DRM, and it wasn't even always-online.

If you must try DJMax Respect V, try it on XBox's Game Pass, if you have the chance.


But in the end, I can't say DJMax Respect V is worth buying. Maybe I'm just poor and DJMax is just that fancy restaurant I can't afford, the one where the food tastes good partly because it's nicely cooked and partly because you spent 80 bucks on that dish, so really you *have* to enjoy it.

As a little history, I spent all my highschool years grinding Cytus 1, even doing 1v1 Cytus with a friend during lunch. Cytus 1 has so far been my only real rhythm game experience and I found no game with music like it that has hooked me since. So when I found out DJMax Respect had a Cytus AND a Deemo pack, I brought it. DJMax has since then became my go to rhythm game of choice and has reignited my passion for Rhythm games in general. 

I love a lot of music in this game, aside from giving me more Cranky, T+Pazolite and NeiN to listen to, it has introduced me to ampstyle (RIP my friend), Boogy Voxx thanks to the Muse Dash pack, USAO, MYUKKE and all the NB Ranger songs. On top of having gameplay that doesn't give me a pain induced aneurysm (Looking at you, Osu and Voez) and a load of UI themes meaning I can listen the banger songs on my home screen as well is cool as fuck. 

My only complaints are that I hate I can't turn off key sounding. I know you weirdos hate it when a song doesn't have keysounding but some of us want to be able to enjoy the song without our own fuckups being heard and therefore throwing off my concentration. Also, I hate for solo play, you can't play most of the songs until you unlock them through level ups so I can't practice songs like Black Cat outside of multiplayer. Fix those two problems and I think this is a perfect rhythm game for people who just wanna slap buttons to the beat to. My only wishes right now is another Cytus pack that ports the Cytus 1 songs (let me play Libra Me and Gate Of Expectancy please) and maybe a collab pack with Vocaloid, just maybe.

This game is great, but I‚Äôll be completely honest NEOWIZ has absolutely no idea what they're doing.

DJMAX as a franchise in its own continues to be one of the strongest "vanilla" scrolling highway rhythm games out there and the music selection and gameplay in RESPECT V continues that legacy as it has to be one of the best I have ever played.

However, most of the good music is locked away in DLC packs which require you to spend much more then you need to. At A$70 you'd figure that the game would have a ton more to offer in terms of content but really it's lacking for the base game and most of the songs are locked behind progression (which is not necessarily a bad thing, but encourages players who don't want to play the same thing over and over to buy the UNLOCK SONG PACK.). If you really want to get as much as you can out of this game, you'll have to spend an extra A$100 to get a decent chunk of songs that will keep you satisfied.

The large amount of money that needs to be spent just to unlock the majority of the game is not helped by the fact that the game has Online-only DRM. What happens to all your cash when the servers go down? Redundant, Useless, Burned in a pile with everyone else. It's disgusting to see a game which very clearly doesn't need to be always-online built in a way where it has to be. The game also has the dreadful XIGNCODE 3 anticheat (which is not even mentioned on the store page!!!) which while not as bad as something to the likes of Denuvo, it certainly hinders performance to a noticeable extent.

Alongside this, NEOWIZ's business model for RESPECT V's longevity has been disappointing. There is a battle pass now that constantly blares in your face to check it out and costs a really dumb and stupid A$22 for one season's PREMIUM TICKET. Every time a season start's there's always a pointless 10GB update which doesn't seem to contribute anything to the game. All of the seasons introduce nothing but cosmetics and nothing in gameplay. Maybe a season will release alongside a new DLC pack but will never be the result of the season pass. It's frankly kind of disgusting to think that this can be allowed and continues to happen in a rhythm game of all things.

As per the actual game itself, it's quite good. The gameplay has to be one of the most fluid and easiest to pick up I‚Äôve ever tried. I do have a few nit-picks like how the UI (especially after the battle pass being added) is particularly mediocre, there is no mouse support in the game, so everything is keybound. The game is built for controller support so I do have to give them that, but it can become annoying sometimes especially with a cluttered menu that could be much easier to navigate with a mouse.

I enjoy that most Gear with the exception of a couple DLC inclusions are keyframed rather than a sprite that runs on 60fps, meaning that even on high refresh rates there aren't any weird desyncs where the gameplay is 144fps, but some animations are 60fps. I also enjoy the accessibility in Gear as there are a few with both shapes and pills for notes, but this also segues to my next point.

The game isn't exactly clear on how to unlock things. It's great with the amount of content you can actually get without paying a cent, but in terms of helping you figure out how to get there? It isn't exactly helpful. The songs in the game are unlocked with every level up until LV.99 which is somewhat straightforward but is not easy considering after 28 hours, I believe I am still LV.40. On the other hand, miscellaneous stuff like Icons, Plates or most importantly, Gear, is not exactly clear on how to get them. For example, The TAPSONIC Gear requires you to get the corresponding achievement for clearing 60 6K songs... but never tells you this? On the Gear selector it simply tells you what the gear looks like and what it's called, and nothing else.

To sum up, this game is great, and is most likely one of the best Stepmania like games on steam. But the way that NEOWIZ conducts its business with this game is making me feel complete sorrow to anyone that dumps all of their money into it.

If you want to get the game, buy it on sale, and buy the UNLOCK SONG PASS on sale. There is not a single other thing you are required to have and there is a great chance that once the servers go offline your money will go to waste anyways. Please try to limit your spending on this game.

Let me start by saying I've been playing DJ Max Respect on and off for about a year and only have approx. 34 hours at time of writing this review. If you like rhythm games and are willing to undergo a learning curve then this is the game to get. In the 34 hours I've played so far I have just finally become confident in my 4B tune playing and now feel the desire to move up to more buttons. The key to this game is having patience to fine tune the speed that works best for you and to map your buttons according to your specific play-style. The only frustrating thing that I can comment on is the exuberant price for DLC songs. If the game was F2P then I could understand the higher price tags for DLC but you're paying a pretty penny for the game itself and then shoveling money out to get more songs to play. That being said however, I have been quite satisfied with the season pass rewards as well as the DLC songs that I have bought. 

Tl;DR: If you like rhythm games and want to go down the rabbit hole this is your game. DLC is expensive but usually worth it.

It's games like this where I wish there was a "mixed" option. While I don't outright hate the game, it's definitely not worth the money in my opinion, only maybe on sale.

Reasons to buy this game:
-Playing songs that aren't 4k
-Cool presentation

Reasons to not buy this game:
-There are many other rhythm games for cheaper on steam that offer way more in my opinion. While I'm happy-ish for what I paid for (I bought this game at launch), I keep coming back to osu mania for my 4k fix.
-It's extremely large for what it is. Without the DLCs (though I think they still might be downloaded locally?) The game is 55 GB as of this review. That is larger than pretty much every game in my steam library except like 3. I get that every song has a movie with it, but maybe we could have the option to only download the movies when you play the song (maybe delete the cache after a while?), and have an option to download all the movies for a smoother experience (or even choose to not have movies at all?) For a game I only occasionally boot up to play a few maps, it takes up more space than my entire osu installation with THOUSANDS of songs in it.
-Annoying DRM. It makes it take longer to start up, and it doesn't let you play offline. What if I had a steam deck and I was out and about? Guess I'll cry about it.
-Having to unlock songs. Why on EARTH is the "unlock song pack" $10 ($3 on sale)? Why should we have to unlock songs at all? Rhythm games are a pick up and play genre. We just want to pick a song that we like and get going, but a large amount are locked off and require you to play. It's something that annoys me to no end in Deemo and Cytus. I bought the game, let me play the songs. Locking gear and noteskins is COMPLETELY fine, because it's cosmetic. Locking songs is just terrible. It feels like a cash grab decision considering the fact that you can pay to unlock it.
-Not all songs have charts for all difficulty and key combos. Look, I know it's a lot of work, but it SUCKS when there's a song that I play in 6k and go "ooh I like that" and switch to 4k to see if I can play a harder version of the song (because I am significantly better at 4k) but it just doesn't have a harder chart. It's especially depressing when it only has the first 2 difficulties, because they're way too easy. I get it, it's just such a buzzkill though.
-It's nothing new gameplay wise. Yeah, it's just like basically every other key-based rhythm game. It doesn't offer any unique new gameplay styles like you might find from ADOFAI or Spin Rhythm.

Preference things:
-This game features keysounding, meaning when you press a button it will instantly play, meaning that it will sound like YOU playing it. While some enjoy it, I personally don't. Even while getting MAX hits, it feels off and it's extremely distracting. There is a "sound buffer" to assist in it, but jankiness will continue to pour out, even if the game sees you as playing "perfectly". I would love if there was an option to disable it outright.
-I didn't like many of the default songs. There are a sizable, maybe 20ish songs that I like included with the base game, but for a rhythm game (especially since I paid almost full price at launch) that's not very many. This is purely up to taste, but I much prefer the soundtrack of other rhythm games on steam overall than this game.
-There's a lot of DLC. The base game is fine, but man it costs so much money to get all the DLCs even on sale. Other games are far more generous with DLC, though I do understand why they do it like this, just buy the packs that interest you. I don't want to have to research which packs have songs I like, I just want something like what muse dash did and give everyone some familiar rhythm game songs while mixing in originals to learn about all wrapped up in one DLC.
-Side tracks. They are an extra 2 buttons added to any mode. So it's not really TRUE 4k, it's 4k + sometimes you have to press Left and Right Shift or 6k + sometimes you have to press Shift. It can be annoying, I wish I could have the option to turn them off, since I prefer to play pure 6k.

I don't think this game is bad or buggy (though it doesn't seem well optimized for lower spec machines), just maybe not worth most people's dollars. If you just play 4k, don't bother in my opinion. The charts can get tricky at the absolute top, but it's like easier than ~3* osu mania maps. I really enjoy playing 6k, and that is EXTREMELY rare to find in osu, so I'm not too mad about my purchase, though I wish I could go back in time and stop myself from doing it.

My favorite rhythm game and I am happy it continues to receive support.

Lots of options for how to play that make the game either more approachable or challenging depending on what mode or speed the player chooses. Can easily be played with a controller or keyboard as well. The base game has a decent selection of songs.

Some downsides, which are admittedly going to be valid deal breakers to a lot of folks:
[*]The anti-cheat which requires an always online connection.
[*]The cost and amount of DLC, even if they go on sale frequently.
[*]There is a season pass system that adds a lot of limited time to earn cosmetic flair.

Despite these downsides, I still enjoy plucking away at a few songs here and there and would recommend this game to both longtime and new rhythm fans.

DJMAX is a fantastic rythm game and with Respect V it's finally on Steam. 
This reminds me of the good old days of DJMAX Portable 2 and DJMAX Trilogy (my 2 most played DJMAX games).
I love that the keynote sounds are actually part of the played song (sounds and sometimes even vocals).

The game has a huge and great selection of all kind of songs (K-Pop, Rock, Trance, metal, etc.). The base game alone includes over 160 tracks each with their own music videos and patterns in 4/5/6 or 8 button mode (there is no 7 button mode). 
If you use a keyboard you will need 2 extra buttons for the side notes which occasionally appears in certain charts. 
On a controller the sidenotes are are mapped on the analog sticks or turntables by default.

Not all songs are available from the start. You get experience points after finishing a song and unlock more tracks as you level up.
Of course, you can unlock new gear and notes, but this time around they are cometics only. You are also able to unlock avatars, plates and titles for your DJMAX profile. 
Unlocked music videos and artwork can be viewed under Collection.

The Collection mode is additionally keeping track of your stats and ingame achievements as well as displaying how far or close you are to reaching said acievements and it's associated unlockables. 

The other Modes are:

[b]AIR[/b]
Playing a random song or use auto play and just listen to them. 
While playing in AIR mode you can not get a game over regardless of how many notes you miss. You can also write messages (not real-time) for other players in AIR mode to read.

[b]FreeStyle[/b]
Basically pick a song and play.

[b]Mission[/b]
Playing songs with certain clear conditions (e.g. cannot miss more than 3 notes, reach certain combo count or score, fading notes, etc.). 

[b]Online[/b]
This consists of two modes: Ladder and Open matches.

The [b]Ladder[/b] mode are 2-player games to climb ranks. Both players are playing the same button mode with a pick-and ban phase.

In [b]Open[/b] mode you play with up to 6 other players. The host picks the song, but you are not bound to play the same button mode or difficulty chart as the other players. This is a very enjoyable online mode.

[b]Ranking[/b]
This is for viewing the leaderboards.

There is no Arcade mode. It's definitely not a deal breaker and some won't even miss it, but would have been nice if it was included. 
Unfortunately, this game is an always-online game due to it's anti-cheat program. So those with an unstable connection might not be able to enjoy this game.

Still, I can highly recommend this game for veterans and newcomers alike.

I've been a fan of DDR and ITG for a while now, but haven't until recently tried my hand at, uh, rhythm games with the hands. Konami's Sound Voltex, Beatmania, and others have caught my eye, but the locations to play at the arcades are few, and the ones that do exist seem to have internet issues -all the time-, preventing people from saving their scores with the E-Amuse Pass. 

With DJMax, yes the game is expensive and yes it's on Steam and yes you have to be online to play it, but if you're installing it on a computer chances are that more times than not you're connected anyway (at least more than the arcades I frequent, sheesh). That, to me, is a moot issue. As for the price? There's a few arcades within a 150km radius that charge a little over 20 euros/dollars (they're about the same at the time of me writing this) each time you go in. If you frequent said arcades several times, you've already exceeded what this game costs and then some. That's how I see it. 

What I like about the game is that you can play it however you want. Console controller, keyboard, one of those gamo2 controllers, etc will all work. The selection of songs isn't bad either; you'll find some hits and some misses in any pack. I will echo what others have said though and tell you that it is best to wait for a sale to buy the game and/or DLCs you want. It'll save you a pretty penny and get you a pretty awesome rhythm game experience at home.

If I were to spend enough time beating all the free songs I would just have to pay for more which is lame. Why pay 40 bucks for a game just to dump another $200+ into getting all the songs when I could just get on Osu! (which is 100% free btw) and play my library with over 2000 songs on it. Didn't play enough to form a completely unbiased opinion on the game its just not my cup of tea.

One of the most approachable and fun music games on steam.
If you're a beginner looking to learn and have fun, this is a perfect game. The timing window for "max" is easy in this game compared to similar games.

Not only is this a good game to start on, but the difficulty goes far beyond what most players will ever be able to achieve. You won't run out of room to grow with this game, unless you become a music game god lol. If that's the case, you will still probably come back to challenge the hardest patterns in this game, as there are some very very very difficult ones. (nightmare, 4b sc for example)

Imo the best thing about this game is the availability of 4, 5, 6 and even 8 button/key modes for all songs.
If you get bored, you can always try a different button/key mode.

The only downside is that ranked play in this game has a really steep climb as you get higher. Due to the easy timing window, other players will 100% perfect play every song. The last song of the match has a stricter timing to prevent ties.
Also, you will cry when learning tighter timing windows in other games like EZ2ON REBOOT.

However, in 100 hours of gameplay, I've only touched ranked a few times. It's fun, but not the main draw to the game. The issues with it aren't really a big deal. And if you're gonna play ranked seriously, then you're probably good enough to perfect play most songs anyway :)

I play rythumn games casually so my hours are low but ive reached 20 levels in game and played alot of songs [it feels alot anyway] 

my main gripe about this game is alot of the songs feel amaturish, which is ok they deserve attension too its just there is alot of songs that feel that way, at least in the base game [ i havn't baught any dlc packs for this as i judge the base game first and determine by the base game if the dlc is worth it], looking past that alot of the songs feels bad, the songs that are good can sometimes be ruined by the keypresses an example would be that i played a song that was soft and more ballard like but when i pressed the keys it sounded metallic as if banging on a metal pot or something, that completely threw me off as they were in stark contrast and thus ruined the experience for me. 

For people new to rythmn games or only played them with the phone or the VR this will be a learning curve so the lowest amount of buttons is 4 [phones it tends to be 3 depending on the game of course] most of the songs seem to be dance-like or electronic sounding like someone just slammed there face into a keyboard whilst using a music program lol. some songs are great though and a friend of mine who has been playing this for a long while insists the dlc packs are worth it as they are better than the base game music, my argument is ''why should i buy dlc music just to listen to some good songs to play too? surely there should be good quality ones in the base game too?'' but i am very critical so lol 

Pros: Fun, Has multiple button options [4,5,6,8], it has an AIR mode that is like playing the game during a live stream [?]. there is alot of songs even in the base game. very smooth gameplay i experience no lag

Cons: the music feels amature and hastily thrown together, most of the music is dance or electronic and trance, not many slow soothing songs to play casually to, learning curve [if you play osu! then this would be more your thing], the key presses sometimes make a sound that is in contrast to the song being played which is off-putting and ruins the experience of the song.

Sorry for the wall of text!

I was introduced to DJMAX what seems to be ages ago when a rhythm game player came to me and asked if I can try the game out. I was like 'sure, why not'. What I did not know was that he let me play the hardest song in the game and see how I'd do. I cleared the song to his astonishment. I asked what the game it was and that is how I discovered DJMAX. It became one of my most played games on PSP.

Wait, another vertical scrolling rhythm game?
DJMAX is a game that had a very big following and could have reached mainstream if it was released on more platforms earlier. That decision came rather late. Relatively recently DJMAX made it to PC, that is with DJMAX Respect V. DJMAX is a vertical scrolling rhythm game with several button modes. You can start with 4 button play, progress to 5 buttons, then 6 buttons and eventually end up playing 8 buttons. Apart pressing the regular buttons there might appear a slide note from time to time, there are two slide notes (mapped to Shift keys on PC) and they add little bit more complexity to the game. Since this is a game that was meant to be played with d-pad and buttons the song charts are made the way that it is possible to play them with these - players used to play rhythm games meant for keyboard play may wonder why there's just certain combinations used in the charts.

There are long notes in the game that you need to press as well, just hold them and release them on time. Each note be it a regular note or long note are being judged - you get judgment from 1% to 100% depending on how close to being on time you were. The timing windows are actually huge which makes it easier to hit a note (if you miss by a chance you can just press it again to still hit it).

The timing in the game is very lax (feels even more lax compared to the PSP games). It is the combo, as in many Korean games, that counts the most with you keeping max Fever going. There is a Fever bar that fills with each note confirmation, when it gets full you need to activate it to get a 2x multiplier. Then you continue to fill it again. When you fill it and activate it in time you get a higher multiplier for everything (3x). The maximum multiplier you can get is 5x which will stay for as long as you manage to fill the bar and activate Fever in time.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PLVkDC9uI70

Each song has a difficulty shown in stars. It ranges from the easiest 1 to the hardest 15 for the 'playstation control' charts. There is another scale marked SC which is meant for keyboard play and starts around 3 and goes to 15 as well and will introduce a playstation player to more patterns and chord combinations making it even way harder - a PC VSRG player will find these SC difficulties more familiar. Note that a SC 3 charts is more like playstation 8 in terms of difficulty.

There are several modes in which you can play, there is Air that lets you play a randomly chosen song or just watch and comment on it. There's Freestyle mode where you can pick any song you want and get the best score. Then there's Online play where you play against other players either using a ladder system or just playing for fun. Lastly there is Mission mode in which you complete a set of songs with certain modifiers or conditions.

So much music
DJMAX offers a wide range of music styles. Many of the songs may be new to non-rhythm game players but there is a lot to choose from and the music is good. For rhythm game enjoyers there are DLCs from previous versions of the game including Technika but also from other rhythm games like Chunithm, Deemo, Muse Dash, Groove Coaster etc. The base game gives you over 150 tracks (there are free tracks added from time to time). All these songs have music videos that you can unlock and watch in the game as well.

DJMAX has style
Korean games tend to look great and DJMAX is not an exception. It looks simply great. It has a great style, and not just one. You can unlock more skins and also customize the look of in-game when you are actually trying to read the charts and pressing buttons. Not many games can rival the look of this game.

In order to unlock customizations including songs you need to fulfill certain criteria. There is a lot of achievements to get in the game and are neatly presented to you. Some may seem impossible to get but when you get them you will feel rewarded. There is no other game that motivated me enough to actually hunt the achievements!

Not everything is great...
DJMAX is a great game that offers a lot to the player but unfortunately there are few things to note. First the game uses anti-cheat Xigncode which requires an internet connection. There is no way to play the game offline or with a bad internet connection. Second thing to note is that the game is very expensive. To this date the total of the game including DLCs would total for me to 388EUR. It is for a lot of content though but there is even more content that is behind a paywall. Each season you can get 'free' stuff, even a skin if you finish all steps. That you can only get if you get a battle pass though. You can even pay for it to automatically unlock at the end of the season. Means throwing a lot of money at Neowiz.

The last thing I'm not fond of is the fact that Steam achievements expect you to have those expensive DLCs. Perfecting this game means a lot of money spent.

Verdict
You can clearly see that DJMAX was created with love. It has everything players could possibly hope for in a rhythm game. It is beautiful to look at, offers 150+ songs of various genres, has different button modes and game modes and gets many DLCs with more great music. So far it may be the only game coming from a different platform that runs without any issue on PC. Unfortunately the game needs constant internet connection and is rather expensive.

I can highly recommend this game to anyone who likes to press buttons at high speed.

Before i start i just want to point out, I saw a LOT of negative reviews stating something about delays and other issues but i never encountered any. That being said, some of you may experience issues with low end machines if any at all.

[h1] PROS [/h1]
[list]
[*]A piano type rhythm game, responsive and simple. 
[*]As with all rhythm games you want a good set-list, and this has it. songs ranging from multiple genres, [u] there's a song for everyone! [/u]
[*]VERY challenging 
[*]Consistently updated
[/list]

[h1] CONS [/h1]
[list]
[*]Like i said at the start. some people might find issues with the game that weren't apparent to me. 
[*]The way the game is played occasionally makes my fingers/wrist/arm ache. be cautious if you also experience stuff like this.
[*]VERY challenging
[*]Mission Mode

[/list]

[h1] Final Thoughts [/h1]
Overall amazing rhythm game with a great soundtrack and massive skill ceiling. Not a game where you will become amazing within a week and that's whats fun about it. SC is a difficulty/pattern that plays so much different to the other difficulties. The game is constantly being updated with content and a Dev update on their YouTube, the game has heart into it, and it shows with it's Music, artwork, playerbase etc.

In my opinion though, mission mode is not very fun. It's INCREDIBLY challenging, but not just because hard song with difficulty, they had modifiers or other effects that make the song play/look/feel different, some of the missions are minor, where as some are incredibly ridiculous with their difficulty, so it doesn't feel like a game mode where you can play to beat all the missions in order, it's more of a game mode where you play whenever you get better and see if you're good enough to beat the mission you got stuck at, only to get stuck on a different mission. Some people may enjoy this however, it does give you a place to test yourself or a goal to work towards, But for me it just feels unnecessary 

If you're a fan of rhythm games regardless of how they are played, you'll get a ton of fun out of this one!

[h1]9.5/10 [/h1]

...fast forward to 2022. I finally get my Steam Deck I reserved the year prior (highly recommend btw). Then by chance I find this game. Outside of those sheltered experiences with my pirated copy on my hacked PSP (which itself was a much-appreciated gift from a very sweet admirer, thank you again...), I knew nothing about this series. I bought it immediately. And some of the DLC too. And even before starting to play, I knew I would want to buy more of the DLC in the future.

Having finally been able to sit down with it, after only an hour I know I was right. This game is fucking awesome. (Crap, can I swear on here...?) üòÖ

The DRM literally kills this game. 

This company doesn't deserve your money or respect. If you can wait I would hold off and wait for other DRM free alternatives of this game to release. ;)

[h1]Feel the Rythm![/h1]

[b]Cythus/Deemo Update[/b]

The DJMax franchise finally coems back to PC with DJMax Respect V! The series being one of the most beloved rythm games for the PSP (Portable series) and PC (Trilogy) and with numerous arcade titles such the Technicka series. While the series was left rotting due to the change in times and the decline for rythm games on the mainstream area, it still keeps an ample presence in the rythm game niche genre.

[h1]Real Review[/h1]

Okay enough of sugar coating.
The game is great, has lots quite a bit of original music and their videos as well as various licensed artists. While the PC version (this one) is lacking in content compared to the PS4. It complements this with various additions for online interactions.

[h1]Everyone is Gonna Die:Updated[/h1]
Negatives...
The game on release suffered many hitches and slowdowns due to the Anti-Cheat implemented (XIGNCODE3) but most of this issues have been resolved with the latest updates. Becoming more enjoyable and with slowdowns.

Only Negative I have is the cost, but if you value Rhythm games, and you have played on Arcades, then the cost per Song is way better.

[h1]Recommendations[/h1]
Play the game with a computer made in the last 5 years with a dedicated GPU. A capable CPU is you want to stream, and with a SSD or fast HDD. And if you want to go for SC beatmaps, try to use a keyboard as close to N-key rollup. Otherwise you might not be able to perform as great as you would.

[h1]About DLCs and Cost[/h1]
Starting this we will go on the Cost and DLC quality.

[h2]First of all, Cost:[/h2]

While the game is quite expensive in comparison to "free games" like osu!mania and, etc, etc. One of my greatest issues with those is that the beatmap chart quality was always awful, while not true for every signle song, it was normal to find it on a Button Number one didn't like or wasn't used to. So even finding a good chart was rare, and when playing online, it was always the same old songs and charts.

As for DJMax Respect V? All those issues are gone, all songs are excellently mapped, you can choose what Button Number you want to play on, the speed for the note drop, and much more, all even when playing Online with friends or randoms. With enough song variety and style variety for it to not get old.

[h2]DLCs[/h2] [i](Currently with, Extended V, Emotional Sense, Trilogy, Clazziquai Edition, Black Square, Deemo and Cythus)[/i]

The game has been out for almost 6 months now, and we have had 4 mayor DLCs (Ext-V, Tri, CE and BS), 2 minor DLCs (ES and GC), and various other cosmetic DLC up for grabs (they are totally optional, but good if you want to support the game or Visual Effect artist, [i]*cough* RDR *cough*[/i]) and with more DLC to come... Those already available on PS4, but possibly another Ext-V? And while not yet ever announced, there is still Portable 3, the phantom DLC which is aid to come in the future.

With the newer additions of Deemo and Cythus song packs, the number of machinegun songs has increased, but still the mappign is wonderful. Too bad there is no full soundkey mapping, but still not bad.

With 104 songs available as DLC as of right now, this pushes the game to have over 250+ unique songs, and hundreds of beatmaps available. Its not a terrible purchase (hurts on the wallet, but I don't have a single arcade on my city, so might as well just buy the DLCs). 

As for DLC Rankings...
- Extended-V
- Cythus Collab Song Pack (Song variety and great songs added)
- Deemo Collab Song Pack (Calm songs with tons of maps)
- Black Square (Difficult songs and some nice ones)
- Trilogy (Old classics that are just great)
- Clazziquai Edition (Some more licensed music but good in general)
- Groove Coaster Collab Song Pack (Do note, its all high BPM songs)
- Emotional Sense (If you just want to have the missing Trilogy songs for your game)

[h1]Anti-Cheat: XignCode3 Addendum[/h1]

What is XignCode3? A DRM and AntiCheat used in DJMax Respect V
Official info at: https://web.archive.org/web/20200818134331/https://www.wellbia.com/home/en/pages/xigncode3/ (original link was killed, but Archive.org has good backup)

[h2]My Thoughts on Anti-Cheat[/h2]

While many, MANY, other players are pushing for XignCode3 to be removed due to it being a "malware", "root kit", "I just don't want it". And while I do understand some of those concerns, it varies from game to game on what features of the Anti-Cheat are used by the game developer. In the case for DJMax Respect V, this only applies to this:

- No Botting for perfect games (Anti Macro)
- No Impossible Scores (Anti Cheat, No Cheat Engine nor Debbuging)
- No Memory Scanners nor Edittors (HeartBeat)
- No fake game owners nor fake DLC purchases. (Online DRM, verified on external server)

I have tried to verify in multiple ways, but on my observations, it DOES NOT HAVE ANYHING SIMILAR TO A ROOTKIT. While it scans memory on startup, the game is very smooth and responsive, without any hitches. And CPU/HDD activity matches for a video/audio decoding routine.

So if you are having issues while gamming, if your PC suffers while playing 1080p video plus fast firing multiple inputs at the same time, this game is not for you.

An outstanding reboot of DJMAX series. Easily accessible, and yet provides decent challenges that keep you engaged for a long time. Most of tracks are curated good enough as well, giving you tons of joy while playing(or you could say 'listening') the game.

DLC pricing policy, however, may be burdening, as the game currently has numerous separate packs for additional contents. They mostly have great musics and keynote compositions for what it's worth, though(grab them on sale if you can). Fortunately you can try those songs in open match if you have a clear pass(which grants you an access to all tracks that the host have).

Occasional stuttering and note-skipping are also part of the downside. It can get frustrating to go through the entire track, only to see your game stutter and miss your notes. The issue's not that frequent, but it can be a glaring trouble to say the least.

That being said, it's still the best rhythm game I can burn my free time on over and over in my book. Nothing beats the satisfaction coming from breaking your own records every time you improve. Double the fun if you have friends to play with.

Highly recommended.

I regret buying this game on Steam platform. 

Before I decided to get this one, I checked if my gaming laptop can run the application properly and it turned out that the requirement had been met. Certainly, I successfully installed and began the game. However, I found that when it comes to charts that I need to hit multiple keys simultaneously, the app doesn't accept the key inputs properly though I use a 26keys-rollover-model keyboard. This phenomenon irritates me especially when playing difficult charts, which often have crazy chord patterns. 

I tried to solve this problem by changing in-app settings or installing the latest GPU driver, etc. but ending up with wasting time. To make the matter worse, the Steam platform did not accept my refund request because the total playing hour exceeds two-hour limit. I sent the request for many times and insisted that the reason I played the game for over two hours should be taken into account, but the only result I got was rejections with auto-generated messages. 

Actually this was the first time I bought a game app on Steam platform, which further disappointed me. Perhaps this was the last time for me to spend money on Steam.

Personal Rating: 6.5/10
Gameplay: The actual gameplay is pretty simple and nothing that makes it stand out from any other rhythm games. This doesn't make it bad as sometimes simplistic approaches are also the best. You do have the additional options of changing the gear & notes you use for cosmetic purposes. The game may not be for everyone as there is no alternative to change whether the notes will be upscroll or downscroll: as this is set to downscroll mind you. First issue I had is immense hand cramps due to the default keybinds being set to A,S and ; @. Left and Right Shift for optional sliders. I was able to easily adjust to the controls although it didn't have any comfort level to it whatsoever. Also, in harder difficulties this keybind WILL fail you as you're unable to simutaneously press 3 or 4 notes altogether. Meaning you're forced to change the keybinds to anything that will prevent that, my keybind for this for 4B (4 Buttons) is S, D & 4 5 on the numbers keypad to your right. It's a lot more flexible and comfortable to grind through songs. For any other buttons like 5B, 6B and 8B I haven't tested to try how good or trustworthy they are.

Music: Honestly the music is a hit or miss. There are varied genres of music like RNB to rap, rock to dubstep/trap, mainstream pop and video game music to anime songs. A lot to work with although a fair majority of them I am particularly not fond of out the 120 songs the base game offers you. I can't speak for everyone as music preference is entirely subjective, nonetheless I still find my way to play every songs I can for the sake of wanting to. Mainly for the sake of grinding or practicing.

Game Modes: OH BOY- where do I even start with this? There's a few select game modes that gives the player a lot to work with instead of solely focusing on "Free Style" which is the main game mode most players lean towards to: playing whatever songs you can unlock. There are 3 game modes, Air Mode, Online (Ladder Match and Open Match) then Mission Mode. I will be speaking of their purpose and how I felt when using these game modes.

- Air Mode is just a way to chill out and play through songs the game has available with the community. Even if you don't have DLC it's there to appear and give you the chance to play them. There's a chat box and you can send messages to the lot of people if you don't wish to perform, and in all brutal honesty. I still cannot see the purpose of this mode at all, there is no way to actually converse. It's mainly just listening to music and everyone saying "GGs" whilst spamming hearts. I don't know how much closer you can get to that. I never used it much because it felt the same as Free Style, just an added audience who act like bots. (Sorry)

- Online (Ladder Match) is basically you ranking up to the leader boards to test your ability as a rhythm gamer. Which is far from beginner friendly nevermind the fact that it is far from being fair. I without a doubt think this is only for players that have played this game for years or so to gain consistent accuracy regardless of any song and their difficulty. As accuracy is what actually determines whether you win a match or not. There are a lot of tiers too I'm not going to get into because I'm frankly not skilled enough in the degree that the more knowledgable side of the fanbase does. I'm just often met with players whom have clearly spent more hours and/or I fail miserably due to never have seeing a song before; which ends up all being DLC songs  I will DEFINITELY not fucking buy. HOLY SHIT. CHECK IN THEIR STORE, as of TODAY in stores the bundle for the "COMPLETE EDITION - DJMAX RESPECT V" it is 344,13 euros it has a 20% price currently which does not excuse anything. Maybe the hardcore fans say otherwise and it all also depends on regional prices and most of the people who own the ridiculous shit are likely more on the fortunate end of the spectrum. An added bonus is the company has claimed they're doing nothing to change of the pricing. :Toma: even the base game is 50,00 euros which I wouldn't expect of a rhythm game at this quality and what it offers. Could be due to the licensing of the songs but overall, it is such a trek. I may be going off topic but it does matter in terms of Ladder Match. I'm not spending an absurd amount of money only to PROBABLY not get a guaranteed chance of winning as it all depends on my actual skill set at hand. Nevermind the fact alone of going against high tier players who can get a 99% or 100% and still be a low tier like me. I am willing to spend hours on a game to get better at my own pace but the ranking system doesn't give you the room to grow and reach your potential. This will likely drive a lot of new players away or anyone getting into the groove of rhythm games which is unfortunate. I'm not determining that everyone will think this way but I'm merely thinking of the perspective of beginner or intermediate players who wish to play rhythm games casually or challenge themselves. ANYWAYS, don't get political over the prices and how people should spend their money. Regardless if you bought it or not, I can't deny that to me this is a LOT and many rhythm games I know of don't have this insane pricing. I bought this on a sale, if it weren't for that I'd not spend my money on this at all.

- Online (Open Match) is.. yeah not much to say. You get to make your own lobby or join a lobby of people but most of the time they're locked by a password and usually filled with Korean players. You'll need like a lot of friends you know of in the game if you really wish to put this mode to use. I don't have anything against global players, it's more like I'm just put at a disadvantage I can't even play with anyone regardless of where they're from. So yeah that's it in a nutshell.

- Mission Mode is what it says, Just missions you have to do that you can unlock more of throughout the game that is likely a good practice for newer players in general + it pushes themselves to improve. For the likes of me, I got bored of it easily as I already could FC songs on Hard or Maximum in a good few hours into the game, thus forcing myself to play songs on Normal with songs I don't like. It destroys the purpose I felt like it was trying to do, It didn't feel rewarding either when I did do them. There is some missions that require you to play in 5B and 6B, maybe 8B even? But I can't confirm that. I thought after seeing that, it may give me something to work towards to and the answer is no. It didn't. I tried it and couldn't find a way to somehow enjoy playing as a newbie to the added buttons. I think on PC it's a lot harder, BUT console is different. Since I have actually played this on a demo many years back on PS4. I can say that 5B and 6B is far much easier to use and play with. I have yet to try this again since I usually just stick to finishing everything with 4B on keyboard before ruining my muscle memory with using a controller. Anyways Mission Mode, it's not the worst but whatever it is trying to aim for. It's doing a bad job.

This concludes my very opinionated review of the game no one asked for, but I am at my wits end of this game and bored to death. :) I have a love and hate relationship with this game, I still am grateful I got to experience this anyways.

The rhythm game to get if you like these types of games. Fun game with great music and a variety of difficulties to enjoy or challenge yourself with. Just be mindful that with all the DLC, this game is expensive so wait for sales if you can.

TL;DR - Get it, especially if it's on sale. If it's not on deep discount, try other free alternatives like Quaver / Etterna / osu!mania first and see if you want a more "premium" experience visually speaking before purchasing.

Base game has a good amount of maps for the price (Around 150 or so) - especially if you purchase this while it's on a deep discount.

Judgements are very lenient compared to similar games which is good for the dopamine but if you're looking for a very pure and accuracy-driven approach you may want to look at things like Quaver or Etterna. 

The maps have very good support for 4/6/8k modes whereas some other offerings tend to be quite lean on the 6/8 modes. Music variety is -fairly good- but that is very subjective. The actual quality and visuals of the tracks is excellent regardless of personal taste.

DLC is a mixed bag and rather expensive when not on sale, but during sales they tend to go ~70% off which makes the purchase cost for a dozen songs much more palatable. Again please remember you can get thousands of maps for free on Etterna or Quaver.

---

Probably the weakest part is that the auto-offset functions don't work as cleanly and can't be set on a per-song basis like in Quaver. Strangely, because the game is so lenient with judgements (which can't be changed even in freeplay), the somewhat inadequate offset tool may not matter that much.

---

Greatest strength is the overall map quality and patterns used, as well as visual representation. The upper end of difficulty isn't as ludicrous as in other free alternatives because this is primarily a port of a PS4 game and many tracks use patterns that are designed to be able to be completed on a controller. For example, maps won't use patterns that would require you to (on a controller) press left and right on a dpad simultaneously. 

V introduced an 'SC' difficulty which is designed for keyboards, although this is not available for every song - it takes the place of the "hardest" difficulty for the songs that support it.

---

All in all, very good value if bought during a sale, and a premium feel presentation-wise.

THIS IS NOT FOR RHYTHM GAME NEWBIES. IF YOU ARE NEW TO THE GENRE, PLEASE PLAY ABSOLUTELY ANYTHING ELSE BEFORE ATTEMPTING TO PLAY THIS.

Seriously, you'll be stuck on 3-4 star 4B tracks forever and feel like absolute trash the whole time.

The Game Over screen is also extremely fast and sudden like your typical arcade rhythm games. No forgiveness, when you're out, you're out. If you're new and keep failing, it's going to continuously make you frustrated.

-----------------------------

Okay! With that out of the way, this game is fantastic. I ended up using my Korg Nanopad2 with it, and the beatpad pressing action is extremely satisfying. Check out midi-to-keypress on Github if you want to sync up a midi instrument for free. To anyone saying "ohhh if you can't do it on a controller/keyboard, it won't make a difference with a special button pad," you're wrong. Like really wrong. I was ready to refund this game before I hooked up my beatpad, and then once I started using it, the game made a ton more sense. 

If you're a fan of Bemani/IIDX games, this is a must-own. The songs are really good. Lots of interesting genres and a ton of good WTF tracks too. There are options for audio/input delay, as well as a color blind mode. You can also customize your note tracker (the scrolly boi). Very into this game. It feels like a slice of the arcade at home.

forced keysound. if you rely on listening to the song to figure out when to hit the note(like I do), this is NOT the game for you! otherwise seems like a very polished game, it's just that I'm used to listening to the rythym of the song to figure out when to hit notes, and I can't do that at all if I even get 90% accurate on the note, the song gets out of time and I can no longer rely on my ears to hear when i need to hit the other notes. I'm sure this game appeals to a number of people, just not me.

This game is not for people with semi-godly rhythm game skills looking for a even more challenging experience.

I bought this game on 6/25/2022 in the morning after  looking through steam summer sales, I have a background playing a few rhythm games, such as Osu!mania, guitar hero, rock band, DJ hero, funkin friday, etc...
looking for a challenging game to simply get a challenging experience from a new rhythm game. The few things that bugged me were the hand-full of maps/songs that are close to max difficulty, there were not many songs that were super hard, maybe its because I didn't purchase the DLC's. 

But the few songs that I played were phenomenal, the mapping was great, the background video was cinematically cool, with collaboration songs with League of legends, Guilty gear, and etc. 

When I scrolled through and looked at all the base game songs, there are very good songs in the list. 

I recommend trying this game if you are new or a lower skilled player, all the songs should feel new to you, repeatability is usually there in these types of games, unless you find them easy, and if you manage to complete this game, you can try the other Paid DLCs, try other rhythm games, or take it to the ranked mode.

June 24th, 2022 Update:

I moved my May 22nd review from 2020 to the comments to make room here. I wasn't planning to change this originally, but past few months have change my stance on recommending this game to other players.

With the latest update introducing fmod, the sync is virtually unnoticeable as long as you have capable hardware. Mix that in with keyboard input latency patch from few months ago, I can finally recommend this game to others as a good rhythm game.

But what made me change my stance on this is how we got to this point, not what we got. To keep it short, there was a burst of anger within official discord few weeks ago when the limited edition DJMAX keyboard sales went horribly wrong on the Korean side. And, yet again, they were mostly quiet about the issues and banned massive amount of people from their server.

From this, the users finally erupted: They wanted more transparency from the devs, as well as better management within discord server.

Few weeks after, I'm always seeing the questions being answers, and bugs always being looked into (even if it might be hard to fix, or won't be fixed due to limitations). The mods are always engaging in some form with the players. They addressed some main concerns that users had for DJMAX. This is something I didn't see often back in 2020 where the mods were very silent and not communicative unless there was a game breaking bug that they knew for sure they can fix.

The only downside to the positive changes at the moment is that most of the talks are happening on the Korean side of discord (as the only active community-side moderators are Korean). However, I can say with confidence that the communication issues from 2020 seem to be gone now.

I don't know what the future holds, but so far the devs have been more open towards interacting with players which is nice change I must say. I ended my original review 2 years ago with "It's a game with amazing content, somewhat poor execution, and close to 0 customer service." I can say for sure now that DJMAX is a game with amazing content, decent execution that's getting patched every few months (for the better), and devs who are willing to communicate with players to make it an even better experience.

It's been 2 long years. But now I can say this is something I can recommend.

Original Review:

TL;DR: I'll most likely keep on playing the game, but can't recommend it to other people. (May edit posted below)

There's lot I want to talk about the current state of the game, but I'll only pick out few of the current PC ones.

Pros:
- Open Matching is geared more towards the casual play of the game, so that people can just enjoy playing regardless of their skill level
- Ladder Matching is probably one of the better, if not best, executed ranked mode for any rhythm game (that involves PvP)
- Quality of the songs/videos is top notch, especially with the new addition of V Extension pack

Cons (only going to pick out a few that I think is top priority atm, and not the personal 'I would like to haves'):
- For a rhythm game, the sync is off. There are many theories to why this is happening and speculations on how to fix this, but the bottom line is that sync issue exists. Option to 'change the sync' actually just changes when the note drops, and may cause de-sync between the background track and the keysounded note.
- Games fun to play when it works. Constant steam issues preventing players from booting the game, players dropping from ladder/online matches due to server issues, frame drops at times and even freezing.
- Due to family sharing, players can share the base game to anyone deemed their 'family'. This allowed some ladder mode users to create additional accounts and smurf on ladder (player-base is already thin, and this is just adding oil to the fire for some players).

I can overlook some of the things stated above; but the lack of responses from the team who created this game is where I have to draw the line. Some of the cons are things that have been spoken by players for some time now but the developers aren't communicating to the players on what they are working on (minus 'we're looking into sync issues' maybe once or twice on English boards) nor responding to the questions that players have. This is now basically a pattern where the devs are silent on user's inputs, and stays silent until someone trashes the boards or the discord so they have to step in and clean it up (and sometimes, they only clean up the mess rather than cleaning up + providing feedback). This has been an ongoing thing since the Early Access days (funny how they called it Early Access when they weren't communicating to the players)

It's getting to a point where even the top Korean players are discussing boycotting the game because any feedback that people provide just gets sucked into black hole. I personally still like playing the game but already seeing effects of it happening: people are dodging ladder matches (really can't get any games except meeting same 3~4 people) and flooding into open matches instead, some players are already discussing jumping ship to another game, and I already have few friends who refunded the game.

If they just said something about sync in official post, or even attempt to acknowledge problem exists within the current game, then players can decide whether they want to ride it out or jump ship until things get better. But nope. We're just left in the dark.

As someone who put in way too many hours into this game, I can't recommend anyone else to pick up the game. If you're okay with a rhythm game that doesn't even feel like a decent pc rhythm game and with a dev team who stays silent on anything that happens, go ahead and buy it. Otherwise, stay away and find an indie rhythm game that at least cares about providing feedback to its players. It's a game with amazing content, somewhat poor execution, and close to 0 customer service.
GG

A Keysounded VSRG (Vertically Scrolling Rhythm Game) with good songs, severely hampered with bad optimizations and lack of some gameplay adjustment features.

[b] Positives [/b]
+ Good variety of content and songs spanning the series' lifetime and new original ones, fitting many different tastes. Hardcore fans and Casual fans will both get their fair share of great tunes.
+ Mission Mode had some gameplay features from different games that I found interesting and creative (converting the Technika gameplay to Respect V gameplay? wow)
+ Air Mode lets you try out songs you don't buy/have yet
+ The gears are a definition of eye candy (with good animations on Fever trigger) and the themes are quite visually pleasing.
+ Good for aspiring casuals to train on patterns since the judgement is very lenient. Can also get a little difficult with SC (Super Crazy) difficulty charts.

[b] Negatives [/b]
- BAD optimization and performance, especially compared to other keysounded VSRGs on Steam*
- Always online DRM, when the original PS4 game can be played offline.
- Some songs are not keysounded at all, (this is present on some collaboration packs) If I wanted to play a non keysounded game I might as well move to community made games.
- The content you got on base game is more weighted to old DJMAX contents, so prepare to buy the Deluxe Edition if you want newer stuff.
- There's a lack of certain latency related options to make your accuracy better like NVIDIA Reflex support
- You can't turn on hard and maximum judgement mode in Freestyle. (You can only get that on certain missions or in Multiplayer matches)
- Only the SC difficulty charts are made for keyboards. I wish there are low - medium difficulty charts made for keyboards.
- Many songs lack some difficulty options, creating a weird hole as you scroll down the song list.
- Battle passes in a paid game complete with the FOMO it brings if you're really lazy? Ugh. Even though it's cosmetic I just have to make this point a negative. Sorry folks.

A precaution: This game is non wallet friendly for completionists. Newer players to the genre might be surprised on how much you will have to buy to enjoy the full course, especially when they're starting out from the community made rhythm games. Welcome to the world of commercial and professionally made rhythm games!

* Everytime I play songs in this game, at some point the framerate will take a hiccup and then the song goes haywire with the song/keysound sync, making it unplayable. This is happened since the Extension II update. And this is the only rhythm game I played in my rig with a horrible performance.
the input system is amazing!! and the charting style focuses more on being fun rather than being hard. love it!!

This isn't really a bad game, heck it's actually pretty good and I had a lot of fun with it considering I played the portable games in the past. But I can't really recommend this to anyone or my friends and for these reasons.

[h1]No Internet? Too Bad[/h1]
-Not being able to play offline is a deal breaker for me. I mean I get it, it's to prevent cheating and protect leaderboards and whatnot, but inconvenience is a thing. There's nothing worse than finishing a song and then something happening internet wise and my score/results doesn't go through. I'd understand if it was some online multiplayer only game that required internet at all times to play, but it's DJMAX. The game that I played in the past when riding trains or taking it easy at home.

[h1]Our Difficulties, Our Rules[/h1]
-This is one of, if not, the only rhythm game I played where songs have their own specific difficulty settings to choose from. Maybe it was always like this since portable but I don't know why it's still like this. Most rhythm games I played keeps it simple. You pick a song, and you pick one of 3-5 difficulties. Some games only have 3 and some have 4 or more. But the most important part is that ALL or at least most of the songs have these difficulties available. DJMAX Respect is all over the place. Some songs will only have Normal and Hard, some having Normal Hard but then only letting you do Maximum if you change your mode to 6 buttons, and there's even a song that doesn't have maximum. It just goes from Normal, Hard, then straight to SC. I'm sure maybe they have their reasons for this (maybe because having the easier songs with harder difficulties would make it difficult to make notes that go with the song), but it's really inconsistent and bothers me when the songs I love is too easy and the other ones I like go from hard to SC (which I can handle some of them but it might be a different story for others).



[h1]SC Recommended lol...[/h1]
-Why do they say on the loading screens that they recommend SC difficulty if you're on keyboard? Yes, playing on keyboard isn't difficult, but not everyone puts an immense amount of time into rhythm game(s). Players have different reaction speeds/skill and while they can be improved with practice, you can't practice efficiently if you're a new player constantly trying to do the hardest difficulty and getting game over seconds into a song. It takes time to get good at games like this, and it's almost as if they think all of the players who got this game are already really experienced at rhythm games.

Like I said before, this game is good for what it is and I had a lot of fun. But I really can't recommend this to others. I could have mentioned the fact that half of the background videos of this game during play is incredibly disorienting and forced me to turn it off to actually play the music well, but there are other rhythm games that do the same (though for this game it's the worst I experienced so far, which sucks since a lot of the animations/videos are really good). 

[h1]TLDR[/h1]
You ordered the sundae, they made it really well and with their excellent service you feel like your money was well spent. But then you tried to eat the sundae, you realize that you're not exactly sure where to start from. There are sides that are rather rocky and sides with a lot of sprinkles on it. You find the spot and somehow finish the sundae. You walk out the store slowly, with a smile on your face, and a bad stomach ache to go with it.

As far as rhythm games go, this one is polished, the timing feels good, the music selection in the core game is sufficient, and the variety of free aesthetics is not bad. 

The DLC can be hit or miss, but you just need to check the reviews. 

Overall it's a very solid rhythm game to add to your library if you can shell out the cash for it.

edit - The game is great, but given their history of unplugging games that are online only (such as DJMAX Ray and Technika Q) when they shut servers down, I am compelled to no longer be purchasing more dlc as it comes out until they confirm some kind of offline patch for when they do decide to shut servers down.
