As a relative newcomer to traditional rhythm games, I enjoy DJMAX RESPECT V for its stylish, polished presentation. The user interface is very premium-feeling, the game comes with lots of songs and customization options, and all the notes feel very satisfying to hit. DJMAX RESPECT V, however, isn't the most accessible game for beginner players, lacking a true practice mode and having a high difficulty curve. Normally I'd excuse something like this, but considering the game costs $50 USD, (even more with the expensive DLC packs) you shouldn't buy it unless you are fully willing to commit the time and effort the game demands of you to get better. If you'd consider yourself a rhythm game fan, this game is a must-have due to how amazing it feels to play, but the game isn't for everyone.

9/10 - A challenging, polished rhythm game with a good amount of song variety

As someone who has epilepsy and already played other DJMAX games, Respect V doesn't "respect" the franchise...

As you can see with my playtime, I barely could play the game. Because there's no option to reduce the flashy effects on the screen. You can "reduce the brightness", but that only seem to dim the background, not the flashy effects on the screen (which makes things WORSE).

I could play the Clazziquai Edition or the Black Square Edition on PSP with no issues. The effects were there, but they weren't flashy compared to the Respect V.

Also, with the anti-cheat + needs to be connected to the server issue, it made me feel less inclined to keep playing the game. I feel really sorry because DJMAX was one of my favorite music games franchise and watching it go downhill like this...

Alright, first thing I want to get out of the way, this game is not "perfect". Reviews like that are just kids (or adults, I don't judge... yes I do) hopped up on the sight of kawaii anime girls

|=| What a lot of reviews complain about |=|
The anti-cheat. It truly doesn't effect anything. That's all I have to say about that. If it effects you somehow, sucks to suck.

The season passes and cosmetic garbo. What they don't mention is that the game never tries to shove it down your throat or force you buy anything. I already bought the DLC, and I don't feel any obligation to purchase the season pass... so I don't... pretty easy. Not even very tempting, its just... there.

The price. Ugh, get a job, look up the r/beermoney page on reddit, something, like my god, it doesn't cost that much. Yes, when its not on sale, the price is a bit unruly, but its on sale often, and is worth the money spent. 

A lot of reviews say the game is "too easy". I think this is because people spam keys, since it doesn't technically have a penalty at the lower difficulties, and then think "oH bOy ThIs GaMe Is So EaSy" I wouldn't just out right say its "easy". Every game similar to this genre scales in difficulty. This one, scales pretty far. If it's "too easy" then you must be getting Max Combo on 8 key SC difficulty right? Oh... No? Well... then it must not be very "easy" huh -.- And if you CAN do that, and are still saying its too easy, then try getting a life, maybe going outside, getting some fresh air, grab a coffee and meet a women, walk that poor neglected dog, find a job, work 120+ hour weeks, drive yourself into a self destructing depression and end up in the hospital, rethink life decisions, marry girl from coffee shop, find a new job with a reasonable work to pay ratio, get your own house and then try playing the game again. Shouldn't be too easy anymore.

|=| Now my issues, I guess? |=|
When the track speeds up during parts of certain songs it's not a very smooth transition. Keeps you on your toes though.

Some tracks don't always follow a sort of rhythm or beat. The majority of songs aren't like that but a few are so off beat that it's easier to complete muted.

The difficulty scale doesn't always make sense? Not that it has to be 100% accurate but for examples sake (purely just an example, I don't really care enough to write down what songs I found this to be the case with), say you can do various 10 star difficulty songs with ease, then a 6 star song shouldn't be difficult but in some cases, it is... if not harder.

There wasn't much of a tutorial, I mean, sure there was for the actual game-play, but then it just kinda throws you in and I had to figure out the menus and stuff myself. Not a big deal but when a person starts playing this game, wouldn't it be better to have the menu on freestyle or missions? Not everyone who bought this game has played and knows what's where and what to do and on that note, this game generally is not the most newbie friendly. Hints constantly saying "SC is the recommended difficulty for PC" is just... stupidly misleading? I can't even fathom completing an SC song yet, it's not cause I'm awful at the game, I just haven't been able to drown hours upon hours in older or related title before coming to this.

And finally, why I think overall it's worth the money.
I have dabbled in similar games (community driven ones), the game-play isn't something new or unheard of, but aesthetically the game is very beautiful. On top of that, not having to scour the internet, download music packs and songs that I probably won't like, and then wait for everything to sync, has already made this purchase worth it to me. You load it up for the first time, you get a large variety of genres and everything you want it there, no issues. Yes sounds like a lazy reason to buy this, but I'm not broke and what other reason is there to buy a rhythm game? If you aren't looking for aesthetic, ease of access, or cosmetics then shouldn't you just stick to the free stuff?

I hope this review can be of some help, if for whatever reason you feel it's necessary to comment about something you didn't like in my review then I suggest taking it to someone who actually cares because I sure as hell don't :)

[b]If you like Rhythm games I highly recommend you add DJMAX RESPECT V to your library[/b]

The general gameplay of the game is like this:

[a][s] 
- far left lane, left lane

[;][']
- right lane, far right lane

Hit the button when the "note" hits the line. 

--------------------------------------------

Its fun, there's over 150+ songs in the base game.

Currently the game goes on sale for 70% off, so [b]pick it up when its $15 and as long as you don't hate the music you will have a good time[/b].


*Side Note: If you like the game you can later buy the Deluxe Edition for a reduced cost, so don't worry about DLC

I've played the PS4 version of this game since 2018, and recently was able to purchase the Steam version (main game and ALL 18 song DLC packs) during a sale for about $120 USD, which is a steal compared to the full price of the game and DLCs, especially as there is currently close to 500 songs in the game, all with several patterns of 4-8 buttons, and some have a steam-exclusive SC mode that's geared towards keyboard players. The music is varied, and has a breadth of genres, meaning there is something for everyone. The Steam version also offers access to collaboration packs  (NEXON and Muse Dash) that are not available for the PS4. Furthermore, I feel I have more control over the speed of the songs on PC vs. PS4. Though, I also appreciate that I can use my console controller to play. So, the transition between the two versions was almost seamless. 

Yes, this game is difficult, but you will find yourself improving with time. And, with updates still coming, it's a game that's hopefully going to continue to offer more to consumers in the future. I would definitely recommend this to all rhythm-game lovers, just make sure to try to get it on sale so that your wallet doesn't take such a giant hit. :)

Don't listen o recent negative reviews, they're people who are either just bad at the game, don't understand how these games work with unlocking the vast library that's free, or they're vulgar and mad they were banned for saying ToS things in lobbies or in the official discord. You don't have to buy the unlock DLC just play the game and level and you'll keep getting new songs. 
Whether you're a casual or competitive rhythm game player this game is for everyone. As someone who is legally blind and color blind I play this game with no issues on 8 finger med-hard difficulty songs (6 finger very hard songs). I've not seeen a single valid negative review of the game.

Let me preface this by saying that I love DJMAX. I've been playing since Portable 1 back in the wee days of the PSP.
Hands down it is my favorite music game that doesn't require a dance pad. I even went as far as to buy a $300 arcade style controller when this game came out on PS4. Between the controls, the songs, and the feel, you'll be hard pressed to find better experience available in North America.

That said the DRM check for this game is ludicrously insulting. You absolutely **MUST** be online to launch the game and it uses a DRM software that has a rather dumb history with regards to privacy. This is just as bad as the DRM check was for DJMAX Trilogy, which required a special USB dongle... and that's my only legit complaint. 

I've logged hundreds of hours into this game and it's been sort of the cornerstone of my weekly streams. The colab packs they've put together have given me exciting new ways to play songs from other music games without worrying about "stepmania tier" charts. 

Get it. Get it now. Don't delay. As I write this the base game is on sale for $15. A steal at twice the price.

Update 4/27/2022:

I have been playing this game on and off since Early Access when it first launched roughly 2 years ago.  At first, I was showering this game with praise as it is the only DJ Max game left that most people could have access with on PC.  I can't say much about the PS4, PSP, and/or PS VIta since I no longer own DJ Max games on those.

But seriously now... Xsigncode 3?  I understand they want to squash the hackers on the leaderboards, but for the most of us that play casually, this is a bit too much.  I would like to give my subjective input about the this game.

PROS:
1. Large library of songs from different DJ Max games, saves the headache from keeping certain ports of the game just to play a few favorite songs.

2.  I can host and play with my friends that don't have the DLC and just the base game.

3.  DJ Max has been around for many years with a strong fan base.  Even as far back as EZ2ON days

CONS:
1.  Probably the biggest one is the XSignCode 3 anti cheat, the most invasive anticheat software you could have picked for a simple game like this.  I feel they only did this JUST for competitive ladder, to which most people just play open lobby (privately with friends) or Freestyle mode just to have fun.  This is purely overkill.

2.  Unless you are a DIE HARD DJ Max fan (I would consider myself one), the amount of money you spend to buy the song pack DLCs can get expensive.  Especially that if it only comes with 1 song that you like, you get a bunch of unpopular ones with the rest.  Its best to just play with friends that can host a lobby that has a larger song list to choose from.

3.  Understandably, this game REQUIRES online access to play.  There is no offline mode, therefore, when this game does go down and the devs no longer support the game.  All the money you spent on DLCs, THEMES, and SKINs.  Your sh*t out of luck.

Thoughts?:

I might sound hypocritical when I love the series, but hate what the devs are doing with the game.  I truly want to support this game.  But with the current direction and state of the game.  I feel it has become a double edged sword.

On one hand, It is the most up to date DJ Max game there is officially so fans can enjoy the series and songs they loved playing.  There is history to this series.

On the other hand, The amount of money you invest into this game potentially will never return if anything happens to the online service.  Will there be an end of life patch once this game's life is about to end?  I'm not sure, as DJ Max Trilogy suffered this same fate which most players with USB Dongles have no way to access their games to play again.

The Bottom line?  Ultimately, if you are a long time fan with the series and decide to overlook the bad sides of this game, I can highly recommend it to you.  Unfortunately, for a majority of others, it is a one sided love/hate relationship between you and the developers of this game.

I hope this helps some of you make the decision to play this.

At first, I gave this neowiz team a chance and wished they could do better than they did in PS4 version. but now, 2 years have passed and I'm so disappointed in gameplay quality that this team has delivered to me.

This game has potential to implement some new gameplay aspects, but they throw that potential away. You can see that "various" gameplay from mission mode, but it's limited and locked to very few songs in the game. Now the best thing they can do is milking our wallets with f**king useless and endless "Season Pass". The endless season pass provides just anime-style decorations and nothing has been added or changed in the major gameplay part since the first season (the game is at season 5 while writing this review. yes, that means they've released 5 rubbish passes in total). Matchmaking is meh, just win 2 out of 3 songs and get some rank points, get a decoration at the end of season, rinse and repeat on the next season. and whats AIR mode for? a new interactive screensaver?

Many QoL improved features still have not implemented into this game (such as mouse supporting, more random options in freestyle mode, in-game combo/judgement pos. customization, early-late indicator, etc.), and the game is using a horrible anticheat which consume your PC resource and effect your gameplay sometimes (like framerate dropping or stuttering). Moreover, internet connection is required even you want to play a song in single player mode.

This game has its strength in various song genres, but lacking of gameplay aspects makes me just run this game when a new songpack is released, try new songs for an hour, and leave it in the library for a couple of months until another songpack is coming.

Not recommended at all, even you're a die-hard fan of DJMax series.

This game's songs are really fun and I will say that this is an option for a 4 key (or more) rhythm game, however I want to point some things out if you are planning to play this game. 

Price: What may deter people from this game is its pricing including DLC. I got this game for 15 bucks during a sale, its normal price isn't the most friendly so I recommend getting it during a sale. Its DLCs aren't much different, if you're planning to get DLC, then make sure to choose ones you are actually gonna play (mainly ones with songs you like and will have fun with) 

Gameplay: It's very good as long as you have a computer that can run the game at an acceptable performance, you may have to lower some graphics settings if there are FPS drops, you don't need a very powerful computer for this game (just look at the minimum specs or be close to its recommended) The game can be played with keyboard or controller to fit the players style which is nice, unfortunately its hardest difficulty SC is mainly created for keyboards and kind of takes away the diversity aspect. As a keyboard main I have no problem for this, but if you are controller user it can really be a bummer.

I decided to make a review now because I noticed this game's getting a Mostly Negative reviews mark on its Steam page and I honestly want people play this game even if there are other free alternatives out there. Really the point of rhythm games, in my perspective, is to have fun and enjoy the experience, especially if you have a huge love for music.   Btw I give this game an 8/10, Unfriendly prices and some gameplay restrictions, but the overall product is something that I (and hopefully you) can greatly enjoy.

If you're new to rhythm games and have never heard any of the songs before, you're in for a rough time.

The combo counter and accuracy, as shown in the videos above, are right on top of the track you're trying to focus on.
Now, I looked for ways to remove them, without going into the Unity Environment and messing with assets - to no avail.
SO I tried to suck it up and play with the counters. (Spoiler: they still suck!)

With the first song, I instantly realized; [i]you[/i] are the one playing a crucial part of the song. If you time your notes poorly, which this game is not forgiving with, the song will sound bad. If you miss a note entirely, that note will not play in the song.
This is [i]terrible[/i] if you like the song or are trying to listen to it in order to hit notes. It ruins any enjoyment you might've had in the song, turning it into a battle against the game to make it sound right.

This is one of the few cool-looking rhythm games I've seen based on the content on the store page. It's exactly what I feared it was: a perfectionist note-popper with some special effects and a video in the background.

Honestly speaking, I'm expecting DJMAX's anti cheat & DRM could be using somethign else than XIGNCODE3 that supports offline play. I mean, you guys can make use of Steam's default DRM and Anti Cheat (VAC). The fact that it can't be played offline irritates me as the PS4 able to play offline. It's not like your whole life would having constant internet connection in the countries like South East Asian countries, as I myself always kept few offline stuffs for offline use and flight trips.

Aside for this, contents are great, music are great, nothing more can be said. DLCs are near complete with DJMAX Technika Tune, DJMAX Technika Q, DJMAX Ray, and Tapsonic titles missing but the majority of the DLCs have been ported pretty goodly. Only my concerns if this game stopped servicing, all the DLC can't be played offline and would be pretty useless unlike the PS4 counterparts.

Would I recommend the game? If you're a fan of DJMAX game and don't have console, I'd slightly recommend it. Honestly, I'd recommend the PlayStation version more, but if you want to take it, go on. It's what you like after all. Sadly steam don't give an option to give 6/10 rating.

While the music and customizable content seem pleasing and promising for this game, there's other features of DJMax that hold the game back. First, The mission mode has a steep learning curve that can frustrate newcomers; players who happen to pass are only rewarded icon and banners for these intense missions.
Second, the clear pass in a way defeats the purpose of paying for DJMax as well buying the DLCs. For instance, I had already bought a DLC that includes all of the songs, UI theme, BUT ONLY SOME OF gear of the respective theme. The rest of the content that corresponds with the DLCs can ONLY be accessed via clear pass. To add insult to injury, a premium subscription is required in order to get most of the customizable content (UI, gear, clear sound, fever sound, EVEN the judgement design) The free tier only provides mostly profile cosmetics ( icons and banners). And if paying for access to content ONLY to end up drilling through songs to EARN THE PREMIUM CONTENT YOU PAID FOR wasn't enough,  those content are COMPLETELY UNAVAILABLE once the SEASON for the clear pass is OVER. For rhythm game that has to be paid for it should not be treated as if its free to play, like Fortnite. If it wasn't for the fact that I was focused on the music and gameplay, I would have IMMEDIATELY requested a refund because of this sleazy pass feature.
One thing, however, that has made me most concerned with the legitimacy of this game is the UNNECESSARY measures Neowiz goes to prevent online cheating and piracy on DJMax. Of course, I was told that using cheats was against terms and would break the agreement and I have noticed a program called Xigncode3 would initiate when I start the game. Still, I was curious about what Xigncode3 does and decided to research this program, only to discover that this program SCANS MY DATA TO PREVENT CHEATING. The EULA never told me that an anti-cheat system would READ MY PERSONAL DATA to check for cheating/hacking programs. 
As for piracy, the game uses an online DRM system to circumvent infringement. The problem with this is it FORCES players to STAY ONLINE IN ORDER TO PLAY. This can be a major inconvenience for gamers who are used to single playing. 
To summarize, DJMax holds great potential, as a PC rhythm game, thanks to its songs, but its held heavily by a SLEAZY subscription pass, INVASIVE and UNECESSARY anti-cheat/piracy practices , as well as its unfair distribution of extra content. NEOWIZ, PLEASE REVISE THIS GAME FOR A BETTER GAMEPLAY EXPERIENCE.

If you're into Japanese pop music, Dance, Eurobeat, and soundTeMP compositions/20s MMO BGMs, DJMAX RESPECT V's aesthetic and songs are sure to please you. The base game features over 150 tracks (unlocked as you progress), and differently from other rhythm games, there truly is something for everybody.

Not only that, but the majority of songs are key sounded (you're playing one of the song's instruments rather than just reenacting), which is very satisfying. It serves as rewarding feedback on how well you're doing and makes it much more fun to try and improve.

I usually avoid rhythm games' DLCs because they end up piling up, and by the end, you need to spend a ridiculous amount of money to have all the content. However, DJMAX RESPECT V is so polished I couldn't help but buy the song packs I wanted.

Last but not least, the game is very player-friendly, allowing for a lot of gameplay customization (such as adjusting speed and picking the number of buttons you want to play with).

I decided it would be best to write a review after a while since the game has been out... almost two years.

I think DJMax Respect V has shown me that keyboard rhythm games are fun. I have had a history with vsrg games before such as stepmania, but for some reason those games are hard for me to enjoy. If you told me this was a series that has had a history since 20 years ago, I wouldn't have believed you.

What makes me enjoy the game?
Could it be the music? The charting style that the game has? The amount of the content it provides?
The music in this game is excellent and the charts this game provides even at the high levels are extremely fun. You get the base game and you have pretty much a lot of content, over 100 songs! But expansions and seasonal updates come out breathing new life into the game every so often adds even way more content to the game. The game (with expansions) currently sits with over 400+ songs; most of them being original to the DJMax series along with many songs that are from collaborations with other games.
You can open up mission mode to find the capabilities of what the engine can do in a pretty innovative fashion.

This game is still getting content in the future with some expansions already announced to be in the works. If you are looking to find a fun rhythm game, or trying to get into a rhythm game, I think DJMax Respect V is a pretty good choice.

However this game does have a few flaws, such as how timing feels in this game. We finally got a offset for timing!! However it just doesn't feel too right personally :(

Kinda late review since I bought this in 2020, but I really enjoyed playing DJMax Respect V since I used to play the Portable series before in my PSP and the Technika series in our local arcade. 

The good:
> Great variety of songs available in the base game
> You can also play random songs (you might have a chance to play a song in the DLC packs that you don't own yet) in AIR Mode
> Dazzling BGAs
> Easy to learn but hard to master
> Timing/latency is tolerable for KB and controller plays. Good luck playing in Hard Judgment on a ranked game though.

The bad:
> Always-online required (I get that it's for the anti-cheat system, but man we can't play if the servers are down and/or they pulled the plug in their game's servers. Neowiz has a history of shutting down games with no option to refund past purchases)
> The base game and the DLCs are kinda expensive. Just buy them during steam sales so you can save more. 

Rating: 8/10
Very good game but why do I face people that are coming back the game that are actual gods in unranked, lv 7 against someone that perfect 100% a maximum 200bpm song

I play rhythm games on a hitbox, an arcade-style controller with big clicky-clacky buttons. As a result of that, I can't quite recommend this game. It requires you to use analog sticks if it detects that you're playing on a controller; since I don't have those, I have to remap everything with joy2key and use my actual keyboard for menus. There's no mouse support in the menus either, so I'm constantly having to reach for odd buttons (F10 opens the options menu, for instance). It's a pretty big annoyance when the problem could have been avoided by letting me remap just two inputs.

Also, even though being always-online offers a few cool features, the fact that the game won't run at all while offline is pretty unacceptable. 

Finally, there's a double-whammy of difficulty balance that makes the game hard for me to recommend to anyone who isn't basically already a pro at rhythm games. For starters, this game is just really gosh-danged hard. I'm no pro, but I've played my fair share of rhythm games over the years and I'm having a hard time completing most songs on their lowest difficulty. There are very, very few songs that a true beginner could actually complete. Secondly, those few easy songs are all kinda similar; they're generally slow, simple, sugary pop songs. There's a huge variety of music in the game, but if you're starting out (or like me, you just suck) you'll have to get comfortable with playing a lot of very same-y stuff. It's pretty frustrating hearing all these cool tracks in the menu, and having to scroll past them because I'm not already godlike.

Cost's a shit ton for all of the songs. Really depends on if you like the music selection, for it's pretty diverse, but it might not be enough of what you like (without buying many song packs). Other than that, if you like osu mania you will like this (unless you are too good and the music is too easy, but that's highly unlikely ;3

[h1]PREFACE[/h1]
I'm aware my hour count may seem very low in this game, but I am not new to this genre or even this style of game. A little over a year ago I got heavy into 4key through OSU! Mania after years of dedicating myself to Guitar/Clone Hero and deciding I wanted to try something new. In that year I managed to crack at my peak, Top 68k globally and 10k in the US ([url=https://osu.ppy.sh/users/15195525]My Profile for Proof[/url]). So this review comes entirely from my experience with OSU! Mania compared to this game.

[h1]TL;DR[/h1]
If you have any interest in downscrolling rhythm games this is the game for you, easy and intuitive online modes, multiple ways of play (4k, 5k, 6k, 8k), all the charts seem to be VERY well done and vary widely in difficulty welcoming all skill ranges. [b]IN MY PERSONAL OPINION[/b] this game far exceeds the quality of OSU! Mania and is an absolute no brainer, [b]9/10[/b]

[h1]More In-Depth Thoughts:[/h1]
Though games like Clone Hero, OSU! Mania, Stepmania, and Etterna are free giving them absolutely no barrier to entry and a much wider variety of music to choose from the value of an extremely well put together premium game can't be ignored. OSU! Mania for example, the one I've far and away played the most of, has 4k/7k as officially supported ranked difficulties but they are still at the end of the day side modes to the far more popular OSU! Standard. This means it gets updated far less often and major changes to the system are rare. Which is why a decent portion of the community migrated away to Etterna. However, something like DJMAX has been worked on by the same studio for years with downscrolling being their only focus, thus the system feels and looks tighter. I've never met a person on planet earth who likes Mania's release timings on long notes. This game not only doesn't have that issue but also makes LNs more interesting by adding a second type known as Side Tracks. I personally found this quite clunky in my first hour or two and it's still 99% of the time the reason I drop an FC (or MC in this game) but the more tracks I played the more I enjoyed this addition (Try KD/A if you want a really fun example of the mechanic in action without the difficulty being so high it feels overwhelming). Changes like that as well as how much more transparent feeling the scoring system is and many other features such as the ranked 1v1 online mode and really enjoyable single player content make this game a massive value proposition for more than JUST the free play feature you get in most Rhythm Games. The biggest knock against this game compared to a free alternative is the song variety (lack of representation of certain genres like Jazz and Metal which can often be some of the most fun genres in 4k) and the fact most songs don't have every single difficulty meaning a song you really enjoy might be inaccessible due to being out of your skill range or un-fun to play for the opposite reason. The DLC is VERY expensive (Holy Shit it's $127.07 ON SALE for the complete collection) but you get a pretty decent chunk of new songs with each pack so it doesn't feel as bad to buy them piece meal, and the base game (on sale for $15 as of writing this) is really jam packed with songs as is. Additionally though we might be lacking overall in genre representation the songs that are there are mostly original to this game and are all extremely well charted. Mania tended to have same-y repetitive patterns due to the way the community self regulates and standardized itself. This game isn't afraid to change up a specific pattern within the same song or experiment with more unique implementations of pre-existing patterns. Though it makes sight reading a little more difficult at my level of play it also makes tracks more fun and even makes lower difficulty content still interesting to play (again I point to KD/A and it's usage of Side Tracks to emulate the dance moves that go with the song, something Beat Saber also did with the same song). This game will for sure be my go-to for 4k gameplay for the foreseeable future if not forever, as I consider also trying to learn something like 6 or 8 key once my 15* clear rate goes from 2 to every track available in the game. Anyone with even the slightest interest in Japanese Arcade Style Rhythm games has no reason to not at least try this game, you won't be disappointed.

[h1]Closing Thoughts:[/h1]
This review is longer than every other review I've ever written combined and multiplied by 2 and it's on a game I currently only have 5 hours in. If that alone isn't enough to tell you how passionate I am about it and how good this game is I'm unsure how to sell you on it. I just recently bought an XP-Pen Tablet to start learning OSU! Standard (based on Elite Beat Agents/Ouendan) and have all the sudden found myself rediscovering my love for 4k after feeling a massive burnout and planning on taking a break from it. That tablet probably won't see much use in the near future and I honestly couldn't be happier.

I absolutely LOVE this game. it's what I wanted out of OSU! mania and quaver, but done perfectly. the charts are difficult enough to be fun and challenging without being unnecessary chord walls, and the game itself is graphically beautiful as well. the starting selection of songs is pretty diverse as well, and you unlock songs pretty quickly (i unlocked like 5 in my first 40 minute play session). while i'm not usually a fan of forced keysounded games, since i don't like keysounding usually, it's done rather pleasantly in this game so unless you're failing horribly at a song or really off on your offset it's not too disruptive. my one note is as a beginner, definitely change the control layout. the default layout is uncomfortable on the pinkies, and since it's not traditional 6k it's hard to process spatially. i recommend a s ; ' for the main 4k, and left and right alt for the side notes, since they aren't actually off on the side. this feels better spatially and comfort wise as a beginner, and is also reminiscent of the layout of a sound voltex controller, and sound voltex is a game with a similar 4k and side key format.

This game never fails to put a smile on my face. There is music here for everyone and you will find yourself coming back to the same songs over and over again. DJMAX achieves a level of satisfaction that most games cannot. You can truly feel yourself improving each and every minute that you play. A forever game and a must have for fans of the music/rhythm genre.

It took me 1 hour to download this game and another hour to realize that i wanted to uninstall and refund. Before I go off, I will have to say that this game has an amazing user interface,. All the interactions and menu animations are absolutely gorgeous. However, this does not change the fact that this game is just a worse version of Osu!mania. The song selection can not even begin to match the massive user generated DATABASE Osu! holds. Any song and any artist will probably already have a map on Osu! if you seached, and if it's a popular one there's probably 3-4 maps already done by different mappers. 

Quantity isn't the only advantage Osu! holds over this game, they hold an advantage in gameplay/map quality too! Having a system where anyone is allowed to upload their own maps and everyone can play them means that the community determines the quality & promotes the popularity of the maps. Simply put: popular maps are popular because they are good and liked by the player base. This game however, generate their own maps and have their own internal quality control. This provides a solid base-line for map quality, but it cannot attain excellence. There can only be so many "excellent maps" in such a small sample size that this game provides, meaning Osu! beats this game soundly in quality.

These are just some of the things I've got off the top of my head. It may sound like I'm shilling for Osu! but I really did enjoy this game. Just not for the price.

I really wanted to like this game. It clearly has had a ton of work put into everything from the songs and videos to the menu transitions. What ultimately defeated me was the controls.

I was just starting to get the hang of the odd A-S-Lshift and ;-'-Rshift, as presented in the tutorial, when the next group of songs added a fifth input which was shared by the D and L keys. I had to shift both my hands to accommodate the change, essentially restarting the learning process, and then I was constantly having trouble with the D and L keys because I would mistakenly chain them together. Six fingers and only five inputs. The ratio made it extremely difficult to read the notes too. 

Finally, I became so frustrated that I just stopped playing. I had a bad experience with a good game. Maybe I'll come back to it with a cooler head, but the ergonomics here are really painful and definitely worth talking about.

No clue who decided that the UI has to be as cluttered and flashy as possible, but it makes for a really terrible experience because you simply can't see shit.
Also no options to disable said clutter. 

Its unfortunate, but this alone makes it extremely unpleasant to play, so i will have to refund it.

It is a good game only in itself, never about other features like the online mandatory which is always the worst part. Nobody likes to pay a developer to own end-users' private assets that include the game itself and the machines the game occupies. Online dependency among paid software has always been a crap and unreliable. It simply takes controls from the users and generates more confusing issues and underappreciation. 

You cannot play this game offline; you cannot play this game standalone; you cannot play this game without accepting constant product changes; and you cannot even run this game without all their Internet and server demands. 

Whoever develops software interfaces like this is ultimately untrust-worthy. you can't expect those commercial group lasts for you forever. If one-day they go, your machine is roasted. So reconsider to purchase this game although it has a best music performing gameplay.

Also, the online mode is suspeciously cheating everywhere if you understand this type of game and played it with others. The irony is its anti-cheat engine running in background. It is just not right, too commercial, very little humane.

Honestly this game is pretty good.
Through my life I always played stuff like Guitar hero 3 Legends of Rock. However I've been absent from Rhythm games until 2020 when Friday Night Funkin came around and brought back this interest, Proceeding to move onto things like Quaver and Stepmania.

This game is really cool and it comes with a lot of content from the get-go alongside DLC and even battlepasses for cosmetic purposes (Which also comes with a free battlepass aswell). 

However, Even buying the Deluxe edition in which gives you more a couple of the DLCs, You'll be spending A LOT of money. The base game itself is good enough haha.

Having been a DJMAX fan since the OG PSP days (hooo-boy that's long ago) this game is the definitive version of the franchise (imo) Having tracks from the beginning in DMP1 all the way up to New Collabs, it is going to bring back all the nostalgia if you've played from the start and have been following the series. 

The game itself has the most polish of ANY rhythm game I've played, huge song selection most of which are wonderfully charted. 

As a controller only player I am ecstatic that the impossible key combinations are all only in SC charts, and every song in any key mode (4,5,6,8) as long as it's in normal/hard/maximum (all difficulty options) is all playable with a controller (ie all the patterns included are possible). This is a huge problem for me in all other rhythm games as they make no distinction to the player whether they're on controller or keyboard and lump all the patterns together including impossible charts.

As for the strict online only part, I can understand why. As piracy is a huge thing and this is probably the best way to mitigate and counter piracy. In this day and age (in 2022) we should have a permanent internet connection anyways so this should not be an issue at all. 

The other thing is that it's relatively expensive without a sale, so do wait for a sale before purchasing!

TL;DR 
Pros:
-THE Definitive DJMAX game
-Huge amounts of songs
-Controller impossible charts are all SC difficulty only 
-Most songs are wonderfully charted 
-True keynotes allow players to inject their own flair into songs
-Beautifully animated background videos (and a collection to watch them in)

Cons:
-It's expensive

Cheers, and hope to meet you on the ladder or in game if you decide to buy the game!

From the moment I've started playing this game, I've fallen in love with it. While I say this, I certainly can't say it's a game for the faint of heart. If you love the DJMAX series or are interested in trying it, the game is definitely worth it on sale; however, if you expect difficulty holding combo or accuracy on a play is going to be too much for you, consider holding off.

The game is an overall charming revival of the series, with a varied song selection and surprisingly thorough charting principles on the "easier" songs so that nearly everything is a blast to play. The game encourages players to try out a variety of modes with different chart difficulties so that the game continues to remain fresh across the same songs. I wish more free content was added to the game throughout its lifespan; however, what we have so far is certainly a package worth recognizing.

More than just a simple rhythm game with music and keys to press, this game offers an ecosystem of progression through unlocks (songs, skins and so on) and is designed in a way that encourage you to improve beyond what i've experienced in other games.

This is a solid rhythm game with good charting across a variety of formats. There are some things you should know before buying though:

- Songs are grouped by which past game they were ported from, which means there is no sensible grouping by genre or aesthetic. This means it is extremely likely that the songs you find appealing will be spread across various DLCs.
- While the formats are labelled as 4k, 5k, 6k, and 8k, all modes actually also have two "side tracks" similar to Sound Voltex's FX buttons. I found it odd and unexpected that the 4k mode uses 6 buttons.
- You cannot rebind "side track" inputs on gamepad, even though you can on keyboard, so you may need to do some awkward gamepad key mapping to get your preferred input method to work.
- Nearly all songs except for collaboration songs have key sounds, which cannot be turned off. This specifically means key sounds that are taken out of the original track and then timed to your inputs. I really dislike this, because a rhythm game shouldn't be made easier by muting the audio, and yet that's what this mechanic achieves in practice.

All that said I do enjoy the game, but it sure is pricey and I don't think I'd feel the same if i hadn't got it on sale.

DJMax Respect V is probably the most robust, complete rhythm game on Steam, albeit with a steep price point for those wishing to jump in at this point. I have logged ~100 hours in this version, WAY more on the PS4 version, and play a LOT of other rhythm games across all platforms - please take this into account when I give my thoughts and opinions on this game.

Good:
+ Great, diverse soundtrack. From slow orchestral songs to upbeat bops, I'm sure anyone would find at least a dozen songs that they'll want to play every session. And this is made by a Korean, so there's a lot of songs with Korean lyrics too. So Korean speakers or K-pop fans looking for something fresh might enjoy a lot of the songs
+ Great UI (in and out of song). UI elements are both stylistically-superb and functionally-relevant, menus are relatively easy to navigate (esp. by rhythm game standards), etc.
+ Large range of difficulty. Not only do songs have different difficulties, but there are different button modes: 4 button, 5 button, 6 button, and 8 button. So beginners and experts will find somewhere to start. AND the different button modes has the added bonus of accessibility, so it's a win-win!
+ Lots of content. Lots of stats to look at. Lots of things to collect... almost to the point to it being a bad thing
+ Online mode. It's a mode. Online. With friends or ranked. There's a lot to do. It's so fun and robust that you start to forget that few rhythm games even have online
++++++++ There's a Girls Frontline pack. Abandon laifu AND waifu. Obtain raifu

Bad:
- LOTS of paid DLC, though I am more sympathetic about this. I don't think this is really a cash grab - there is just a lot because most of the DLC is from the original PS4 that came out 3 years before this game. Some people might say, "well if you already had the charts/songs on PS4, just include them in this version for free;" but there might be some re-mapping or re-licensing that they might need to do for the PC version, so idk. Regardless, it is a lot of money to spend to be current. As someone who spends a lot of money at the arcade, this isn't a huge dealbreaker. But if you want a PC rhythm game experience and are broke AF, you might want to stick to stuff like Muse Dash or Beat Saber.
- Air mode is very lackluster. It feels like they wanted to go with the whole live play experience (remember GH Live?), but they didn't fully commit. You'll play it once and never again
- Season pass and FOMO content is very toxic. Normally, I'm on the fence on this one, but there is a LOT of paid DLC in this game. 
--------- To start this version of the game, you "Press any key to pay respect." But in the PS4 version, you "Press X to pay respect." The PS4 version of this game is by far superior to the PC version in this regard.

Tipping points:
~ Most of the songs in this game feature keysounds. Keysounds mean that if you hit a note early or late when playing a track, the note in the song will play early or late respectively. Some people love this, some people HATE this, and most people feel whatever about it (think O2jam or IIDX). If you HATE rhythm games with keysounds, you will not like that about this game; but there are a few DLC packs w/o them (i.e., Deemo, Cytus, Nexon packs... off the top of my head). Conversely, if you LOVE keysounds, you will be disappointed with some packs NOT featuring them. And Neowiz isn't very transparent regarding what will or will not feature keysounds
~ PS4 functional and DLC parity issues. Neowiz did a lot of changes (and even nerfing) to the PS4 version to keep it on par or lesser with the PC version, especially at launch. And as of this review, starting with the Nexon pack, all collab DLC packs will be PC exclusive. This means that the PC version is the definitive version of this game, but who knows what will happen if Neowiz moves back to console.
~ SC charts. If you're coming from PS4, please note that SC charts cannot be played on a Dualshock controller due to how the Dpad functions. Inversely, this ONLY applies to SC charts - any other chart can be played on a controller as they are up-to-par with the PS4 charts.

This review may be biased, as I'm a fan of the DJMAX series since Portable 2 release, but - tech issues aside - I think anyone would appreciate the job done on the game, and the amount of music content on purchase. It has a good mix between old and new.

It did take me a good amount of hours to get the game running how I needed - sync issues between audio and video, game not liking my audio output device for some reason, low framerates or performance issues. A lot of things could go wrong with the game and found little info out there (besides perhaps the official Discord server which still seems quite active). I take it all rhythmic games will need a couple of tricks here and there to have them running smooth, and may always be a solution.

Game modes are enjoyable, especially since the Arcade mode was replaced with Air mode (which is basically a radio station broadcasting songs and you jump in to play them at your desired difficulty). Free Style and MIssion modes are still there, and Online (Versus) mode was smooth when I tried it too - maybe the matchmaking takes a bit longer occasionally but my experience was good.

Lastly, while I'm not a fan of the season pass model, it is good that at least the game does not go into p2w path - at least not from what I've seen. There are several unlocks for the season (4 is the first one I play) and they are only cosmetics. For the rest, it's just your skills.

If you're a DJMAX fan, you probably already have this game and are enjoying it, but if you're not and you're looking to get into DJMAX, prepare some cash buffer because if you like rhythmic games and are willing to push through the initial learning curve, this game will be your new obsession.

First getting this out of the way; online-only has never bothered me with this game and I've never been kicked due to a spotty connection. YMMV, of course.

As for the game itself, the graphic design and art direction are just absolute eye candy. You'll spend as much time staring at the animated backgrounds in menus as actually playing. Countless music genres and styles to choose from. I have almost all the DLCs and there are around 30 songs I've never played nor plan on playing since they aren't my cup of tea, but the variety EXISTS and you'll still be prodded into discovering new songs in Online mode.

If you come from other rhythm games, be advised that the timing window is on the lenient side here, and there's no way to know if you hit the notes early or late (thank Konami for suing other rhythm games into cutting features). Chart difficulty on higher levels makes up for the timing window, with the most difficult songs being kind of reminiscent of O2Jam's mashy style of charts. Also the big majority of the songs are keysounded. Those that aren't are mostly the licensed tracks, which is a shame but it's understandable that licensed tracks won't provide MUCA with all the source sounds and bites for the track.

Probably the very best paid beatmania-like rhythm game on PC as of 2021.

As a last word of warning, developers behind the DJMAX series have been known to completely ditch their mobile online-only games in the past and leave them unplayable, rendering all your purchases lost. This game has been going strong for 4 years on PS4 and 2 years on PC, so beware if you plan on keeping this forever or the admission price is a sacrifice on your wallet.

There is, dare I say, nothing that quite compares to the robust quality of this rhythm game in the music game genre. I bought Respect on PS4 years ago and fell in love immediately. There is so much to work towards, so many great songs, and plenty of options on how to play. A rhythm game with actual progression? What? And it's fun? What!?

Also, because I feel like it deserves recognition, the graphic design of this game is insane. I could sit on the main menu themes forever. Whoever is in charge of this game's art direction is an absolute god. 

$60 can be pretty steep, because it most definitely is when looking at all the expansions for this game as well. Well, if you're on the fence then please take this as a message that this game is worth every penny. This game just keeps giving the more I play it with the occasional free track updates as well. 

Plus, uh, you can play with your friends. Which is also pretty dope.

After a couple hours of playing I personally can't recommend this game. It was on a crazy sale so I went for it. 

Honestly... The charts don't feel good to play in my opinion. It feels like the notes are placed arbitrarily through the tracks and they shuffle between the melody, rhythm/drums and other aspects of the music too frequently. Just personally it's not for me... There are other games that do the same thing but better... Again, in my opinion. The charts just don't feel great to play.

Also, I know that side notes are ingrained in the charts as a mechanic in the game, but it's something that adds frustration to me as a player who is used to 4/6 key play and it actually being 4/6 keys not 4 (+2)/6 (+2). I guess I'm just not used to change.

This game adds a different depth of play to the rhythm genre with extra mechanics to increase the difficulty; some players may like that challenge. Personally  it's more bothersome.
‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ

This game is kind of expensive if you don't wait for a sale, and it has always-online DRM, but it's one of the best places to start if you're relatively new to rhythm games. What you're paying for here is polish, presentation, and quality charts for most skill levels. 

There are free alternatives out there, but they sometimes require going to forums from 2011 to find song packs, the visuals will be for 480p screens, or if nothing else that the song charts are made by rhythm game enthusiasts who have 16 fingers. 

With around $26 (the current sale price for the Deluxe Edition) you get something like 200 songs, all with videos, key sounds (the notes actually play the sound from the music), and note charts for 4,5,6 and 8 button playstyles ranging from beginner to insane. You can pick this pack up and learn with a gradual difficulty ramp from beginning to end.

If you master all of that and you don't want to pay for the hundreds of other songs, you can easily transition into the community developed games where you might sacrifice quality, convenience, and presentation for variety and difficulty.

While I absolutely love the DJMax franchise, and have been playing these games for over a decade, I have to put this point number 1 up-top; [b]This game requires an active internet connection at ALL TIMES, even if you never intend to interact with any of its online components.[/b] It also has intrusive anti-cheat features that scans your active processes for anything it doesn't like, and if it finds something, will completely prevent you from playing, again, even if you never intend to interact with any of its online components. If they're even doing server maintenance, you can't play the game at all. I'm telling you this because the fucking store page won't. THIS is anti-consumer as fuck.

Behind all that lies one of the greatest rhythm games ever compiled, and a love letter to fans of a franchise that has been running over a decade strong. The level of quality and amount of content provided here is unmatched by any other rhythm game on the market, and I feel the pricing is justified. Devs are constantly pushing updates, fixes, and even some free additional content. The base game regularly goes on sale to about $20 (usually even less), and it's definitely worth it if you're just looking to get a taste.
I'm very sorry to inform you that this game will not get any favorable comment in some regions. (China)

[b]UPDATE on 27 Oct. 2021:
[i]We are very sorry to inform you that this DLC pack will not be available for purchase in some regions. (China)[/i][/b]

[b]IF YOU DON'T KNOW WHAT THIS IS AND ARE JUST CURIOUS[/b]
The base game won't let you down. Just buy, or add it to wishlist and wait for discount.
[i]However, as other reviews mentioned, this game can't be played offline, and installs an anti-cheat plugin (some consider it rootkit) on your machine.[/i]
DJMAX is an arcade-style rhythm game, where you [b]follow the commands on-screen and mash buttons to the beat[/b]. Each command corresponds to an actual sound in the song, so you're essentially recreating the song in real time. On the flip side, broken music is in itself a punishment for shoddy play.

As of June 2020, [b]the base game contains 167 songs, about 130 of which are worth revisiting[/b]. The rest are forgettable, but I can't name a bad song. Each song comes with at least 6 charts (8 being common) spread over 4 distinct input modes, with varying difficulty. This sheer volume of content makes the game [b]easy to pick up, but insanely hard to master[/b] - it takes maybe 2 years of daily practice to clear all charts out there. Also, each song features its own unique music video, some of which are hands-down exquisite.
Some early reviews point out that the game's audio isn't in sync with the visuals, but [b]the audio sync has since been reprogrammed; now it works fine[/b]. I play many respectable rhythm games and have no timing problem with this game.

[b]ARE THE DLCs WORTH BUYING?[/b]
[b]If you love rhythm games, the V Extension pack is worth it.[/b] A healthy selection of new songs and a full new set of challenge missions make this pack stand out.
For the other packs, it REALLY depends. DJMAX is known for having groovy music and polished visuals, but to be fair, many songs in the "retro" DLCs are kind of forgettable. I'm talking about 1 out of maybe 4, but considering how expensive each pack is... :\ That being said, if you want extreme challenges, the [b]BLACK SQUARE pack offers more than the others do[/b].

DRM is atrocious and game will likely die when they shut the servers down. But right now it's the best rhythm game experience you can have on PC. Enjoy it while it lasts or until something better comes along.

This is my first foyer into the DJMAX series, and I‚Äôm honestly pleasantly surprised with my experience. 

DJMAX is filled with personality and style. The colours and interface pop out at you in a way that‚Äôs not entirely jarring, but not subdued enough that you can‚Äôt appreciate the art and aesthetic it‚Äôs going for. The game also has quite a few unlockables, from profile cards to different skins you can use to freely customize your approach notes and the bar thingy I can‚Äôt quite currently name.  

While I personally don‚Äôt find a good chunk of the maps to be anything too difficult than what a lot of avid rhythm game players are already familiar with (this is honestly probably due to the songs used), the ones that do hit‚Äî hit pretty good. I‚Äôd say this game has a lot to offer in regards to content from all the maps being charted in 4-8B, the challenges, to online play (and tbh there‚Äôs no use playing multiplayer unless you‚Äôve unlocked at least all the base game songs‚Äî which takes quite a while to do), that it might be a little daunting for someone looking for a casual experience. 

Similarly to a lot of people, I have a hard time fully recommending this due to its online-only experience. For someone looking to get the steam deck and be able to play this game on the go, this is a huge disadvantage. Pricing-wise, this game is also extremely expensive. Getting the base game with all its DLC would cost you a pretty penny, so I‚Äôd wholeheartedly recommend just getting this game and its DLC when it goes on sale. 

Overall I‚Äôd say this was a good experience regardless, albeit much of its shortcomings can possibly be a deal-breaker for a lot of people.

My review is more to address other problems I see mentioned in the other posts. There are absolutely cons to this game, and I would say they're as follows:
-Price dissuades anyone but diehards from buying it.
-Always online can make a bad experience for those with a shoddy connection
-I don't have an issue with 4B but you absolutely may have trouble finding MP matches with other button settings.
Outside of those, I really wanted to address the complaints regarding Xingcode and the such. Yes, it is included in the game, yes it's probably just as ineffective at stopping cheaters as battleye and yes it is kernel level.

What you really have to let sink in though is absolutely every single current game with multiplayer has anti-cheat, and it's all kernel level whether they advertise it or not. Your alternative is folks like myself will write a kernel level hack that will be undetectable, or worse, you end up with GTA's online mode that's so lax it allows your IP to be exposed to other players.

While this does mean that there are exploits to Xigncode to control someone's computer, that person has to install a virus that directly targets that game onto your machine. In other words: if you don't have a virus from some place else, from someone whom knows you play dj max, then you're fine.

Held back by a mediocre song selection and strange difficulty choices/weird note patterns.

Song selection: So, you know when you're watching an anime, and a big ol hip hop dude walks in the room, and they REALLY want to show you this guy IS hip hop, so a composer that's never written hip hop in his life now has to make a backing track for this character, and it is so painfully generic, and not memorable at all....Someone made an entire game with that, but with the occasional K-pop track sprinkled in. They showed me some mercy, and put in three guilty gear songs. Two of which are good. 

difficulty/note patterns: Weird how there's alot of songs that have one star difficulty ratings, and then jump straight to seven stars or eight star. Smallest jump i've seen is a one star to a six. Weird how these are the only two options, yet some songs get four. Some songs on their normal difficulty feel like hard songs. There's an issue with some note patterns. Patterns i'd deem absurd. There's alot of really jumpy patterns that don't feel like they follow the rhythm of the song, rather, they're doing their own thing. Some songs in this game, once they start have zero breaks to help you breathe or get your bearings. Just a non stop assault of notes. Not even a hold note to show you a little mercy. These feel the sloppiest because I got no sense of what they wanted me to do at all. Typically, good note patterns feel like im either playing AN instrument, or just following the general melody of the song, and some songs do this, but i find a little around maybe 1/4 songs DON'T.

-Ranking system means nothing. 
There's only two grades. A and B. It's really satisfying to be told you got an S or a SS or even just an A+ or something, you won't find that here. When I fail I kinda want to be told how badly. There are songs I barely made it out alive, and some where I felt "I did okay" only to be met with the same B rank. Why even have it at that point?

-Notes make noise: Not a fan of rhythm games where when you hit a note, your note makes a UNIQUE sound. Typically in other rhythm games its a simple drum beat or tambourine, or missing a note just results in muted note. In this game, it's sometimes a unique instrument but its sort of playing alongside the original. The end result is, even if im scoring 100%'s MY note still plays out of sync with the music and it just sounds horribly awkward. There doesn't seem to be a way to turn this off.

plus sides:
The menu is stylish.

I'd recommend amplitude (harmonix), A project diva game, muse dash, or visiting your local arcade and playing jubeat.

[h1]üé§Introduction[/h1]
[b]DJMAX RESPECT V[/b] is the latest rhythm game from the DJ Max series that has been releasing games since 2004. This title has a lot of content to get through in the base game alone and goes above and beyond what you expect to find in a standard rhythm game. Despite so many things going right for this title, the one red flag is a constant need for internet connection which raises some issues for the future of this game...

[h1]‚úîÔ∏èPros[/h1]
‚Ä¢ Loads of skins to unlock for the notes and charts
‚Ä¢ Focuses on the precision of hitting notes
‚Ä¢ Loads of songs from multiple genres that all include music videos
‚Ä¢ A lot of content and things to unlock
‚Ä¢ Different modes including mission, Online, and freestyle modes
‚Ä¢ Varies difficulties along with 4, 5, 6 & 8 button charts

[h1]‚ùåCons[/h1]
‚Ä¢ Requires constant internet connection (even in solo modes)
‚Ä¢ No practice mode to nail tricky charts
‚Ä¢ High difficulty curve as you start improving and moving onto harder songs

[h1]üïπGameplay[/h1]
[h3][b]DJ Max? Never heard of it[/b][/h3]
Admittedly, this is my first experience with a DJ Max game so if you're a veteran of the series then I doubt you'll need much of an explanation of what this game is. However, if you're new to this game like I was, let me explain how this title differs from other rhythm games.

[b]DJ MAX RV[/b] is unlike other traditional rhythm games I've played in the past (I admit I've only played Guitar Hero), it focuses heavily on hitting notes with precision. Every note you can hit gives you a different amount of points based on how precisely you hit it, from 1% (wasn't even close to hitting the note on time) to 100% (hitting the note perfectly in time with the beat), this instantly gives the game a bigger skill gap between experienced players. To strive for completing a song without missing a note is one thing, but hitting every note perfectly is insane for some songs.

Another small aspect that you might notice about this title is the game doesn't punish you for hitting buttons where there isn't a note, so technically you can just spam buttons mindlessly to pass a song. However, as previously mentioned, you'll probably get a worse score if you don't at least try to hit the notes in time, so for competitive matches, spamming isn't an option at all. Now, why don't we talk about difficulty.

[h3][b]How to give yourself Carpal Tunnel[/b][/h3]
[b]DJ MAX RV[/b] isn't shy to put you through your paces and destroy you with ridiculous charts that will probably kill your wrist. To say that this game has a high difficulty curve is an understatement but that doesn't mean that the game only caters to players who are willing to put in the time to learn this game. The game rates difficulty on a star scale, 1 being the easiest and 15 being the hardest for those who want to experience carpal tunnel. Getting better at this game is difficult and the game doesn't really help you with it either.

One major gripe I have with this game is there isn't any sort of practice mode where you can replay a section of a song to nail a set of difficult notes, which was a surprise considering how difficult some of the songs can be. The only way of 'practicing' is to play it over and over again and brute force yourself through a song till it finally 'clicks'. This is only really applicable to higher-difficulty songs, but it's still a problem I face when trying higher difficulties outside my comfort zone.

Another great aspect of this game is the multiple different button modes that you can play, 4, 5, 6 or 8. The best part about it is there's nothing pushing you to aim for 8 buttons, if you have the most fun playing 4 buttons then you can just use the 4 button mode only, you'll have a more compact board than the other buttons, but still get high difficulty songs to play on.

[h3][b]So... Much... Content..![/b][/h3]
If you were expecting a simple rhythm game with just a tracklist of songs to play through trying to get the new high score then you'd be dead wrong. There's freestyle mode that is your standard, choose a song to play on whatever difficulty, online which offers open lobbies and a competitive mode, countless things to unlock (music videos, artwork,  etc.), challenges to complete, mission mode, and an air mode.

[h3][b]TURN THE MUSIC UP[/b][/h3]
It seems like the DJ Max series in general does a lot more than your average rhythm game, with an extensive tracklist of [i]"...over 150 unique songs..."[/i] in the base game alone, which offers a wide variety of genres along with each of these songs having a music video in the background, that range from a live concert of that song to people creating music videos for these songs specifically. It really does feel like this game goes above and beyond what a rhythm game should strive for.

[h3][b]Error: You aren't connected to the internet[/b][/h3]
One aspect that worries me above everything else about this title however, is the fact that the game [b]requires you to have constant internet access[/b], this raises multiple red flags. At some point this game could just be shut down and no longer playable at the flick of a switch, the base game is expensive enough as it is let alone if you dive into DLC territory. I'm unsure why I need constant internet connection even when playing songs solo, but the fact that it's there should be something you think about before even thinking about purchasing this title.

[h1]üñ•Ô∏èGraphics[/h1]
Not exactly an area that you tend to look for in rhythm games, if anything you're only expecting a clean chart that's easy to read notes off. However,[b]DJ MAX RV[/b] offers a lot of flexibility and customization with your chart allowing you to mix and match different chart skins and different styled notes. Although this isn't necessary by any means or gives you an advantage, it's nice to have a unique style that makes everyone's chart look different.

[h1]üí≠Closing Thoughts[/h1]
[b]DJ MAX RV[/b] is something special, it's clear that the developers put in a lot to make this game good and it clearly shows. Even if you just get the base game there's still a lot of stuff to do before you even consider getting the DLC (which there is a lot). If you're new to the game there is quite a difficulty curve to get through, but once it eventually clicks you'll love the game even more. Even for the veterans who have played the countless releases before this game, I think they'll love it as well. The only downside is the constant requirement to be connected to the internet which I can see being the breaking point for some people since the game could be switched off at any point. Overall though, a fantastic rhythm-based game that I almost feel ashamed of for not knowing this series existed for years. Now if you'll excuse me, I have some tendons in my wrist to start snapping...

This is my first entry in the series I've played and it's cool, it's fun, it's pretty, and it's really jank and strange. I'd say this figuratively, but with the context clues I've picked up from the long-running music artists and the "Lore" in certain videos, this might literally be a huge and constant passion project and bless them for it.

This is as much an art project as it is a game. Some of the videos, some of the interface options, a few of the menus even, are absolutely beautiful, which makes it strange when placed next to doodles of PS1 or DS styled graphics. There's entire anime intros for background videos, then there's some doofus farting in his laboratory in the next. There's high profile artists like Marshmello and licensed League songs right next to a Fruity Loops Studio experiment made for the PS Vita 10 years ago made with their favorite midi instruments.

I've just never seen such contrast in quality and consistency. It's charming in a way but it kind of leaves half the game kind of undesirable to the casual player. It's true many of the songs are not originally catered to the western audience but also many of the songs are just not fit for a rhythm game, personally speaking. A large amount of them are very short and filled with strange jazz or dubstep fills, switching practically randomly between instruments. I'm playing more improv than I am rhythm half the time and as a consequence it doesn't feel good trying to learn those songs.

I do really enjoy the variety of difficulties however. The variable number of buttons and the extreme range of difficulty from simple to impossible is really nice. Online works pretty spotless too from all the time I've spent with a few friends.

Might be rambling a little but there's quite the rabbit hole to this game. Also the price point is a bit steep, this is a sale-only game for me for both the game and especially the dlc.

Major caveat out of the way first: the game uses XingCode 3 always-online DRM. Nearly a negative review based on that alone but the rest of the game makes up for it.

Otherwise, an extremely polished game with a massive amount of songs all charted for 4 - 8 key. There are some audio latency issues that were fixed for me by running the game in windowed mode and making sure vsync is disabled; once that's sorted it plays perfectly.

If you're only interested in 4 key, I'd wait until this game is on sale as you won't find anything more challenging than Stepmania and its various offspring can offer - though there's some quality charts here to play for sure, it's not quite worth paying full price (at the time of writing) in my opinion.

Very good and polished rhythm game. Tons of songs, especially with the DLC and difficulty that ranges from sleeping on the keyboard to setting your keyboard on fire. As a PS4/PC port, you might be worried about controls if you don't have a gamepad. But no worries! They really thought this one out and I find I actually *prefer* the PC controls over the PS4 version.

DJ Max is all about precision, and it won't fail you for randomly flailing on the keys like most other rhythm games. You'll only fail if you miss the notes entirely (don't get me wrong, on harder songs you *will* fail). However, hitting the notes as precisely as possible is how you'll net the highest score possible and getting a true 100% is very difficult even on easier songs until you get a ton of practice.

Highly recommended for any fan of the genre.

Game is way harder than it needs to be to get into. More frustrating than fun. Way too expensive.

Really simple things such as giving each note a different color, having lines to separate the notes in the chart horizontally, and having timing marks on the chart, are absent. Learning a new rhythm game is like learning to read a new language. Playing one well relies upon being able to read that language fluently. This game's language is harder to learn than others with zero benefit. There is no style or hook for this learning curve. I'm no stranger to using nothing but spacing for timing. But this one is just a plain vertical chart. It's just bad design. Sure, after 2 days of playing an hour each I've started to be able play 6 and 8 note charts more fluently, but I've still got a ways to go when I'd probably be able to play 5 and 6 star songs full combo by now if it just differentiated everything better.

Most of the music is butchered and just not fun to listen to while playing. This is one of those games where you are actually playing the music. Before the song starts or even during the song, you can freestyle and hit keys to play your own music of sorts. Play out of time and you'll hear the part you're playing sound at the wrong time. Press the wrong key and you'll hear a totally different instrument or note play. Now that's not awful on its own. It's actually pretty neat. What's awful is that your key presses play sampled notes of whatever instrument is playing in the song. But they aren't the sample of the music at that particular time. It's the same sample over and over and over again. So if you have a piano part for instance that's the same note 3 times in a row, you can pick out immediately that it's just a sampled piano playing repetitively and sounds nothing like the original mix of the song. I don't know about anybody else but I like to actually listen to the music that I'm playing in a rhythm game. Also, not all of the songs are this way, but from the dozen or so I tried most of them were that way. And the ones that weren't were way more enjoyable to actually play. It'd be extremely easy to allow you to just turn this feature off and listen to the original mix of the song.

The best part is that when looking up stuff about this game to try and remedy these issues, I find forum/reddit/comment posts from other people bringing up these same issues. And almost always they're just met with elitest pricks replying "that's how it is and how it should be". "Get good". The usual fare. Not understanding in the slightest that lowering the skill floor does nothing to the skill ceiling and that they've been acutely stockholm syndromed.

And all this gatekeeping for $50?! Not worth it by a long shot. No practice mode? Not even just a no fail mode? Steam DB has this down to $18 on sale in the past, which is a price that might be worth it for this. But even if it was free there's still much more fun rhythm games out there, as the issues with its music are built in and un-fixable. And isn't that the whole point of a rhythm game? 

E: 10/4/21 and this is on sale for $18 again. Most of its DLC as well. Definitely wait for a sale.
