As someone that never grew up with rythm games (I won't count Guitar Hero because no sane person does) I first got my hands on Muse Dash about half a year ago. While it only has two main inputs it can get quiet hard at some point.
So I learned the basics there and wanted to switch over to a normal 4 button rythm game.
And so one of the pc-based games I found was this. DJMAX RESPECT V.
I already heard a lot of mixed reviews about this game but with it being over a year (nearly two if you count in the EA) since it released, I thought many of the problem have been fixed... Well... no...

First of all: For rythm games I have a janky setup where I have to get the offset to about 310ms... Yeah I know... Yup...
Put me on trial and burn me like the "witches" centuries ago...
The problem: The game only goes up to 300ms. "Boo-ho. 10ms. Just get used to that". 
Well... I tried. But the game was still way too offset. It kinda felt like I had to have around 400-500ms...
By no means is that (the additional 100-200ms) a problem with my PC or setup but of this game.

Anyway, next problem: The sound. The audio sliders only go from 50% to 100%...
I really hate the hit sounds (especially because they are so offset) but I can't turn them off/ even further down.

Next problem: Keybindings. I think it's stupid that we can't set multiple keys for one action.
My left pinky finger hovers between control and shift and its akward to hit the correct button sometimes...
(Not the biggest problem but still...)

Next problem: The songs. I went through them and didn't find anything interesting (neither in the easy difficulties, nor in the higher ones).


(Bought the Deluxe Edition on sale for about 22‚Ç¨ (Germany)... Unfortunately I had to get a refund and now my search continues for a better PC-based 4-button rythm game...)

Was on the fence on this for a while, after all, osu and osumania by extension are free, so why pay when I can get a similar experience? I'd normally wait a bit longer, but for anyone who's on the fence while the sale is ongoing, I figured I'd give my thoughts:

DJMAX Respect V has been a lot of fun in the short time I've played it. The presentation is very good, and it just feels and looks premium. The keysounds when you press a key and the background videos playing make playing it a lot more fun, and a cooler experience. Music selection is pretty solid and plentiful.

One important aspect is the charts. While you can find quality charts in osu, no doubt, a lot are not that great. Here things are charted excellently.

There's plenty of different options for different skill levels, you can play with 4 keys to 8 keys, across a few difficulty options. The good thing with paid games like this is each mode and difficulty gets a quality chart, so you can play your favorite songs no matter your skill, whereas with community made charts, you may sometimes find yourself unable to play a song because its only been charted at a very high difficulty level. While it doesn't necessarily affect the difficulty, you have a ton of options in terms of note speed.

As far as modes, there is a live mode where you just play through songs and can comment and view other people's comments. Pretty relaxing. Free play to do whatever, a mission mode, multiplayer: both casual and competitive options. 

There are two big downers IMO:
- Always online is super lame. Not a huge problem for me, but just on principle it's pretty wack for a mostly single player experience
- No practice mode, which is kind of baffling.

Otherwise, game is good. Definitely recommend checking it out while it is on sale, probably would give it a solid nod even out of sale.

As a rhythm game fan (I have played DDR, Cytus II, Osu, Taiko no Tatsujin) I can definitely recommend the game while it is on sale just because the music packs can add up very quickly in price. The game menus are very clean looking, really great and unique visuals for each track as well with the ability to adjust brightness or turn the BG video completely off.

DJMax also gives the player the freedom to choose control settings between 4-keys to 8-keys and adjust song speed within each track as you're playing. 

It is hard to think of a con yet for this game, although I've only had around 14 hours. If there was one thing that would be nice, it would be the option to use Mouse to select things on the screen, it is entirely keyboard controlled but this is probably to accommodate players that use DJMax controllers. A practice mode so I could practice the trickier charts would also be really nice to have.

I would like to also address some things regarding negative reviews that I saw to help anyone who's on the fence about the game. The game does not play notes "out of sync", the beat or notes out of sync with the music happens because the player's timing is off. Keys will be mapped with different elements of the song as it continues (synth, percussion etc etc) and if you are off tempo then those keys with their designated sounds / instrument that are part of the song will sound out of place, but that is entirely on the player and not the game.
real fun, just wish i could play longer, but my carpal tunnel doesnt like it

SERIOUS RHYTHM GAMERS BEWARE: As an Etterna player, I found this game unplayable due to unsolvable audio latency issues with hit sounds. Sadly, I _really_ wanted to play this game.

Specifically, performing any type of calibration so that the notes sync with the music causes hit sounds to be terribly out of sync with the music. Since there is no way to disable hit sounds, and the developers confirmed this will never be added, the community answer to this issue is to play on 0ms and learn to hit everything early.

I think this is unacceptable for any serious rhythm game play. I dropped $100+ on this game and all the DLC during the sale, and requested a refund within 30 minutes.

Original review below:
Really good-looking game with lots of great songs. Unfortunately the terrible key latency and lack of sync config makes this game completely unplayable. The game also has online-only DRM (even though most of the game is single-player). This is NOT the way to show players "respect".

[h1]Update: 02.10.2021[/h1]
I have decided to give this game another shot after over a year of reviewing it and then no longer having played it afterwards. While most of my review is still valid (some parts even more so than before - especially with all the new song packs packed into DLCs), one thing I can for sure say has been improved is latency. The game received some additional settings you can tweak to compensate for your audio latency and I have to say, it's very effective in practice - about a year ago, in many 8-10 star songs I've averaged something about 97% accuracy, which was brought down mostly by me getting out of sync with audio in certain more complex sections of songs, causing me to miss horribly. Now I'm getting over 99,5% accuracy in many of these songs, and I can clearly tell latency has been improved all around.
So, one of the biggest issues about this game has been improved, but outside of that there's not much else. I still can't recommend the game for the price, but if you're considering getting it on sale, it may be worth a consideration. Just be ready to splurge more bucks on DLCs with extra songs, if you want the full experience.

[b]Review[/b]
An excellent and fun rhythm game, which I can't say it's worth the asking price of $50 (or $75 if you want all songs), hence why I can't entirely recommend it. If you asked me, I'd say "$30 for a full package and this review would be positive". $75 is more than even some AAA games, which is why I'll try to judge this game like an AAA game.

Why is it excellent?
- 150 songs (170 with DLC) is nothing to scoff at, that's quite a lot. With a very wide range of genres, I think everyone should be able to find songs they truly like. I especially like the addition of Marshmello's "Alone", I wish there were more songs of this kind from labels like Monstercat, Disciple, Proximity etc. Seems like a somewhat easy way to increase the song library while bringing in more players!
- There's a lot of songs from previous DJMAX games too, a neat nostalgia element for those who haven't played a DJMAX game for years, like me. [strike]Even though there aren't any songs from PORTABLE 3, which is the game that introduced me to rhythm games...[/strike]
- The new AIR gamemode, even though it's basically "random songs with ability to chat", is a simple yet great way to listen to DJMAX's library trying to find songs you like.
- Each songs has 2 or 3 difficulty settings available, which is great for newer players in particular, that can start learning slow songs and then gradually increase the difficulty over time to improve.
- I'm digging the art style a lot. I'm bad at describing such things, if you want to see it in action, just search for some gameplay videos.
- Online multiplayer is, I believe, [strike]a new deal in DJMAX and a very welcome addition in this day and age[/strike] (I was wrong, thank you Kakurady for correcting me). My experience in multiplayer has been flawless so far. There's ranked mode, in which you play against different levels of AI before getting a rank, after which you get to play against real players. Queues might take a minute or two, probably depending on the time of day you're playing rn.
- Can be played with a keyboard or a controller. I personally prefer the keyboard, but the side note mechanic makes me think giving controller gameplay a shot might not be such a bad idea.
- Supports Family Sharing. Given this publisher's ferocious copy protection measures, this is something worth mentioning I guess... [b]EDIT 12.04: Within 2 days, there will be an update that will no longer allow you to share DLCs via Family Sharing. Excellent job, publisher, you're actually making it even worse![/b]

Why is it bad? In no particular order:
- When playing multiplayer, if you're playing a song that you do not own via DLC, you will be forced to sit through and just listen to it instead of playing it. At least right now, DLCs make up under 15% of all available songs so it's not such a huge deal right now, but if more DLCs come, it might become one.
- The game requires you to be online to play, which I believe the only reason for that is being a part of game's copy protection. Cmon guys, even the universally hated Denuvo DRM allows you to play offline!
- The game comes with an anti-cheat. Which usually isn't a bad thing, but this game uses XIGNCODE3, which has been proven to dig extremely deep into your system and basically spy on it by gathering extensive logs, compromising its security. You have been informed (of course by me or by yourself, because the game doesn't care enough to tell you), do as you wish with this. 
- While the game allows you to adjust note speed and background dim/brightness in each song, it doesn't allow you to force these settings upon all songs.
- The volume of certain songs is different compared to other songs. There's also no way to quickly adjust volume without going into settings or dropping the system/output volume entirely.
- There's no option to change the position of the "playfield" on the screen in AIR mode (which I don't see why it would be a problem when chat is disabled) and in multiplayer (I'd rather have my playfield on the right rather than on the left)
- No option to completely disable SFX sounds, which will throw off everyone who has to use negative offset to compensate for their audio's latency.
- Numpad Enter cannot be bound to anything. If you manage to play 4K/5K/6K like me, which is by using 1/2/3 numpad keys, you might find this problematic.
- Doesn't support 16:10 displays - if you're still using such a display, you'll be forced to a lower resolution (my brother's example: he's using a 1680x1050 display and he's forced to play in 1280x720). I know DSR/VSR exists, but these features tend to add extra input lag, which is the last thing you want in a rhythm game.
- As I was informed on the official Discord server, there are some other issues, like unconsistenly long loading times (the game takes its sweet time to launch too). Apparently, this has been reported and acknowledged by developers, but months later hasn't been fixed.
- VSync enabled by default for some cursed reason. Yes, it fixes tearing that's visible in a lot of dynamic BGMs but at the tradeoff of input lag. Some players might not even be aware they're hindering themselves!

There's probably more which I might have forgotten about, but I'll edit the review once I do.
Most of these "bad" things I have mentioned are minor and will not affect everyone, but amongst these issues there are some that even free games like osu! don't have, let alone this game with an asking price of $50. The game is playable, enjoyable, well-made. But not made well enough for this price tag.

Post Release Update:
After playing countless hours, I can still say, without a doubt, that this game rules even harder then it did in EA. Since then, the devs have added a "battle-pass" equivalent to the game which lets you unlock additional rewards such as player icons, emotes, themes, and more. All progress made in the battle-pass can be obtained by either playing in online mode, free play, or by playing missions. This is deffinetly refreshing as you are not gated to doing only online portions of the game and are awarded for just playing how you want.

My only gripe would be DLC cost. While the content may be good,  DLC will net you between 7-20+ songs and can be very pricey if you want to jump all in. I suggest waiting for a sale if you would like to get the DLC and to only obtain the song packs. Do not get the gear packs confused as they just give you an additional skin and nothing more. 



Early Access Review:

This review only reflects what I've currently played in the Early Access and includes:
-Air Mode
-Freeplay
-4 Button, 5 Button Modes with difficulties up to SC
-Playing with a PS4 Controller
-Playing with Keyboard Controls (I HIGHLY RECOMMEND SWITCHING TO THIS AS IT IS HELPED ME GREATLY IMPROVE MY SKILL VERSES BEING USED TO THE PS4 CONTROLLER LAYOUT)

If you are familiar with Beatmania, Guitar Hero, or pretty much any rhythm game, you will understand the basic mechanics: Press a button to the note/beat in the song and get a high score. While I have been a fan of DJ Max ever since the PSP releases, I can say that the early access version only shows a PERCENTAGE of content that the rest of what the franchise as a whole offers. Despite a few of these shortcomings, DJ MAX RESPECT V promises a great experience for both old and new players with weekly updates and a responsive development team to criticism and recommendations via their official discord.

First, what does this game offer you in EA? Well, you have access to Air Mode: a Nico Nico Douga-esque experience where you can play a variety of songs based on their BPM (Beats Per Minute) with a (limited) chat box for those in the same lobby as you, and Freestyle mode: pick any of your unlocked songs and play them in various button and difficulty modes.

Songs are unlocked via leveling up and completing some challenges in your collection menu. To level up, you gain experience from playing any of the aforementioned modes, while some of these challenges range from 'Do X Amount of 4B Songs' to 'Get 50,000 Combo in Freestyle' which aren't incredibly hard but can seem intimidating for new players. Because of this, I DO NOT recommend the Unlock Song Pack DLC as it dampens the experience of honing your abilities and retaining what little sense of progression there is in the EA.

Whether you have previously played DJ MAX RESPECT on the PS4 or are a newcomer, there has been several content updates every Thursday as of this review. These updates usually consist of hot fixes and 2-3 new songs added per week. I don't expect this to be a normal thing, but the new music seems very EDM-focused and is very much in line with the style of DJ MAX which is loud sounds, bass drops, and synths galore. So, this is very much so an UPDATED version of DJ MAX RESPECT. 

I recommend this game mostly as a fan of the series and for what the future content alone promises. I will update my review once the game is out of EA, but if you like good music ranging from classical, rap, rock, and EDM in a game with TIGHT and RESPONSIVE controls, then I HIGHLY suggest giving this game a go or at least looking up some of the OST/Gameplay on Youtube as it truly is a banger.

DJMAX has finally made its way back to PC, 11 years after Trilogy, and it sure doesn't disappoint.
With SC mode coming back, an extremely difficult mode, which is pretty much "Master" mode, it will need a keyboard to clear, as it uses all buttons on the keyboard in ways that you could never do on a Dualshock. 

Base game has over 100+ free songs and hundreds more in DLC (can get pretty pricey but definitely worth the cost.) Online is very simple, and its easy to hop into rooms and play with people from all over the world. There is also a ranked mode which pits you against the best of the best to see how high you can climb for banner rewards to flex every season. (I wouldn't try this mode unless you can consistently hit 99%+ on most charts and Button modes, you can pick what mode you wanna pick at lower ranks, but when you get higher, you'll have to pick more than one, and at the highest rank you are forced to play all button modes)

Speaking of seasons, each season has its own Battlepass (I know, I know stick with me for a bit) which lets you grind for banners, icons, and occasionally Combo skins, judgement skins, and UI skins. Its extremely grindy, but the last week of the season gives everyone x4 exp, so its very easy to finish even if you don't play everyday.

I was wondering what they would do after they gave out all the PS4 DLC, but they are still giving us new songs and charts to play with. If you are looking for a new PC rhythm game to get into, or are wondering if its worth getting even if you already own the PS4 version, I highly recommend DJMAX Respect V!

- The price tag on normal occasions, both on the base game and the DLC.
- AIR Mode; specifically, the game doesn't tell you when you've had one playthrough of a song in AIR Mode (relevant for some unlocks), so you'll have to guess when the game actually "awards" you one playthrough.
- DLC releases between this and the PS4 version aren't usually aligned, so if you own both, this one gets priority. Sucks if you own both versions, ngl.

Generally, if you like the DJMAX series, I do think that RESPECT is a must get, although I will say that it isn't worth its normal price tag, so wait for the base game and the DLC to go on sale first. For the songs under the COLLABORATION tab, some of them aren't keysounded, and while that personally does not bother me, I have a feeling it's a problem for other people. It is a big plus that the Guilty Gear, GROOVE COASTER, and Girls' Frontline songs are keysounded, though, but if it helps, just remember that CYTUS, Deemo (to some extent), and CHUNITHM don't actually keysound the songs in their respective games. Lastly, I wouldn't recommend buying gear and note skins; it's not like they add much to the gameplay anyway other than a new look.

EDIT (8/21/21): I don't know if anybody's pointed this out before, but there's two things about this game that I absolutely despise: 
1) There is no option for you to practice HARD JUDGEMENT in any way. It appears in Online Mode if you hit tiebreakers, and on some missions (particularly in the DLC missions), so it's dumb that this game doesn't let you practice it (save for the songs in Mission Mode that actually use it).
2) Speaking of Mission Mode, especially on DLC missions, the game NEVER tells you if HARD JUDGEMENT and/or RANDOM (sometimes both) are active for some songs. You'd think that the game would tell you since it mentions it on most of the missions in the base game missions, so why on earth are they not mentioned???

This doesn't change the fact that I love this game, but if you're going to put a LOT of time into this, these are just some warnings you have to be aware of.

This is an *excellent* rhythm game, with only one major flaw- it's so god damn expensive to get into.
First off, the pros. The base game here has soooo much content if you like rhythm games. There's like, almost 200 songs to get through leveling, up until level 99 or something. And every song has a huge number of beatmaps- 4 button, 5 button, 6 button, 8 button, and usually 2-4 difficulty levels per song. There's so much to do! Not to mention the Air feature, which while I think is kind of stupid, it gives you another place to practice as well as see random gibberish typed out by people mistakenly hitting the enter key while playing a song. I haven't touched the Rankings or Multiplayer stuff and I still have 25 satisfied hours, with plenty more to come as I just play these songs over and over again. I'd say this is an excellent tool to get into or practice your rhythm game skills.
My two qualms though: First off, Mission Mode. A neat idea, playing a set of songs with an objective you need to do, like not missing X amount of times or hitting Y amount of score. But in practice, the missions get real awful real bad. Headache inducing movement, insane "Chaos" modifiers that send the game into overdrive, and gauntlets of challenges in a button combo (Seriously who plays 5 button, it's so wacky) you're not used to. I guess it's something that you can slowly work at, but I feel like some of the challenges are very unreasonable unless you're absolutely insane at rhythm games.
Other issue, cost. This game is not cheap, and all of the DLC is very expensive despite how long this has been around. On top of that, as of writing this I'm not sure how recent the "Clear Pass" is, but that's an extra $20 for a couple of extra emotes and themes- themes being something that doesn't exist in the base game to my knowledge, you need DLC for that. It's almost insulting how much they expect people to pay for that, battle passes in a rhythm game are stupid as is but charging $20 for the privledge of getting a useless banner is just... it's low, man.

All in all, if you're interested in rhythm games and you found this during a nice sale, I totally recommend it! Maybe try it out for two hours and see if it gets with you, it's pretty different from mobile rhythm games but is very rewarding once you get into it.

This is one of the most polished rhythm games I have ever played in my life, so far. DJMax Respect V has that "premium" kind of feel I cannot really describe. This is the first installment of the DJMax series released on PC. I would say the game is suitable for all skill levels, whether you are beginner to rhythm games or a veteran, this is a 100% BUY.

[h1] The good [/h1]
- Over hundred songs to play (including unlockable ones), they are fully keysounded, so it feels like you are the one playing the music.
- 4k, 5k, 6k, 8k modes, modifiers to make the gameplay harder. Although I do not recommend sticking to 5k if you are used to 6k, it is confusing.
- MISSION MODE - tons of quests to complete, but it is more challenging.
- AIR MODE - lets you play even the songs you do not own, but you must get very lucky, because it is randomized.
- ONLINE - play with other players in Open Match, or compete and climb the ranks in Competitive Mode.

[h1] The bad [/h1]
- Some songs have a huge difficulty spike, but honestly, aren't we all used to that by now?
- If you really want to play ONLINE Open Match with other players, you most likely will not find many people to play with you, because you probably bought just the game alone without any DLCs. You cannot play DLC songs in Open Match, even if the room master has them. You also must have them in order to be able to play.
- The game only runs online, therefore, if your internet happens to have technical difficulties, you will not be able to play the game at all.
- As I mentioned above, this game has tons of DLCs. If you are trying out the game, do not buy the DLCs yet. Do some research if the songs and the stuff contained in the DLC are really that neccessary to get.

[h1] Final verdict [/h1]
Worth it, including the DLCs (??? if you want more songs in the game I guess). It plays well. There is really not much to dislike about this game, it feels good to play. I don't regret this buy. Plus the 65% OFF the original price during the summer sale is a SMASH!

DJMax is a Korean button based rhythm game, for those who are uninformed. I had no nostalgic or general ties with this game before buying DJMax Respect, so I came in completely blind.
For reference, I am an active percussionist, and work with music quite often. As such, I have dabbled in other rhythm-based games, like Guitar Hero, Muse Dash, and Groove Coaster.
This is one of the more popular rhythm games in the entirety of Steam, so I decided to give it a shot. This is mainly a review for those who have little to no idea about rhythm games.

PROS: 
-A metric ton of starting music. Seriously this game has a lot of music without DLC, add that in and you got a decent bit to go by.
-Lots of genres. There is most likely one song that will ring with someone, and honestly, trying them all out is a good way to find something you might like. Personally, I love the Guilty Gear collaboration which came in for free.
-Highly Customizable. This is the one that I think DJMax is the best at. There are lots of options to change your controls, and customize where you want your board, what you want your board to look like, what you want your notes to look like, and many other things to make it your perfect style.
-Variable Difficulty. Not everyone is a musician or rhythm gaming genius, so DJMax has a good bit of easier songs, and a difficulty star system to let you know what you are getting yourself into. Besides that, if you ARE looking for difficulty, every song has a 5 button, 6 button, and 8 button layout option, combined with different difficulties for everything. Personally, I hover around the 8 to 10 star range with 4 button or 6 button layouts, but at first I was WAY worse at this game. The missions help to slowly guide you into mastering the game little by little, and even though I was very against 6 or 8 buttons at the beginning, I slowly began to dive deeper in difficulty. It pleases everyone.

NEUTRAL:
One thing to note, since this is a Korean based game, a majority of the community is Korean, so just keep that in mind when you start playing.
Also, there are a few mainstream songs by Porter Robinson, Marshmello, and other big names, but the majority of these songs are either very underground, or made specifically for this game. Also some songs are SUPER weird, and (in my subjective opinion) are not very good. Looking at you Kung Brother. But I suppose that's due to the fact that many of these artists are experimental AKA not mainstream artists, which do bring some really cool and unique ideas to the table, for sure.

CONS: 
-Expensive. Seriously, add all the DLC together in this game, you are looking in the HUNDREDS. Outside of the default songs and the V Expansion bundle, every single expansion costs additional money, and can run you $20 each. Compare this to Muse Dash, which, after one DLC purchase, you never have to worry about buying DLC again. And there's a LOT of these DLCs for DJMax, and are borderline locked away unless you shell out some cash. Buy the DJMax Respect V Complete Edition when it's on sale, and you already have a ton of songs there, but still is important to note, as these DLC rarely go on much of a sale at all, and are locked away for those who don't want to pay.
-No practice mode. You pretty much never get a chance to practice these songs unless you play on AIR mode (which selects songs for you). This is a HUGE killer to me, because maybe there's a specific part of a song I want to practice, but it's just blocked off aside from actual play. I'm seeing people rectify this with the fact that almost all the songs are only 2 minutes, but that's still something I find annoying.
-Little competition for my skill. This is a bit of a me only thing, but a good 30% of these songs are impossible for me to even play, and a high majority of the community when I go into online mode are playing it like a practiced Moonlight Sonata. It's hard for me to find people at my skill level to play with, which kinda sucks, because then it's mostly just solo play, and the competitive mode is too hard for me to even attempt a competition against someone.

SUMMARY: It's one of my favorite rhythm games, but isn't without it's caveats. The price may sway some people, so I would recommend buying it on a sale if you are interested. Has lots of cool and great songs only available through the game, but is very difficult if you want to try to really challenge yourself. 

8/10. Make DLC either a little cheaper, or more accessible, and it's golden

This game is a mixed bag and amazing for dj max and rhythm game fans but may be hard to get into if your new to rhythm games or PC game troubleshooting.
Pros:
-This game and its DLC go on sale often. Definitely pick it up on sale if you like rhythm games. 
-The DLCs add songs from previous DJ max games as well as other rhythm games. They also include their own mission packs and unlockable cosmetics.
-lots of optional collectibles including note shapes, play area designs, profile icons, comments, profile art panels, etc
-most unlockables can be obtained through playing songs in freeplay and season passes but some can come from unlocking achievements, clearing missions in mission mode, online versus mode, etc. So you definitely get rewarded for exploring the options.
-game has a fair amount of songs and if you get DLCs there are SO MANY songs from various genres. A couple DLCs also come in bundles to get them together cheaper, such as the dj max technika 1-3 DLCs.

Cons:
-In order for this game to be playable I had to troubleshoot and find that going to the source files, right clicking the .exe file and finding the run as administrator checkbox and checking it removes an annoying reoccurring random few seconds of lag spikes issue.
-other than achievement hunting air mode seems arbitrary. You just pick from a rotating list of songs and if you want you can throw the game into autoplay and leave comments with other users. It's the mode that pops up first on the menu and is the least relevant.
- most achievments are vague and you wont get most of them without reading the achievement list first and many of them are locked behind DLCs. This is a con in my opinion but I could see achievement hunters finding this fun and getting rare achievements because of it.

Enter Ranked, Jump to Silver I immediately from unranked, feeling good. Queue for a match, get absolutely destroyed by someone high leveled, immediately demoted to Silver II. 10/10 game, would carpal tunnel again.

FOR NEWCOMERS: There is a reason why its called "Respect". This PC version of the original PS4 version of Respect equally expects its players to know what is going on. All of the collective knowledge from previous DJMax games are compiled in this one singular game. Again, this game is MADE FOR FANS. I HIGHLY suggest that you play the tutorial, and start with 4B Easy mode, and work your way up. I also highly suggest you play with a PS4 controller/Keyboard (Whichever you prefer.), as Respect and DJMax, as a whole, was made with the PlayStation button set in mind.

As someone who played the original DJMax from its infancy (Yes, both the first PSP edition and the first PC version, and no, not Trilogy.) I can say that DJMax Respect/V is a warm hug back again to the PC. 

I will be honest, I did not see Respect heading for a PC port, but I was pleasantly surprised when it did. A lot of the PS4 version components and aspects of the game were carried on to this version, and I am very pleased to see it. However, there are things that NEOWIZ added in this version of Respect. Right off the bat, I noticed that Arcade Mode was replaced by Air Mode. Arcade Mode has been, and always been, the staple of DJMax games. Air Mode feels like said mode, but radio style; you don't know what song you're getting next.

And now the tracks themselves. It's very pleasant that they still let you start with some songs from Respect, PC/Portable1 and Portable2. However, its a nice surprise to see NEOWIZ add in new songs from artists such as Marshmello, Porter Robinson (Both Worlds and Virtual Self tracks, but not Nurture :((( ) and K/DA.

DJMax Respect is very lax in terms of timing judgement. In prior DJMax games (namely, the PSP ones) timing judgement is very strict and to the letter. Respect/V, fortunately, is still very lax in terms of timing, but you can always change the timing offset in the settings, should you choose to challenge yourself. 

The new difficulty they added, Difficulty SC, are for those who are proficient with the keyboard (I'm looking at you Trilogy players). Its a very challenging mode in itself, and I'm very glad NEOWIZ added this, as its very much a callback to both DJMax PC and Trilogy.

The DLC as well are present. What struck me however, is that most if not all the PS4 version DLCs are much more cheaper on this port when its on sale. If you have not yet bought any DLC from the PS4 version, and you decide to get this port, I highly suggest you buy those here. You wouldn't want to pay 20 bucks for content that never goes on sale, do you?

Now let's talk about Online Mode. Oh god, YES. This is what they did so right. In the PS4 version, if you don't have PS Plus, you basically get cucked. You don't get to play online matches. Nothing more, nothing less. However, Respect/V allows you to freely play two modes; the classic 1V1 ladder match and Party/Group play. What's very great about Respect/V Online is that it never runs out of online players (Respect Online is a friggin desert my dude, don't even try). Ladder Matches is a very great addition to the Online mode, as it is incentive and motivation for players to keep playing.

All in all, I think that this version of Respect is really well done. Its a shame however that some of the modes from the PS4 version were cut and nowhere to be seen. But we have to do what we are given. Respect/V continues the theme of paying respect to both the players and creators by simply including an entire demographic of players who are and were familiar to one of its past games' mechanics. 

Lastly, DJMax is still very much, a niche title in the west in terms of the rhythm game community, but is very well-known in the Asian demographic of players. If you are reading this, and you live in the west, share this game's existence!

Keep on pressing folks. Press X (or Space!) to pay RESPECT.

UPDATE (7-6-21):  I'm switching to "Recommend" for now.  The game has a ton of songs and if you don't have any de-syncing issues with the audio, it's a great time and worth the money.  There's an option for "Audio Buffer Size" in the main game settings and if you set it to "Large" or even "Medium" I found that it'll mitigate any audio de-syncing issues you may run into.

------------------------------------

OLD: I've sunken tons of hours into this game and I thought it was a blast.  I'm sorry, this is an otherwise very fun game with a ton of songs (even if you don't purchase any of the DLC, though I would recommend it if you get this game), but in the most recent patches of the game, the game constantly has audio de-syncing issues during gameplay where the background music "stutters".  It doesn't seem to matter what settings I use in game or for my GPU or computer.  It always seems to de-sync the background music which makes this game virtually unplayable.

Unless I'm missing some setting to check or uncheck to fix the audio de-sync issues, I could not recommend this game right now.  I will edit my review once I see there's some sort of fix or if someone helps me understand how to fix this issue.

I don't think this one ended up being for me. Really like rhythm games but a relatively new player in actually getting down to play nowadays. This game is really built on punishing. If you fail you completely restart, and with no ability to slow down BPM for practice i'm not sure i'll be sticking around. A lot are speaking on it being made for fans, that's cool. Really wish it was new player friendly, compare this to something like Rocksmith (And technically harder) which actually builds up difficulty from bottom up, compare it to OSU which gives you the ability to slow things down. If you're argument for it's difficulty is it's made for fans, then you risk alienating an entire group of people who'd love to be passionate about this game. It's pretty, animation is consistently spectacular, music is great (the RnB threw me off, there's a lot of that in this), but it doesn't appear they want newbies. Great deal of frustration in that, why gatekeep? Anyways recommended if you're an experienced player, it's clearly built with that audience in mind. Not recommending so much for newbies.

DJMAX Respect has very quickly become my favorite rhythm game on PC. There really isn't much to say, it has great songs, well-made charts, a lot of variety in music & unlockables, and a ton of consistency. HOWEVER. You probably already know about this game's TERRIBLE DRM. It's always online, and it scans for modified files while the game is running to make sure you're not tampering with the game. And due to the DRM, if you plan on playing this via Wine on Linux or Macos, it's not gonna happen. This is purely Windows ONLY, no matter how much fiddling around I've done to try to make it work with Wine. However, it does run well under a virtual machine, so long as your computer can handle one.
It really breaks my heart on how locked down this game is, because I love every second of playing this game. It's a real, genuine pleasure. But Neowiz won't be budging any time soon on making the DRM any less extreme, so if you're on Linux or Macos, or if you just don't like companies treating their genuine customers like serial criminals with excessive DRM, maybe skip this game and play DJMAX Trilogy on Wine instead. But otherwise, you're in for a real treat if you can play this game.

[b](This only applies around the time it was written, since I'm probably too lazy to update it anytime in the future :/ )[/b]
[spoiler][strike]ÊàëÁî®‰∏≠ÊñáÂØ´ÊòØ‰∏çÊòØÈÇÑÊØîËºÉÂ§ö‰∫∫Áúã= =/Might be missing the main audience by having this written in English, whatever[/strike][/spoiler]
For anyone who doesn't know it's a.... Well, [i]kinda inaccurate[/i] port of the original PS4 game and the main point of this review is comparing the functionality of both.
If you don't even know what DJMAX is go seek some help from Wikipedia and YouTube before reading this.

[h1]PROS[spoiler]?[/spoiler][/h1]
1. Brand new SC (short for SuperCrazy) difficulty exclusive on PC
However not every song comes with it, besides that even songs with it don't have it in every mode, for example if you're not confident with your ring fingers and play on 4B forever, you're only gonna find a quarter of the songlist having their SC chart available.
Also keep in mind that as everything other than SC was initially designed for PS4 controller and remains completely unchanged here, they are sorta.... dull to play with a keyboard, so you might end up having even less "desirable" charts here than you do on PS4.
2. Could be much cheaper depending on your region
3. Online mode for up to 7 players together instead of 2 on PS4
Plus being on Steam makes it way easier to socialize with your online friends.
4. A ranked mode for competitive play
Although it gets frustrating real quick unless you're one of those super try-hard players and have no problem getting a 99.80% or something.
5. 5 exclusive songs including 2 League of Legends collab songs.
Something I'd rather not have; All of them are full songs a.k.a. long af, along with terribly made charts.
[spoiler]I for one hate them to the point that every time I see them it feels like they're polluting my songlist[/spoiler]

[h1]CONS[/h1]
1. [b]Bugs, glitches and all kinds of performance issues[/b] inevitable at this point
I'm 100% sure it's not my computer's fault as it runs most major titles smoothly, but when it comes to this game it can even freeze frequently at the song select screen.
Also I don't know if it's a China-only issue but I randomly fail to sync savedata like every 10 minutes.
2. It's gonna take at least several months to get back all the previous DLCs that already exist in the PS4 version, which means there're like 150 additional songs missing currently
3. Local 2-player mode got removed so you can't chill with your roommate/boyfriend/girlfriend
4. 8B mode feels super counter-intuitive and agonizing on keyboard
Still you can plug a controller and use that anyway, but since SC is impossible to do with controller that's literally the same experience as PS4 plus all the bugs.
5. A renovated mission mode where all the 10B charts got yeeted

[h1]TL; DR[/h1]
Only consider this over the original if you
A) don't own a PS4‚Ñ¢
B) value your online friends more than friends irl
C) have trouble playing this with a controller
D) are a desperate series fan like me so you're gonna buy it anyway

Easily the most polished rhythm game on PC. There's a LOT of content to this game, and unlike certain community-created rhythm games, (not naming names, but... you know,) all of that content is high-quality and accessible to all levels of skill. While the game is a bit steep in terms of price, especially considering DLC, it's absolutely worth the money considering how well-crafted this game is. I will say, the game's tracklist can be a bit odd; there's a weird abundance of songs that don't really feel like "rhythm game" songs. (There's Bossa Nova and Disco in here, for whatever reason. I'm not complaining, it's good for variety, just... I need to push buttons FAST.) That said, the tracklist is also pretty massive, and there are some fantastic songs in there.
It's a little annoying that the online ranked mode doesn't seem to be... populated? The placement matches pair you up with players that are obvious bots, and considering you need to do 5 placement matches to get a rank, it can get a bit annoying. Even after placement, I had trouble actually getting a match. Still, this is a rhythm game, the online modes are a bit secondary, so it's not a huge gripe.
Audio/video lag can be an issue: even with the audio buffer at minimum, the time between a keystroke and the keysound is about 90ms. This isn't too much of an issue, considering that most songs are keysounded; your brain can pretty easily adjust for the delay. However, a good few songs aren't keysounded, including entire DLC packs, which makes the delay a lot more apparent if you're using the sound of your keystrokes as a guide. It's annoying having to remember which songs aren't keysounded, then having to go to the settings and manually adjust offset every time you want to play one without noticeable input lag.
All of that said, these are just gripes. It's pretty easy to nitpick when everything else about the experience is just sort of perfect.

This review comes from someone who played other rhythm games like IIDX, BMS, K-Shoot Mania, Stepmania (DDR), Beat Saber, osu! and its modes, etc.

Part I: Addressing the issues

Before I actually review the game, I want to address an issue with the review bombing that this game had to go through. Please, hear me out before forgetting about this game due to these negative reviews. The situation is different from how it might look at first glance. Yes, the price went down after release, but it happened for a reason. There is a difference between Early Access and Released title pricing. When the game got released, the pricing got recalculated for different countries/regions. Moreover, Neowiz has already stated that they will fully compensate everyone who bought the game before the release.

Now, another issue is about XIGNCODE3. It is an anti-cheat that this game is using, and a bunch of paranoid people is hating on it because it scans your system. Please, do your research after which you'll realize that a lot of anti-cheats work in a similar way. The developers of XIGNCODE3 are clear about how their anti-cheat works, and there's nothing spyware-like in it. Now when we got this out of the way, I can finally talk about the game itself, and oh boy it is a good fucking game.

Part II: The positive aspects

The game is really underrated. Maybe it is because of the negative reviews. Maybe because it is expensive. But in my opinion, the game is worth its money as it is one of the best (if not the best) VSRG(s) out there. Here's why.

Let me start with the most important - the music. It is really good. You have a variety of different genres, and all these tracks have their individual feel. There're high chances that a person playing this game will find the music they love there. I actually listen to DJMax OST in Spotify. Most of the songs are made especially for this game, and all the notes are key sounded (meaning each note has its own sound and you actually make the music while you play it). Maps are also really well made and it is a pleasure to play through them. You actually feel the rhythm there (a lot of popular games fail at this like osu! or Beat Saber which lack this feeling).

The design. I am speechless there. Like seriously, big thanks to the design team. This game is visually pleasing, the design is so good. The space theme for the online part of the game. The graveyard for old games. All the different themes for each mode (4B, 5B, 6B, 8B). Everything. And don't say that the design (or graphics) isn't an important part. It fucking is.

The quality. Everything feels premium. It is a pleasure playing the game that is so well-made in terms of quality. Developers actually tried hard making a game good in all aspects. Having different cover for each difficulty of a song and other little aspects like this one really make the game good.

The content. I have never thought that collectibles are something you want in a rhythm game but I actually love how each song has its own plot, characters, and MV. It makes the game alive and enjoyable even when playing solo.

Part III: The negative aspects

Online. As I said, this game is quite underrated and it doesn't have millions of players playing. You will face bots in ladders when there aren't enough players. Though don't get me wrong here. The game is not dead.

Issues. I personally faced an issue where the game is literally unplayable when you first start it. All the animations, videos and the gameplay itself were stuttering. The game is supposed to run in Fast VSync mode but I had to enable it manually in NVIDIA Control Panel to fix that stuttering. This is not normal for a game with such a price tag and is the worst part of the game. Another issue I faced is that the game lacks local multiplayer though the UI literally implies that there should be such an option (and PS4 edition has it).

Song choice. I have played a bit of DJMax Trilogy (the game is really weird btw and lacks lots of things like brightness control, BPM information and so on, but yeah, it is the game from 2008) and realized that a lot of tracks in DJMax Respect V were borrowed from previous games. I will be honest, I don't know how much is actually borrowed and how many songs are new, but this is something I didn't really like and felt like pointing out (though it's not a problem for people who haven't played previous games). You have to pay quite a lot for the DLCs which is a minus on its own and when you pay so much for them you expect to get OG new content~

Part IV: TL;DR

This is the best VSRG game I've ever played (among non-arcade rhythm games!) though it definitely has its problems. I hope this game gets more attention and developers will continue supporting it and listening to the community. In the future I will make an update to this review stating if the game support is decent

Part V: Support of the game
I don't really want to spend time on this part, but I think that enough time has passed to actually make an update. Summarizing:
1. Problems I mentioned were not fixed. Sadly, they all still remain in the game and you are the one who needs to fix them
2. Online is still bad, but did not get worse
3. Game is still getting support which is good and that's why I'm not gonna switch the review to negative. Still, it is sad to acknowledge that this game went the paid DLCs way. I still think the game is one of the best in non-arcade VSRG market, but it is way too pricey. Developers definitely love money and do everything to keep the money flow high. Buy the game and the DLCs only when the sale is up

As a fan of DJ MAX from the Portable era, this is a definitive nod to the franchise's own legacy and how much itself has evolved. This is a must buy for any Rhythm Game fans, although the price might deter that for most.

READ BEFORE BUYING: 
If you're a full time linux user, the game is borked, since it's running XIGNCODE3, which is a common anticheat in which most games that run it become unplayable there. Since the game runs that anticheat you'll most likely stumble upon a black screen and that's pretty much it.

Check ProtonDB for details: 
https://www.protondb.com/app/960170

Respect V is an expanded yet definitive port of the PS4 game, bringing back the franchise to PC after the shut down of Trilogy and Online. This game is a compilation of tracks, bringing a major library of songs from each part of the franchise but also bringing new and fresh tracks to the table. The game at the moment has songs from Portable 1-3, to trilogy to literally all three Technika games, but along with Respect's own list of songs plus collaboration with other games and certain and labels. As of May 2021, we now have almost the majority of the franchise even though we're missing a few songs from DJMO, and a few event songs from the Technika series. This brings a total of 400+ songs if you have all the DLC.

As mentioned the game is a port, but it brings a lot of new gameplay features sacrificing a few small things from the PS4 version. The game now brings SC patterns, SC patterns are charts that are designed for keyboard, basically movements that can't be done on a controller. Easy to Maximum dificulties remain the same or have changes, but they can be played really well on a controller regardless. Meanwhile, Arcade mode is replaced with AIR. AIR Mode is a game mode designed to be played endlessly yet receiving rewards by playing songs that are in rotation through three different channels. Each channel has songs with different dificulties, and all of the songs are available including DLC tracks through this mode. This game also has Ladder Match which is basically your ordinary ranked mode but other than all of that there's nothing else new other than also getting a battle pass.

In overall gameplay it plays a like a Mania, you have playstyles from 4,5, 6 to 8 buttons having separate and different patterns between eachother. Only downside is that 8 button play doesn't feel like it since you're playing around with a Side Track styled system while having Side Track in 8 button anyways. EZ2ON has real 8 button play, and even though the judgement window on EZ2ON is more strict it feels more rewarding than 8 Button DJMax. 

The game doesn't really feel rewarding, it feels more forgiving and relaxed than other games. The judgement window feels smooth and peaceful, leaving you with better accuracy and scores in comparison to other games. This game can be really easy to get Perfect Plays once you get really good, but in comparison to others, expect your accuracy to be from 99% to just 95% or lower (little joke, but you'll realize it the more you get better in the genre). But overall the game play is solid. I forgot to mention the game has auto fever in comparison to all the other DJMax titles, you don't need to press any other button to fever since it does it on its own for better combo and scores. 

Downsides and personal complaints:
The game has hitsounds to the brim, until you get to see songs like Alone, songs from League of Legends, and even a lot of the collaboration songs excluding Cytus and Deemo don't have any hitsounds. The lack of hitsounds ruin the purpose of the game, where a lot of the instrumentals used to feel natural by hearing the inputted sounds rather than having no noise. Hit sounds in this game feels less natural than EZ2ON's system. While a lot of the songs and missions have hitsounds, one thing I noticed is how long notes don't have sounds, leaving half of the songs not fully coded with those hit sounds. 

The game is online only, and lacks local multiplayer features. The PS4 version is offline and has local multiplayer, but the PC version is completely strict and has an anticheat leading to a straight up Online Only DRM. This DRM is really strong, preventing macros and modifications into the gamefiles and it's really annoying since you're going to need consistent connections to play the game and save your scores. Your account is completely tied to another account leading to save files being server sided and all of your DLC's are also server sided. 

Family Sharing is no longer permitted. The game no longer allows family sharing due to two hackers dealing with Ladder Match and ruining the fun for players who play the game borrowed in the first place. At first it felt okay restricting DLC sharing but then they decided to restrict the game share leaving a lot of players having to buy their own copy anyway. 

Battle pass system is a nightmare. While it sounds ideal to pay for a battle pass to unlock seasonal content into the game, the leveling in between tiers have become worse. It can take you more than 15-17 songs to reach to a certain tier, and the easiest way to level really fast is through Ladder Matches. Now what's so bad about the leveling is that you usually earn 1k per ladder match, now the experience has been drastically reduced and it's now much lower if you don't have the pass. Owning the pass for a small boost is a joke, you barely get an amount for owning it as a bonus and the only good thing about the pass is that if you don't own DLC, and other players do through Open Match, you can play their songs for free. Speaking of that, it's now technically a paywall when the PS4 version had that for free, and the PC port is also restricted from that. You get a lot of fun little cosmetics, but I think the battle pass system is a complete chore due to the fact that its ridiculous on how much you have to grind for it. This whole system is a joke, and even if you love the game a lot you can always blame other companies for going through this route to cash out. 

Other than that, the game is really fun and well done. Sadly, the game is a major investment in which if you're a veteran or a newcomer, you're better off getting it on a sale. This game is stupid expensive, and I personally prefer having to buy all the major songpacks rather than also getting collaboration packs. It's an amazing game for newcomers to the Mania genre, and it's definitely worth picking up despite a lot of its flaws. I personally bought this game without having any knowledge or skill for Mania games, but after a few years even if I'm not that amazing it's good to keep on playing. 

As for the PS4 version, while they're supporting both games all I know is that it's slowly being ruined. I don't know any other details but from how badly managed the PC port is slowly becoming, its slowly getting bad on the PS4 version as well. I'm not saying both games are bad, but the way they're managing the game is slowly getting messed up.

EDIT: There's been an overhaul of the multiplayer and unlock progression of this game, which I'll talk about at the end.

This is an accuracy-focused VSRG (vertical scrolling rhythm game), but a good entry to start with for beginners; the timing windows are somewhat forgiving for this breed of rhythm game. There's four button modes (for most songs), so you can start with whichever mode is most comfortable for you, with the keyboard controls being freely configurable. If you're coming to this from IIDX/SDVX, most of this game should come naturally while going for full combos and perfect plays but there's still plenty of challenging note charts despite the forgiving entry level. Various rhythm game controllers also work with DJMAX.

The music is mostly Korean house, R&B, and light K-pop, but there are also several worthwhile licensed tracks, trance/techno/DnB based songs, and some J-pop. This installment draws it track list from various games across the series and they're still (as of March '21) releasing song packs for the game. If you want all the music DLC, the bundles are a better deal overall.

NEW STUFF BELOW:

At launch, the game had two multiplayer modes: a perfectly adequate lobby mode where the host would pick a song for up to six other players to casually play through and a bare-bones ladder system that almost no one played except the top 10-to-15% of players. The season pass update actually provides REWARDS for playing the game in general, but the revised multiplayer ladder awards the most progress towards unlocking them.

The new ladder rankings are a function of rewarding skill and adaptability. The lower brackets only require you to opt into one button mode; you will run into a lot of 4B and 6B-only players in the beginning. But the higher you go, the more button modes you have to have enabled to advance into higher brackets. Consequently, the best of the best can play all of them. Expect a lot of close matches in the vein of DDR.

The material rewards for simply playing, whether you get thrashed in PVP or not, are more unlockable items such as UI frames, menu themes, players titles/icons, banners, and lobby emotes (a new feature). (I'm marking it not recommend for the DRM and that it may be seen more - wait until it's onsale and beware of what is pointed out)   What I can say about the game so far is that it's nothing like Technika's controls, I knew that coming in having asked the community. Even buying the Technika pack doesn't change that but there is a mission where they emulate it I was told. 

The difficulty seems way high - this might not be a problem. A song older song I knew has a rating that is moderate but I thought I knew it and could do it.  NOPE!  Again, I'm not saying this is bad, just be aware, you, may need to start at the lower difficulties and work your way up as well as if you knew songs with a different control scheme, you probably don't know them as well as you think now that they are redone. 

Also, this game highly more GPU intensive than you'd think.  It's just video (which you can turn off) under a simple interface of a rhythm game right?   Yes, but no. I was hoping this would run on my HP Elitebook that only has Intel integrated graphics but no, it pegs the GPU and has obvious pacing issues which is crucial in any game but certainly these.

The Clear Pass isn't a great idea and is grindalicious, there's an absolute mass of DLC, but this is still one of the most solid rhythm game experiences you can play. In terms of the DLCs, avoid anything that says "Gear Pack" unless you really want more cosmetics and you're golden in terms of getting only the essentials. It'll still be super goddamn expensive if you want them all at once but keep in mind that my current song count is 412. You don't need all the DLC at once, at most the best place to start is the Deluxe or Complete Edition due to it including the Emotional Sense DLC and the V Extension which is a decently sized addition to the game. I know I haven't talked much about the actual game but there's not much to say about it, it's a high-quality rhythm game with tons of songs and multiple beatmaps including ones that use more keys (4/5/6/8). Even someone with DJMax Respect on PS4 might want this due to the SC difficulty, which is exclusive and designed for keyboard use. This is the first time in years DJMax has been on the PC again and don't let the price tag scare you off.

I am a shameless double-dipper for this game; I've been playing this series since the PSP and picked up eeeeeeeverything for the original PS4 version and yeah, my wallet is crazy light because of it.  But I've put in countless hours in this game and have fallen in love with most of its songs, even the crazy weird ones (of which there are many).

For anyone wondering what the difference is between this and the PS4 version, the big change is the inclusion of "SC" charts for most songs which are designed for keyboard play. 
 As this was originally a console release, most charts are built for controllers or in other words, using your thumbs; SC changes all that.  Otherwise, arcade mode has been replaced with Air mode, which is basically playing a roulette of tracks while people spam messages all over the screen (but not the chart, so don't worry) and while you can unlock some stuff here, your performance doesn't carry over to freestyle.  Freestyle is pretty much the same as are the missions and unlockables.  Online modes include open match where it's just casual play, and a ladder system which is emphasizes accuracy over combos, but don't come into it with this as your goal - matches are few and far between if you're not on the South Korean clock and you'll be competing on MX tracks faster than you think (still fun, but you really gotta be on top of it).

The huge difference, though, is I find the PC version to be much less forgiving.  My first plays were a bit of a challenge as I was barely scratching A ranks on songs I easily put an S on in the PS4.  However, while I initially struggled, I've now charted S ranks across the board and even managed to max combo songs I never could before.  I've always said the genius of this game's charts is in how well it trains you to just zone out and run on autopilot and my opinion hasn't changed.

That said, for everyone looking to play this game with a controller, do yourself a huge favor and get one with a fantastic d-pad (in other words, NOT an Xbox 360 or One controller... omg it's so bad I had to unplug it and hook up a DS4).  Otherwise, for PS4 vets, you can now play with keyboards and that means, if you care to, you can engineer yourself a custom pad for this if you are so daring.

Overall, you're getting one of the best rhythm games out there and one of the OG pioneers of the genre.  Yeah, it can get quite expensive and you are indeed buying a lot of old content, but if you stick it out and pick up the song packs on sale, you will have one of the largest and most varied archive of songs from DJMAX's entire history.  I mean, I begged for a very long time for them to put Feel in here and I finally got it, so if a favorite of yours is missing, it will probably show up sooner or later.

DJMax is a rhythm game has great charts and music. However, without any real calibration options or even early/late error margin display at this time, it makes it almost impossible to play this properly for accuracy/score. If you're at least somewhat serious, you'll be spending a lot of time being frustrated at trying to get the offset correct. It feels like a constant fight of "Am I playing badly or is offset not right?".

I read that they were planning on adding calibration, but this game has been on PC for quite some time now. It's really strange how such a key rhythm game feature wasn't included on release and hasn't been patched in yet.

If you have it, I say stick to the not-as-up-to-date PS4 version for the time being as at least it has some form of calibration on there, even if it's bare minimum.

If proper calibration was added, I'd instantly switch to recommended. Especially if they get early/late display added back in again from original PS4 release, but it sounds like there's some weird patent or legal issue going on with that feature.

If you are willing to fight with getting the offset correct, then go ahead and buy it.

There's something in this package for every rhythm game enthusiast to enjoy.

Hands down the best rhythm game currently available on Steam. Hundreds of tracks, most keysounded, usually with 12+ individual patterns to play. Absolutely INCREDIBLE music. Coming from IIDX which had lots of awesome rave/trance music, I was expecting to be disappointed with DJMAX Respect's soundtrack. But after buying the game for PS4 on a whim, I found myself falling love with the different tracks in the game - going as far as to essentially purchase it again on Steam so I can play on a proper controller. This game is a love letter, remaster, and so much more of over a decade's worth of amazing rhythm game music, and is steadily growing with the regular content updates. I should also note that I suck at rhythm games - I only ever got to 3rd dan in IIDX and typically peak at medium difficulty - but there's lots of content for beginner-level players that will keep you busy for a long time and help you constantly improve. The achievement, unlock and customisation system is also fantastic and provides lots of targets to shoot for that keep you playing.
Because I use win7 for some old programs, I did have some issues with the BGA codec introducing lag - however updates were released that addressed this bug and I was able to play the game again (I have started learning the game all over on a new layout which is super fun!). Thoroughly impressed.

Addition of Clear Pass made me write this review.
Firstly, It's a marvelous game. The best music game on PC. The gameplay is absolutely perfect. Nothing more to add. It's just the best in terms of gameplay.
However outside of the gameplay there are a lot of problems:
CLEAR PASS!
This is unacceptable. I do not tolerate this system in a game that costs this much. Blocking content behind clear pass is absolutely disgusting and just the sheer idea  of this has destroyed this game for me.
ANTI-CHEAT
This has been from the beginning but it's a cancer that is there and will always be. It's like that really stupid cousin that your mom told you to play with.
ALWAYS-ONLINE
One day NEOWIZ will close the servers and you and I will not own this game anymore. Once more, the idea that something is not really my own destroys the pleasure of gameplay I would get.


So, yeah. It's not like I don't recommend this game. The gameplay is fantastic but the problems I adressed are so big that only thinking about them destroys fun for me.
NEOWIZ made a big mistake adding the CLEAR PASS to the game and like many other fans of DJMAX series I want them to know that it's a terrible idea that destroys their almost perfect game.
You want perfect music/rhythm game? Get DjMAX Respect V. But you'll also get all the problems listed above with it. Beware!

I'd like to start this review by saying this:

DJMAX RESPECT V (this game) is a PC port of the original DJMAX RESPECT on the PS4. It is a keyboard rhythm game in which you hit notes to music. The PC and PS4 versions are 2 separate games. The PS4 version is designed for a PS4 controller, while the PC version includes all PS4 charts plus hundreds of SC patterns that are specifically for keyboard. 

DJMAX RESPECT V has a few licensed songs from Marshmello, Porter Robinson, and League of Legends, 7 player online mode, and air mode.

DJMAX RESPECT PS4 has arcade mode, 1v1 online and you both have to have PS+, local multiplayer, offline play.

Now that's out of the way and there is no confusion, let's start with this review. I played PS4 DJMAX since June of 2018 and put an absurd amount of hours into it because I loved it. Once I found out it would be getting a port to PC I was incredibly excited. Early Access was a little rough, and the music sync and scoring issues were really bad, but most of that has been fixed now. You can play at 240 fps, which is really nice. Although it's just a port of the old game but with added patterns for keyboard it became even more fun. It's got a great selection of songs I listen to at work or in the car too. After I first showed my friends this game, they all wanted to play it too.

Here are some features of the game that might help your decision in buying it:

Around 175 great songs in the base game (almost 400 if you buy all of the DLC) at the time of writing this.
4 button modes to choose from: 4B, 5B, 6B, and 8B.
Thousands of patterns to play so you never get bored.
A range of difficulties from the super noob to the ultra expert.
Leaderboards if you care about being the best.
Tons of missions with specific requirements to pass.
A collection mode that keeps track of all your stats and includes gallery images of concept art and songs and Music Videos for every song.

THIS GAME GOES ON SALE A LOT! If you are worried about the price tag (which is a lot for a rhythm game), don't worry. The game and all of its DLC usually go on sale during new DLC releases, which is usually 3-4 months. You can expect the price to drop over 50%, which is definitely worth your money. If you really enjoyed the base game I highly recommend the DLC such as V EXTENSION or BLACK SQUARE. Also, I have written a guide here: https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2362889860
It describes every unlock, gameplay tips, basic mechanics, and more.

Overall, this game is definitely worth getting once it goes on sale. Of course no game is perfect, but this one is a classic and hopefully becomes even more fun after more songs and DLC are released :)
DJMAX is the way and the truth and the life.

I've been playing music games for over 2 decades, it's so nice to have this on the PC, and the couple of tracks from mainstream EDM artists is an intriguing cherry on top.

It's surprising that this game has every era of DJMAX, (4, 5, 6, 8 button modes), also "keyboard specific" charts (SC difficulty), and also Technika mode, a touch-screen edition of the game through the 2010s. But it is a huge amount of content and has something worth playing if you're a fan of rhythm games, and/or the "classic" (DDR-esque) style of music game presentation with notes that flow to a target.

It's a good soundtrack, plenty to like here, especially if you've ever played and enjoyed any DJMAX game in the past, besides Technika, maybe, it just doesn't translate the same without touch. If you really liked that game and don't care about the classic 4/5/6/8 button style, the Technika experience is the weakest part of this bag. But it does exist.

The BEST iteration of the BEST RHYTHM GAME OF ALL TIME~!!

(at the time of this review the game is on sale, and you should probably BUY IT SOON)

 What makes DJ MAX the best Rhythm game ?

-a Clean user interface with sharp design and high resolution graphics
-Gameplay that is adaptable to all playstyles, encourages growth and doesn't punish creativity
-Arguably the best soundtrack for the amount of songs
-7-player LIVE multiplayer matches with the most supportive online community

 With an EXPANDING Library of nearly 400 Songs,
 What DLC should i Get??

a tip for DLC, if you're looking for 'specific songs' check those packs
on their description page to see if the tracks are listed.(a lot of songs have
been moved around). Keep in mind the "Gear" and "Note" Expansions are for cosmetics
only and DO NOT INCLUDE SONGS.

Expansion Pack bundles will save you a little bit more money, and usaully they are 
good/complementary pairings.

Here are my DLC Recommendations in order:
DJ MAX RESPECT V (Base Game)(you need this to play the game)
Clazziquai - the best expansion, VERY talented musicians included here
Black Square - this is the 2nd best expansion and can Be bundled with Clazziquai

Deemo - this is an expansion based on a Piano based rhythm game which has an amazing soundtrack
 including the BEST SONG IN THE GAME (don't believe me, look up 'magnolia' by M2U)

beyond those the next expansions i would recommend would be in this order:
Technika 3
Technika 2
V extension
Emotional Sense
Technika 1

 About the Technika Expansions, i was originally confused by this because these are 
'Touch-screen' games... well they simply took the tracks and made them as playable
charts on the game, which is Good cause now you can enjoy the songs in the familiar format
instead of the Gimmick that was the 'Touch-Arcade'

 if you have any questions just post, i will try to answer as many as i can! and if you're into
music games, go on and buy this game.

So so so, DJMAX Respect V...
Just a little disclaimer, I'm not the biggest rhythm game player and I only played a bit of Osu! and some android games on emulator, so I have no huge experience of other games of this kind, except for Love Live School Idol Festival on which I spent a few hundred hours.

To keep this short:
+ Really well made and fluid
+ Interface is brilliant, mixing colors and animated drawing, never saw a better UI
+ Until now I only played about 20 hours, but there seem to be a big difficulty curve and insanely difficult tracks that I can't touch without immediately failing (maybe because my keyboard is not adapted for rhythm games)
+ A great amount of musics with a level system making you unlock new ones (so please don't buy the DLC unless you are a hardcore fan wanting to support DJMAX)
+ Some really easy musics and a tutorial, so it seems really beginner-friendly

-/+ XINGCODE3, the anti-cheat engine which seems to cause problem with some people

- No offline mode, is for me the biggest downside. Why would you want a constant online mode if you're playing a rhythm game. I understand that it would be important for leaderboards and ranked matches, but aside from that, there really should be an offline mode available in which your progression would not be saved
- I understand the 4B and 6B layouts, but the other ones seem a bit off in my opinion, especially the 8B mode where the notes are displayed on a whole side of the track (3 left or right lines) instead of having a dedicated line. But it could be difficult to keep up if there were 8 lines, even though LLSIF had 9 (but easier note-layouts)
- Had to redownload the game completely after pausing an update

I'm quite satisfied by the game this far BUT can't recommend it because of the lack of offline mode. As stated in other reviews, if a sequel comes out in the future and the servers get taken down, the money you spend will be void.

Can't recommend the game in this state.
There is a substantial delay between hitting the notes and the sound they make.
For easier songs this isn't much of a problem, but once you ramp up the difficulty and have to hit a lot of notes in a short time frame, the audio becomes messed up and disorientating.

There is an in game setting for audio sync, but that only changes the timing of the notes appearing and doesn't fix the audio.

Underneath is an amazing game, but I can only recommend the PS4 version

Waited and bought this during the 65% Neowiz franchise sale because honestly its TOO expensive to own all the DLC.
I owned and played every DJMAX game prior to this including Tapsonic and the original MMOGs.
PSP/PSV era leaderboards were plagued with cheaters since everyone had cwcheat.

DJMAX Trilogy came with a stupid USB stick, but it eventually got cracked anyway, DRM is pointless but I agree theres a need for an anti cheat for all multiplayer games.

Review starts here
Cons
There seems to be about 60ms of input delay.
Obtaining all the content is extremely expensive outside of a steam sale.
Some of the best and most challenging songs are DLC like in the Black Square pack.
Collab DLC like Deemo are not hit sounded which is just lazy and unprofessional.

Pros
Satiates your nostalgia. Most charts are the same as what you would have played on DJMAX/Portable/Technika/Tapsonic
Has cute gears(game UI) and bonus artwork to look at.
Has weird collab events sometimes?

Final Opinion
If you don't play multiplayer, your biggest worry will be the high total cost of the game.
Visually and aurally, DJMAX is the most visually impressive vertical scrolling rhythm game franchise to exist.
The background videos all have of a higher standard of quality compared to its competitors.
Konami's background videos in Beatmania don't really come close to what Pentavision has done over the years in DJMAX
Also the notecharting in Respect is better than all the 4-8k maps that exist in Osu!Mania/Stepmania because Neowiz pays salaries to testers to playtest their stuff, but in online communities like Stepmania/Osu!/Beatsaber, charts can be ranked just because its a popular meme and can be complete garbage. 

Worth every cent!(only if its on a sale)
[Please wait for a sale]
[seriously please wait for a sale before buying this]

EDIT :
Since DJMax respect was originally released as a PS4 game, most of the old notecharts are designed to be cleared on a PS4 controller or on a Playstation Portable/Vita's button layout. Needing you to occasionally spin the left and right analog stick sometimes
There are some charts that are extremely difficult to play on a gamepad though, for example pressing the left and right arrow keys at the same time on a controller is usually impossible for most older controllers. 

Anti combo break equipment have been removed so getting the Lord of combo title may be more difficult if you choose songs too difficult for you in your run and get caught in a retry loop.
