You need to be online to play the game, even if you want to have fun in the single player modes. Everything is unbelievably expensive and a TON of content is locked behind DLCs. They didn't learn a single thing from Trilogy, the way NEOWIZ handles this game makes me believe they'll abandon it in a few years time and all the money you spent on DLC will go to waste due to the always-online policy.  There's a lack of polish in a few areas which is just not acceptable for a game this expensive (e.g. multiple skins from previous games are missing, desyncs and crashes are a thing, online rooms are clunky, no mouse support, ladder is dead, etc.)

As a DJMax veteran, it's sad to see they had a good product in hands but decided to ruin it with aggressive pricing and DRM that forces you to be online in order to access what you paid for.
It's a fun game to play casually or you can also play ranked if you feel like competing. Has several level of difficulties to learn and master.

There is no brightness setting for all songs, have to turn it down every time. More than 70% of the songs (including DLCs) are either awful to hear or have severe light pollution. It's not the arcade, delete those torturing missions and pointless extended ver. songs, especially that fking Airwire .

The base game is a bit pricey (as well as all the DLCs), but once you get pass "being poor" the game is extremely well made. The song selection is really good, there's something for everyone, and the timing/synchronization of notes are on point.

it's a pretty solid rhythm game, i like the ladder ranking and air mode where you can see other players comments is a nice touch.

the gameplay is customizable which is pretty good, there's a few different note skins and play area backgrounds. i would have liked there to have been an arrow skin but that's not the end of the world. It has a good selection of songs that all feel very well charted. the overall quality of the charts is very good, as you would expect from a game of this price.

it also has keysounding if that's your thing. i personally am not the biggest fan of keysounding but for those that like it it's there and very well done.

overall it's a pretty good game, would recommend picking it up on sale if you can, it regularly goes for around ¬£10

Great PC release of a longer running franchise I've played a long time on PSP, though admittedly PC controls take time getting used to.

Luckily the game supports using a DS4 or XBox controller, however the UI does not adept to this. Another noticeably absent thing is a "test" screen for the audio offset, so you'll have to free-ball it. Also, some songs actually miss what for me is one of the signature features of the DJ MAX games, namely the note playback (your buttons playing parts of the songs). This is fairly noticeable, and mostly happens on third-party//imported songs.

The base game includes some nice songs by itself, and other (and older) songs are available in [i] mostly [/i] prices that are worth it. The team adds more songs from time to time, some free, some under existing packs. So in general, if a song pack includes a few songs you like I'd recommend considering it.

Over all a nice new entry in the series, which I'm glad is (this time around) simply released on steam and easy to obtain (looking at you, DJ Max Trilogy). If you're into music games, I'm quite sure you won't be disappointed by DJ Max and it's songs.

UPDATE: Looks like developer updates have corrected the crashing issues and I can finally play without hindrance!

I'm so glad, because I have so much fun with this game. I even got myself an EZMAX Arcade Style Controller from Gamo2, which I heartily recommend. I was into Beatmania IIDX back when it was new, and this scratches that old craving. I don't like the idea of paying a subscription for IIDX nowadays, or puzzling my way through Japanese online purchasing websites in order to do it, so DJMax is where it's at for me.

PROS:
- Generous tracklist of about 150 tunes out of the box, with another added 200 or so as DLC. Wait for a Steam sale for the DLC, when the average cost-per-song dips below 50 cents each.
- Difficulty is very customizable, with 4-Key, 5-Key, 6-Key, and 8-Key modes, plus usually three or four charts of different difficulties (Normal, Hard, Max, and SC) within each mode. Your grade on each unique chart is saved separately. Unlike the PS4 version, you CAN sort the songlist by difficulty, so you don't have to search around for charts at your level.
- Keysounded, so you can definitely hear the difference when you're grooving and when you're not doing so well. (Although I hear that at least one DLC pack is not keysounded, so read the DLC reviews before you buy.)
- There is a timing adjustment option, but I find I don't need to adjust it with my rig. I do recommend using Microsoft drivers for your Realtek sound devices tho, because of audio lag issues with the Realtek drivers. The judgement is very lenient compared to most rhythm games, which I actually like... it makes you want to push for the harder charts.
- Lots of options for the way you want the notes and interface to look. Change how you want the background animation to show through the playing field, at what percentage transparency. Play with the field on the left, center, or right of the screen. Adjust the speed on the fly with a fairly high granularity (0.1).

CONS:
- No mode to slow down charts to study or practice them. Is that no longer a thing in these games?

-------------------------
INITIAL REVIEW:
Unfortunately what would be a great game is hampered by the fact that it frequently hangs and crashes. I tried it on three different gaming rigs on a wired fiber connection, and had the same issue on all. Whenever it tries to do the following things, it will hang or crash 20% of the time:

1) booting the game
2) loading a song
3) updating results at the end of a song (BTW: kiss that full-combo goodbye, it never happened)

I suspect that the problems may stem from issues related to the developer's insistence of "always online" DRM. Even if it's not, it's a terrible idea, when a significant portion of players have no interest in the online or competitive features of this game.

If you do buy the game, don't make the same mistake I did -- Don't suffer through restarts if your game hangs -- Steam will refuse your request for a refund if your playtime is a minute more than two hours.

[b]I love this game alot[/b], it's truly an amazing experience. 
I played all the older djmax games leading up to this one. And this is truly the [u]definite edition[/u] however there is issues with this game that I was fine overlooking but something more recent has caused me to write a bad review for this game. [u]The Clear Pass[/u]

[h1]The Good[/h1]

This game is great no doubt about it from the blazing tracks to the addictive gameplay. Totally worth the money to spend as you get lost for hours trying to get better at the game as time progress. Trying to unlock certain skins and songs for the game while at the same time honing improvement. 
Excellent mode choices (air, freestyle, collection, online, etc...) that keeps you from boredom:

Air - A great small unique mode that lets you play songs live while reading others comments. Like a epic mix between podcast and livestream.

Free mode - Have fun trying to max out combos or play whatever song you like

Online - Battle against others in to seeing who gets the better score.

Mission - Play a collection of songs while having challenging tasks to do such as achieve certain score or being above a certain success rate percentage.

Collection - See your in game stats as well as look at art and see your achievements.

Sounds great but that's not why I wrote this review.

[h1]The Horrid[/h1]

Anticheat <- This is such a crappy anticheat that kills potato pcs as it constantly uses the cpu to check you're not using any suspicious programs. It likely works but truly makes the game hard to play on pcs with weak cpus. Causing likely stuttering and other in game issues.

Expensive DLCs -> I myself have most of DJMAX dlc. I'm fine with purchasing as most of the songs in the dlcs have been in the past game and only to replay these tracks with new SC difficulties as well as a HD Background seems awesome. But for the price tag when not on sale can seems really not worth it. Mainly because of the amount of songs per pack. 

Servers -> Because you always need to be online and connected to djmax servers if they go down then say goodbye to all the money you wasted on this or even the hours you put into it. Once this game is forgotten it's game over as all of your game progress is saved online to the cloud.

And really any other small issue would be here too but this isn't even the reason I'm writing this review either it's because of this

[h1]CLEAR PASS[/h1]

Neowiz what the hell is wrong with you. Putting a damn battle pass from fortnite into this already money hungry game. I pay for the dlcs and i bought this overpriced game what the hell is wrong with you seriously. Now your just doing highway treason with making us also pay for a fortnite battle pass to access cosmetics that we won't probably naturally get in game. You just rid worth it progression now for us to pay premium to unlock said progression awards. 

This is why I wrote this review because of this lame ass battle pass
It fine in game like fortnite as it's free and there is no dlc. I don't personally play fortnite but it's understandable there. But here is [b]absolutely ridiculous[/b]

DJMax Respect is one of many rhythm games on the market with a simple premise. Notes travel across the screen towards a fixed position. Hit the correct button (keyboard or controller) at the right time in order to accumulate points. When I've described this game to people who have not played rhythm games before, they often react with, "That sounds easy!" Of course, this sounds very basic on paper, but the reality is that the level of dexterity, hand-eye coordination, reaction time and, most importantly, sense of rhythm required reach a very high ceiling. Ultimately, none of that matters if the music isn't good enough to keep you wanting to play.

There is a huge variety of music present in the game, even without counting the DLCs. Name a genre (without getting overly specific) and there is most likely at least one track in that style. It is this range that will ensure that there will be a handful of tracks that you will enjoy. Fortunately, there is an in-game [i]favourite[/i] system that allows you to single out these tracks for easy access.

While I have been an enthusiast of rhythm games for the past couple of decades, I am no expert of the genre and its many technical aspects. What I can confidently say is that DJMax Respect and its predecessors are of a calibre beyond other similar games. The variety and quality of its music alone is nearly enough to warrant a recommendation. It's the basic yet challenging gameplay that will keep you coming back for more.

This game will provide more long-term entertainment value for me.

One of many complaints about this game is about the anti-cheat, I for one don't care and it never affected my experience. Additionally, some people complain that it's too easy, that may be true to seasoned veteran IIDX or SDVX players, but for people like me, who don't have access to many arcade rhythm games in my region who has only played either osu!mania, Stepmania on PC. This has been a great experience for me to get out of my comfort zone to try out 5k - 8k and master my accuracy!
All in all, this is one of the best rhythm games on Steam. Buy it! Rather than spending it on drugs or something short-term that only satisfy yer for a while.

P.S: DJMAX songs and patterns were originally developed for a controller scheme not keyboard, therefore some people might find it easy, the dev team has made an additional "SC" DIFFICULTY, that is tinkered to be more suitable for keyboard plays.

For those who aren't completely new to the rhythm game genre but aren't super familiar with DJMAX, here's a little bit of a different review from a specialist's perspective:

I'm a prominent level creator in the rhythm game community and I've authored one of the most comprehensive and detailed rhythm game level creation guides out there.

With the heavy price tag on DJMAX, you are primarily paying for something that few other rhythm games can pull off successfully: keysounded quality level design. Keysounded notes make it feel more like you are actually playing the music and "performing" it yourself. The quality of the level design allows you to really appreciate the music you're listening to. They have a fantastic selection of levels of all difficulty levels, from the very basic to the reasonably difficult.

Should you get this game? If you are reasonably familiar with rhythm games and you like the idea of a polished quality game, you will learn quickly why this franchise has such a cult following. It's got a couple of technical quirks such as not being able to play while offline, but I personally find these to be mild issues overall. The song list is small compared to most other rhythm games, but this is the cost of having a beautifully curated selection.

DJMax finally has a PC game that releases in America! The fact that half of my DJ Max games are imported should be enough to describe how much I'm into this series, but what of this game?

DJ Max is a rhythm game with a familiar setup. Depending on your mode, you either have 4, 5, 6, or 8 tracks with falling notes for you to hit. Luckily for beginners, DJMax Respect V is a love letter to the entire franchise, in that it contains the vast majority of songs from games that came before, only a couple of which have previously been given a proper release in the US. Respect V is an enhanced version of Respect, originally released for Playstation 4 a few years back. With the base Respect V game, you get all the songs from DJ Max Portable 1 and 2 (two early series games, many of them which appeared in DJMAX Fever on PSP, the series' first US release). You also get a collection of tracks composed specifically for Respect.

All together, there's over 150 songs for the base game already, although close to 100 of these need to be unlocked as you level up. DLC is available to nearly round out the entire DJ MAX library: Trilogy, Technika (1-3), Clazziquai, Black Square, Emotional Sense. A few later games are not adequately represented yet, but since there's still a steady stream of updates and DLC, that could only be a matter of time. There are also DLC songpacks for crossovers with other games, like Deemo, Cytus, and Groove Coaster. And then there's the V Extension pack, which gives you another collection of newly-made songs. Many DLC packs also have extras like gears, missions, and even UI themes. The UI themes for past game packs are quite nostalgic, as they emulate the look of the previous games, complete with bringing back old menu music. That, along with the many references like achievement and mission names, make the DLC a special trip down memory lane.

Respect V's Air mode gives you the ability to drop in and out of play pretty much at will, you'll play an endless playlist and the tracks will be autoplayed whenever you do not wish to play. This is good for when you want to start playing quickly and don't really care about what you play - you do get to choose your button mode and general range of difficulty, but the song selection is more or less out of your hands.

Freestyle is the ability to play any unlocked song. Here you can raise your overall score, unlock album images, accomplish in-game objectives, beat your highest scores, and increase that all-important combo counter.

Online mode consists of either ranked battles where you play best-of-3 matches to raise your tier, or free matches where you play any songs you like with others and ranking is not affected. The ranked battle system is pretty fun in my opinion.

Finally, mission mode has you trying to clear specific challenges - and they get pretty serious pretty quick. 

Those familiar with DJ Max games will recognize certain flaws: in 10+ years of DJ Max, it appears Neowiz still lacks a truly experienced/native English speaker on their team. You'll find odd grammar quirks throughout, and this even extends to achievement descriptions that are ambiguous. DJMAX also has a history of not being the most technically polished game series (one of the gears in the PSP Fever game actually froze the game whenever you attempted to use it), although I have not had this game long enough to know if it's a problem. One of the current worst things performance wise is if your computer doesn't meet minimum specs, you will experience the elements of the song and video getting out of sync with each other. Which might not be a big issue, except the game seems to take more resources than it should need. My Surface Pro 3 struggles to keep up unless I turn off the BGM. Looking around on the discussions, performance seems to have gotten worse after updates, so there's always the hope that it can get better again.

Despite the flaws, this game is still a wonderful celebration of DJ Max, a fantastic entry point for beginners, and an incredible value for anybody (especially on sale). I highly recommend it.

Good music game must play.

Here is the rundown:
- The game is fun, lots of music to choose from if you are willing to get some dlc on top. However there will be songs for you to unlock. The dlc are mostly for people that have played previous DJ MAX franchises and like certain songs (like me, i love clazziquai and technika 1-3)
- Overall performance is solid, though i ran into some light issues with load times after 3 days of playing. I verified my game and it seemed to fix itself but super odd. - not a deal breaker for me though. 
- There are a variety of modes to play, you got your standard online with friends, air mode that is kinda like a radio/play as you go (lets you experience new songs that you might not know you've liked) and less competitive. 
- There is ranking for all the competitive players
- There is also a mission mode for you those who want a challenge. 
- They do collaborations with other games like Girls Frontline, Cytus, and Chunithm. So some of the songs from these collabs might be relevant to you. (DLC)

Overall I've always loved the DJMAX series from when I was 16 playing the arcade to now (24). 
If you love music, kpop, edm, ani-pop, and a little bit of classical remixes, then this game is for you. 
However, dlc is a little expensive if it's not on sale so keep that in mind.

IF you are planning for DLC, take some time to look through the songs and see if it's right for you.
Clazzquai - mostly chill songs
Black Square - a little more dubstep-kinda theme
Technika 1-3 - from the original arcade. - all songs are in the associated packs. 

Cheers, go get some MAX. RESPECT.

As a person who plays rhythm games, I love 4K based rhythm games. And DJMAX is one of those games I never thought I'd get hooked on, but did anyways lol. The song library is vast, and has genres of all kinds which makes DJMAX RESPECT V one of, if not, my most favorite rhythm game of all time. It's got really cool mechanics (such as Side Tracks), custom noteskins and gears, and a WHOLE LOT of DLC to explore. Who knows? You might even find tracks that you've never heard of and are now on your favorites! 

On the contrary, one thing I wish DJMAX had were more modes to choose from as from when I got the TECHNIKA 3 DLC, I tried out the TECHNIKA-like missions and fell in LOVE with them. I'd love to see that as a full-on mode one day. ^^

All in all, amazing rhythm game and should definitely pick it up if you can!

This game is one that I do not regret spending money on. It's provided me with hours of fun, nonstop challenge and a bunch of players to play with! 

Pros:
- A decent amount of songs with the base game
- Many different line types for different skill levels
- I can actually play it on my potato computer
- Multiplayer does have a decent playercount
But, there are still a couple of cons, mostly with the songs.
- Songs are locked behind a leveling wall, forcing players to either cheese it with air mode, or spend way too much time playing the same songs over and over again.
- More than half of the songs available in the game are locked behind a paywall.
- Sometimes, the game hiccups and I lose my inputs.
- The game does not like it when I double click the same note, weird considering those notes appear a lot. Although, that's more of a potato computer problem.
- My biggest gripe. YOU NEED INTERNET TO PLAY. God, i wish i could play this game on the go, or in the air, but It needs connection at all times. Go figure.

This game is so well made. I'm not new to rhythm games and this is exactly what I was looking for: various songs (mostly reeeally good ones), 4 differents button-modes (8b is really tricky at first damn), ranked 1v1 games and also a really weird-but-nice mode called ''air'', not to mention the mission mode (that one gets REALLY hard becaus of the modifiers you are forced to play with). I bought it when on sale and I'll say that it was really a nice discount, thanks steam for allowing me to play this pearl.

I tried really hard to like this game and it's unfortunately not for me.

I've played quite a bit of rythm games, notably FlashFlashRevolution (since 2007!) and Stepmania and consider myself to be pretty good at them. Difficulty was not an issue, I usually find it quite boring to have to play through easier songs to get to a level that suits my skills.

While I'm usually very open in my musical tastes, I found none of the songs available were particularly good or exciting. I would often zone-out while playing, either because the song was not to my liking or too easy. I did enjoy the Guilty Gears songs but even then, I would have preferred more engaging renditions; For instance 'Holy Orders' is my favorite but I would have much rather preferred playing S.S.H's cover!

I find notes very difficult to "read". This did make the game a lot more difficult to play, but not in a satisfying way. My personal preference is clear color codes for notes that match the beats, i.e. different colors for beats, 1/2 beats, 1/4 beats, 1/8 beats etc. In this case, the colors seem to change based on lanes and / or whether those notes will provide "fever"? I'm honestly still not sure. It made songs with more notes a lot more difficult to read and I couldn't get a good sense of the beat based on the notes spacing alone.

I do appreciate how polished the game feels. I love the menu animations and the presentation of it all. I like the way the game is made, but not its content.

All in all, I kept playing the game to give it a chance but I ultimately did not enjoy myself with the base pack. I don't feel like purchasing additional song packs would change my mind... And I don't feel like spending more money on a game I don't like that much.

I would advise people to look into the songs the game has and watch a few videos of gameplay to see if that's something they would enjoy. I think it's a good game, it just wasn't for me.

As someone who's been really into rhythm games in the past few years, I picked up DJMAX Respect when it was on the PS4. I was pretty used to controller based rhythm games so I got into it pretty quick, but it never really felt right, kinda like it needed to be on a keyboard. Lo and behold, I thought my wishes were answered, but...unfortunately not.

Let me start off by saying this: DJMAX Respect V is not a bad game. Far from it, there's some really fun things about the game. A rhythm game that uses samples and plays along with you, instead of just muting a track on and off, is a really neat concept and makes it really satisfying when you hit a long string of notes and it sounds perfectly in sync. The amount of music, while a little repetitive, feels decent for the price, and they're adding new songs every once and a while.

So why don't I like this game? One word: lag. I have done seriously everything I could think of to try to eliminate input lag on my system. Reinstalling my graphics drivers, using a different monitor, reinstalling my entire OS, using different keyboards, even trying the game on a different computer, and the same behavior: severe input lag when playing. To make sure I wasn't going nuts I hooked up a metronome to my sound card and made sure the music and met were in sync, then tried to play listening to the sounds of my keyboard and the met only. The results? Max 60% scores on every single note. I repeated it multiple times, with different songs which used different BPMs, and I can't figure out what was going on. To make sure I wasn't going crazy, I whipped out my phone and recorded some slow-mo footage of me hitting the key on my keyboard and watching when the note lit up, and compared it to another fantastic rhythm game: osu. There was noticeable lag on the DJMAX recording. Trying to mess with the audio delay settings makes the chart in sync, but then the music is completely messed up, because the samples are playing at the wrong time, which basically ruins the game for me. I want to feel like I'm playing the music, not just tapping along with a chart.

Maybe I'm just unlucky with my setup, considering other people don't seem to have this problem. Searching online, especially scouring the r/DJMAX subreddit came up empty for me, as if I'm the only one who has this problem (or others have just learned to deal with it). Until this is fixed, I can't recommend the game, especially when the game costs at minimum, $50. There really should be better compatibility at that price point.

A fantastic rhythm game that is brought down by a single flaw: input lag. 4/10.

EDIT: If anyone has the same issue and sees this, please let me know. I'd like to hear if you had anything that improved performance. I REALLY want to love this game, I think it's honestly one of the best rhythm games out there, and I really want to continue playing it and buy the DLC. I just can't though until this is fixed, or until I figure out what my problem is (it really should be fixed in code though, Neowiz).

As a newcomer to the DJMAX series I can highly recommend this game. The mission difficulty can be quite steep coming from a more casual rhythm background - however with some time spent on freestyle clearing patterns, the more difficult challenges of the game feel achievable. Through freestyle you unlock songs and level up your profile, which gives you a steady income of new tracks. I would recommend grabbing the DLC on sale if you enjoy the game as it adds a lot toward replay value. I started by grabbing the TECHNIKA Pack which seems to included many electronic style tracks.

One of the most challenging and most satisfying rhythm games that has you coming back for more. Many different playstyles to master (4B, 5B, 6B, 8B) with their own patterns. Key hits relay noise for note placement to assist in correcting proper notes. The game offers a challenge that gives you a sense of accomplishment. Songs range from 1 star to 15 star difficulty. Most of the time spent playing will be in freestyle (picking single songs). 

I was initially discouraged when I was first exposed to DJMAX, and felt as if the game was too hard. Now 100 hours later I am sitting at an average of 10* max combos in patterns. Missions are for those who want the true challenge -- but are still a bit difficult to me. (20 missions cleared at time of review).

Best rhythm game money can buy and only purchase DLC on big sales, as they go discounted for approx. 50-66% off. Only cons about the game are the always online connection and invasive cheat system to play.

DJMAX RESPECT V is easily the most difficult game I've ever played. 

This is one where Steam's rating system shows its deepest flaws. I think this game is brilliant, truly, but playing its campaign is like a mountain. After opening the campaign in a fashion that is fun and fresh, you'll find yourself brutally dashed against the cliffs of rhythm hell. I have never, in 30 years of playing games, experienced a difficulty spike like what this game presents. It is nigh impossible to finish anything past the 6th level, and yet, I am here, telling you I wish to.

Should you purchase this game you will find yourself repeating a single song for a half dozen hours, learning it like a real instrument. Your hands will cramp, your fingers will pain, but maybe, just maybe, you'll complete that level, and do it all over again.

You probably shouldn't play this game, but boy is it brilliant if you're a glutton for punishment.

First impressions of Respect V compared to osu!mania and other games like it. 

TL;DR: osu!mania and other f2p titles in this genre=quantity over quality. DJ Max Respect V=quality over quantity. osu!mania/f2p=free. DJMRV=Expensive. 

osu!mania is a great equivalent to a game like this, especially given the limitless content and it being free, but it's easy to see why people prefer this over it. What you get here is premium; the animations, timing, song/skin/controls customisation... It's all top notch, with songs even having custom tapping sounds to make you feel like you're actually "playing" the music. You can also control everything using your keyboard, and for a game like this, that is super helpful. Despite all this... The price is a hard sell, especially when you realise how many DLCs this game has on it. Muse Dash does a really good job in its genre of rhythm games, being a variant of Taiko, but its DLC is only 40 dollars and it comes with everything, as well as future releases. Respect V on the other hand sells practically every new release as a DLC, meaning you're spending about as much as you'd buy an expensive indie game for, just to expand what's here. I'm also not the biggest fan of the music selection right out of the gate, so I am already here wondering whether I should bother to upgrade... I think this structure to marketing this game is predatory at best, and makes me, the user, feel scammed. 

This game comes with very nice unlockable content, as well as graphs that show off your overall performance. These sections of the game are done super well and push you to play more for the completionist factor. Compared to a lot of other games like this, I'd say this is where Respect V shines - the overall UI displays this information neatly, clearly, and aesthetically, oozing quality and improving overall enjoyment factor.

The multiplayer is a bit rough around the edge when it comes to options. I can't see any kick feature, it isn't the most obvious who wins after each match, and there is no logs that show the history of your placement - like there is in osu. The upper hand that this game does have over osu's multiplayer is that you can see others playing on the side. While not practical for play, it is neat, especially if you're streaming the game. Also each player is allowed to play any difficulty and key number they'd like, so if you're not so good at the game, people will still bother to play with you because they can adjust their side to be harder. This is a great feature and makes multiplayer a lot more active than most games like this. It's hard to know how this factors into points, but I assume that the harder difficulties and keys will net you more points - as it should be.

Overall, the product is good, but is weighed down by an expensive entry price, and a hoard of DLCs. If this really is your thing, I'd say buy the base game on sale, and expand as you run out of content, and only buy what interest you. Even then, there are options out there like Step Mania, Quaver, and osu!mania, and they're all free. While the product you get here is definitely more polished than any of those, they are at the end of the day free, and if you're already questioning whether you should buy based on price alone, I'd say passing is your best option.

EDIT: On sale the DLCs aren't that much if you remove all the gear/unlock packs (cosmetic/passes for songs you can unlock for free), and the original sound tracks (Not maps for in game, but song files), you are left with a still expensive, but manageable DLC list for all the extra songs currently available. There is quite a lot here for around 50-100 dollars depending on which ones you want to buy (Deemo/Cytus pack don't have keysounds, so some say to skip this, and Technika packs aren't officially listed, and most people won't have these songs for multiplayer anyway). There is also more than enough base content to get your moneys worth if you buy the game on sale, so take my "feeling scammed" comment lightly.

Don't buy any DLC that doesn't directly give you new songs to play. (Unless you want to)
Don't buy any DLC when they aren't on sale. (Unless you want to)
Don't buy the "Unlock Songs" DLC. It unlocks content that can be unlocked through gameplay.

I've owned all of the DJMax games going all the way back to the PSP days and most recently played this over 300 hours on the PS4. This is terrific experience from top to bottom. First, while not always crucial in rhythm games, DJMax Respect V has a brilliant aesthetic. Each menu, each device skin, every UI input is designed to function as a whole so the process of selecting game modes and music is enjoyable. In a game where you might spend hundreds of hours playing, it's nice to have colorful, lively animations and nuances to keep everything feeling fresh. The videos in game are all fun and the variety within the tons of songs you have at your fingertips is huge. Song selection wise, you have great tracks in the base game and then a TON of really well priced DLC packs which expand the game exponentially. Each pack brings new UI themes, new animations, new songs and they are, for the most part easy to enjoy regardless of whatever music style you might prefer. I like harder edged techno/EDM stuff but even the lighter tracks are fun. Game modes range from playing solo sessions for high scores, playing online, partaking in challenging mission modes (and some of them are doozies) and in packs like the Technika packs, entirely different ways of playing the core game. I cannot say enough about DJ Max Respect V, it was great on the PS4 and even better here. It runs like a dream and it is continually being supported by the devs unlike some of the competition. Grab it and think about how much work these guys put into this game.

This is one of the most satisfying rhythm game systems ever. You hit many keys laid out like Piano Tiles, from a layout of 4 to 8 buttons, and receive Fever and extra score for hitting a note precisely. The difficulty curve is phenomenally good: you can play Air mode, which are completely relaxed and easy; Missions, which have you complete a song but with a certain qualifier; or Freestyle, in which you play songs for personal score, which is very challenging and has a limit to many notes you can miss. The game's many, many different difficulties and button layout/variations give you a lot to practice with and many songs to play. Soundtrack is also super diverse and catchy; many different genres and each song has a unique animation in the background. It also has some nice UI customizations. The fun of the game is how simplistic its tremendous challenge is and slowly becoming adequate enough process your ever faster key smashing. There is immense joy in beating a song you have toiled to keep up with for a long time, each song a boss in its own right. As you slowly conquer the catalogue of music, you will feel godlike satisfaction at how fast you can type on a keyboard.

Anyways i'm pretty average at this game even though I've spent hundreds of hours on the ps4 version lol but transitioning to keyboard took a little getting used to on top of the long break I had from the game. Still, I feel myself constantly improving so I'll keep coming back.

I won't lie. This game has some design flaws where certain modes feel pointless or have huge unnecessary difficulty spikes. That said, this is still the best crafted rhythm game I have played in years. There is a ridiculously large amount of content in this game with new music being added fairly regularly.  

The range of difficulty is also incredibly vast, starting with very simplified versions of most songs requiring only 4 buttons (plus two more that are seldom used and are optional when they appear) up to ridiculously difficult 1:1 transcriptions of the music requiring 8 buttons (plus the extra two). Starting out, the game will feel sort of bad because it can be quite difficult and much of the music is actually produced by pressing buttons. If you can't play a song well, it won't sound good. On the flip side of this, when you can play a song well, most of them sound great and the satisfaction of knowing that it sounds good because you're playing perfectly is incredible. Some other rhythm games using booing crowds and jeering announcers to reinforce that you need to improve. This game needs only let you listen to the music you're producing through a poor performance.

Each song has it's own animated (or live action) video that plays in the background during the song giving the feeling of playing a music video each time. Most of them are really well made, but some of them are absolute unapologetic garbage that should be immediately turned off (which, luckily is an option on a per song basis). I think, honestly, one of their video designers must hate people with epilepsy.

After 48 hours, I'm only just scratching the surface of this game. I have mostly stuck to 4 button mode, and I still have not played about half of the songs in the game. I suspect it will take me hundreds more hours to be good enough to play competently in 8 button mode, and I think I'm going to have a blast on my journey there. This game is somewhat expensive, but it has become the only game that I immediately pay for DLC for. For me, it was worth every penny. I can't believe I ignored this series for so long after trying it for the first time in 2006.

This game is just incredibly well-made. The songs, note patterns, dlcs, different modes, and customizations are the best I‚Äôve ever seen in a rhythm game. Yes, you may think the price is a bit much but it‚Äôs really worth it when you know you‚Äôre going to put time and effort into the game. There are so many features to this game that you won‚Äôt get bored of. Highly recommend and you will not regret it.

I'm mostly playing 6key right now at the 11-13 star range so I'm sure I'll continue to get playtime out of this for a while yet.

It gets pretty challenging but is rewarding, and the whole note sounds system works really well. I would say this might be a little daunting if you're new to rhythm games but I think even completely new players can have fun with the lower difficulty 4key maps and improve. Not all the 8key maps necessarily have the highest difficulty for every track, which is also nice since it doesn't gate everything there. Definitely do not want to play this on a laptop keyboard though, you'll want a mechanical keyboard or at least a membrane keyboard with some taller keycaps since this requires a lot of hand/finger independence, and you'll need to use your wrists for some of the harder stuff. Only minor complaint is that the menuing is kind of clunky, but it's still totally acceptable.

~Early access review.
While this game is overall very polished, has a good music selection, and a variety of difficulties to play, there are some things I hope they can improve on. Keep in mind i'm coming from a "tryhard" background in rhythm games with 4 years of 4key experience. If you enjoy rhythm games casually you will most likely enjoy this game. $50 is a very steep price, I got it during the winter sale for $40 and still am unsure about that price point.

First off, there is one thing i'd like to get out of the way. Chart readability. This is more apparent during high level play with high NPS. There are so many combo flashers and "fever" multipliers everywhere, combined with huge combo font, that it is really hard to read notes sometimes. This is more apparent when you miss one and then your combo starts building up immediately showing x2 x3 x4 x5 in quick succession. There are no options to turn any of this off. You can dim the BGA, although I would consider that a standard feature for rhythm games.

Second up is difficulty. Like I said earlier, there are many good songs with multiple difficulties to play. However, most songs do not have maximum or SC difficulties available, making the pool of songs for high level play relatively small. This might not be a problem for you if you play a variety of key counts. I am almost entirely a 4 key player so this is more apparent to me. Note patterns are not very well rounded, I noticed a lot of streams, jacks, and vibros across different songs, but nothing else besides that.

Next up, the air mode. I'm not sure I entirely get the point of this. You play a queue of songs while randomly picked comments from other users appear on the right side of the screen, giving the effect of an audience of viewers while the notefield is moved against the left side of the screen. The scores set in live mode are not saved, and when you go back into free play they are not shown (In my case I checked a song I had not previously played).

Finally, customization. This leaves a lot to be desired. You cannot move the notefield position at all, (it sits a little high on the screen for my liking) you can't adjust the size of the notefield, some VFX cannot be turned off, note speed is relative to each song, sound effects volume can only be lowered to 50% minimum, not allowing you to turn it off.

I know this review seems negative, but I really don't hate the game. It's very polished, has no technical or crashing issues, a decent song lineup, and 4-8 key play. If you are a beginner/intermediate VSRG player and find this game for 30 bucks, go ahead and grab it, you will probably have a lot of fun. From my perspective, it's still limited in some areas. This could all change due to the game being in early access, and it definitely has a solid start.
Needed a new Rhythm game to play and was instantly drawn to the art style for this one. A fun game that on higher difficulties will test your reactions. Definitely recommend it to fans of the genre.

Let's keep it simple so I can get back to playing.

This is the absolute best version of my favorite rhythm game of all time. 

I've been a fan of this series since the PSP games back in the day, and this game contains every single song I have loved for so many years, along with so, so many more. The base game includes a huge amount of content, between songs, unlockables, missions, online play, and the new AIR mode, which reminds me of the LIVE mode from Guitar Hero LIVE, but done a bit better. This mode is cool, since it allows you to try out DLC songs for free occasionally (the selection of songs is random on AIR)

The DLC is expensive. There's no getting around it. However, the way that it is parsed out means you never HAVE to buy all of it. It's separated by the game the songs originally appeared in, so, say, if you love Black Square, but don't like the Clazziquai Edition tracks, you'll never be forced to buy those. It's very modular in that way, and new content is being released constantly.

The sound quality and graphical presentation is clean, sleek, and gorgeous. The online play isn't the most active, but it is very stable and a huge amount of fun.

I don't know what else to say. If you like music, buy it. If you loved Beatmania back in the day, you probably already own it, but if not, BUY IT. Wonderful game, wonderful port, wonderful music.

Waaay to pricey, so I can't recommend this to everyone:
If you want to try out the genre there are cheaper options like TapSonic or Invaxion or even OSU (hey it's free).
Also there's rather invasive mandatory anti-cheat program - so beware.

On the other hand - if you want to try the real deal - just get it, it's good. DJ Max rises from the grave.

All I wanted was my Killer Bee, and I got it.
Finding the large amount of rhythm classics and great new ones definitely hit the spot for me.

It's nice to see that DJMAX is making it's way to Steam. The games are fun from where I originally played DJMAX during the PSP era playing Portables 1,2,3, Clazziquai, and Black Square. Majority of the music are instrumentals, English, and Korean (of course, because they made the series) in different forms of music genre.

This game is just giving me a nostalgic feeling. The higher difficulty settings brings it a challenge and fun to the game and music. Every beat you push brings dynamic tunes, just like the PSP. And the note mapping looks and feels the same (in a good way), so muscle memory comes to play and making it an enjoyable experience once again.

From the looks of it, DJMAX Respect V compiled most (maybe all in the future) of the songs from its PSP predecessor, Technika, and original songs from DJMAX Respect in PS4. I mean, this game IS originally from PS4. The music from Portable 3, Technika, Clazziquai, and Black Square is missing in the roster, which would mean they'll become a future DLC or a free content. Correct me if I'm missing more details.

DJMAX Respect's music video has been rendered high quality, unlike the PSP games to which are pixelated before (Except for Clazziquai, which is [b]THE BEST DJMAX for me![/b])

The game has 4,6, and 8 button modes, if you're so bold and daring to play that many. If you're using a controller like me, L2 and R2 comes to play, just like the classics.

[strike]
[b]Words of Advice:[/b]
[list]
[*] I advice you to play this on a Playstation controller, since it was intentionally played like it. Unless you're the ones who played DJMAX Online and O2Jam, then go crazy with the keyboard. 
[*] Advice from the PS controllers that the R2 doesn't seem to function so you'll miss a beat when the R2 comes in.
[*] Use headphones. This is a rhythm game!
[*] Adjust the speed of notes coming down to what fits you.
[*] Follow the tutorial so you can understand the game better.
[/list]
[/strike]

I don't think you need to see the list since most of them have already been resolved. Play however you want!

The game is in early access and hopefully will bring more old but gold content. I implore you to give this game a chance. This will give you a more discovery of music genres you'll favor. And for those who have played the games originally, play this as well. You'll be reminded of everything you have experienced in this game. I know this review is bias but to hell with it; I grew up with the series.

Enjoy!

a while ago, if you asked me about my thoughts on this game, i would have said it kinda sucks to play on PC and that it wasn't really worth getting. however, after upgrading my hardware a bit (120hz 0.5ms monitor, new keyboard, etc.) and grabbing a bunch of the DLC over the last sale, i've gotta say, this is really damn good.

the song list is amazingly huge, spanning over two PSP games and a bunch of brand new (and great) tracks, and if you get the DLC, you get even more options (i personally recommend getting V EXTENSION and TECHNIKA 3). i'd recommend buying the song unlock DLC just because grinding every song out to play normally is a paaaain.

gameplay is fun and easy to pick up, and judgment is generally not strict in the slightest. speed mods stay the same across all songs, you've got a bunch of different noteskins and 'gears' (your playfield) to change up, you have 4 different choices of modes to play (or 2 more if you end up getting far in the game's MISSION MODE), it's all really really nice.

if you're looking for a paid rhythm game to get into that's worth your money, i'd say get this one. lots of content, lots of fun.

If you're into rhythm games at all, most likely you have heard of this game at one point or another. This is the ultimate collection of DJMAX. This game not only features all of the DJMAX songs from Portable 1 and 2, as well as all the songs from RESPECT, it also includes new songs and skins unique to this version. There are also dlcs planned that will include songs from all other DJMAX titles as well as new song releases.

It's fun, addictive, and challenging. You can choose between 4, 5, 6, or 8 button mode. Each mode has songs with varying difficulties. You can gain experience and level up, unlocking collectible in game items, like songs, artwork, and music videos.
 
[b][i]A thing to note: You do not need to purchase the UNLOCK SONG PACK to enjoy all of the songs. They are unlockable in game by gaining experience.[/i][/b]

[i]My nomination for "Game of the Year" in the Steam Game Awards 2020[/i]

DJMAX RESPECT (PS4) and DJMAX RESPECT V assembles pretty much the whole series/songs in one game (which was likely to have some DLCs), but nonetheless.

The gameplay in itself is pretty playable, a lot of different settings, new songs, new missions and well, we couldn't ask for it since it's already there, but Online Multiplayer to compete against friends and other players!

On a scale of 1 to 10, it's easily a 9 outta 10 for me.

My most favorite rhythm game series ever. Words can't express how important this series is to me(especially the Technika series), amazing song library, and an online versus mode to boot too! The game itself oozes amazing amounts of care.  If you're looking for a great rhythm game with loads of content right out of the gate, this is it. I'd even say it's the quintessential rhythm game of this generation. For returning DJMAX fans, this game is a heartfelt love letter to us, don't miss out.

Some cons to note as well though is that this game must always be connected online to play it, so if you're looking for something you can take with you anywhere, this game sadly is not it.  There is also that anti-cheat software that's a bit suspicious, but I suppose easily overlookable, depending on how finnicky you are. The DLC packs are on the hefty side in terms of pricing, but if you ask me it's worth every cent given how good the songs are.
train your eye become more alert XD. Fun, alot music to play and very hard to get board because it's challenging !!!

if you're a fan of rhythm games at all, especially technical rhythm games, you're doing yourself a giant disservice by not playing this. if the 50 dollar price tag seems daunting, then definitely pick it up on sale. the online ladder matches and open matches are a great touch. this, along with AIR mode and some additional songs, are reason enough to make this superior to its PS4 version. it doesnt yet have all of the DLC that the PS4 version has, but it's currently pretty close. and considering this port came out in march of this year, pentavision/neowiz are being pretty quick with the rollout, which is nice even if it hurts my wallet.

***!!!!!!MAKE NOTE!!!!!!***
This game uses Xigncode3, which is a pretty privacy-invasive anti-cheat program/DRM which also requires you to be online at all times in order to play the game in any of the modes. Most negative reviews will be due to this. Make sure you understand this before making the decision to purchase this game.

I'm a newbie to dj max in general. But the music and the difficulty keep on bringing me back as more dlc songs come and the challenge to get to the next difficulty arises.  So much music, pop, rock, kpop, alternative, metal, just so much to choose from. I can say I'm never starving for musical variety

Additional revision: I've learned about the rootkit that this game uses and won't be installing it again unless these invasive anti-cheat/DRM methods are completely removed

Revision: I've learned that this game uses always-online DRM, which I'm not a fan of. I won't change the rest of my review as I still think it's a great game (I also found out it has 5, 6, and 8 button modes!) but I hope they will revise that decision.

It's really fun! There's some really great music and the charting is pretty good. If you're wary about playing a keyboard music game, you'll be surprised. It works really well. I love the in game aesthetic, and it's awesome that it doesn't have an FPS cap, which you don't even get with IIDX (infinitas & PS2 versions all require a solid 60.) Really fun for a IIDX player.

Things to improve:
I'd like if more songs reached into higher difficulties, I haven't unlocked much yet so there's likely more, but at the beginning I'd really like if I could play harder charts. The higher difficulty ones that are available to me now are pretty fun, I just wish there were more.

I tried playing using a IIDX controller (Phoenixwan, from Gamo2) but it bugs out as soon as I plug it in. This is the only game I have that reacts to the controller being plugged in, so I don't assume it's an issue with the controller itself. While keyboard play is quite good, I'd really like to be able to map the IIDX controller.

Really wish it had fast/slow display, it would be so useful!
It's worth the buy for now.

Simple, yet challenging original rhythm tapping game, DJMAX. I remember when it first came out as DJMAX Online in South Korea, I was a kid-in-a-candy-store. Over the years, rhythm games in general lost popularity, perhaps due to unforgiving difficulty and graphic visualizations. DJMAX in particular lived on in various platforms but keeping its integrity from cheaters was difficult as with many other games at that time. In those early days, Intellectual Property was not even a thing and hackers were unaware that stealing IPs can crash both the game and the company. Keeping the legacy in other platforms such as PlayStation barely kept it alive. But the fans were always there, and when DJMAX was reborn in PS4, I was shocked with awe, as with many others I believe. This game was a legend in the rhythm game community and the legend resurrected.
I had played DJMax Portable 2 when I was younger and finally I get to experience the same tracks and new ones too. I love it.

I played DJ Max Respect on PS4 before I switched over to PC to try it out.  It's as great as I remember it :) You can still play songs at a speed that makes you feel comfortable. (I recommend starting with 8 button instead of 4 so you can go back and clear the easier setting with ease later). The songs are amazing as always. It is a bit different from the PS4 version though. One difference being the Air option on PC...that one not too fond of. Arcade on PS4 was better in my opinion. PC version has more ways to communicate with other players by adding the Air option. No spoilers here. You'll have to try it out to see what I mean. Also as a side note, I recommend getting a gaming PC or laptop to play. It still can be played on a non gaming PC but has horrable lag and there isn't a calibration button. You have to set it up manually in the in game settings. Other than those two things the game is exactly how I remember it. Amazing and Fun. It's definetly worth it to play.

It even has a controller support which I am more comfortable using than the keyboard. I feel like the full price is just too expensive so I waited for it to go on sale which I think is a reasonable price, I even got the bundle. I just hope that there would be an option to customize the UI because I find the x5 Fever distracting especially when it overlays with the side note. I enjoy playing it overall.

While there is a lot to like and appreciate in this DJ Max collection, while I want to sing it's praises and recommend it to friends, I absolutely can't recommend anything to anyone with DRM that prevents it from working during an internet outage.

If for any reason the players' internet goes out, this game is a very expensive waste of hard drive space.  If I could demand a refund at this point, I would.  I might be glad there's no stupid touchscreen gimmicks and I might like the idea behind "AIR" mode, but it's all irrelevant and wasted because the anti-cheat will not let the game boot without an active internet connection.

Of course, if none of this is a concern for you then by all means; the game is solid with some kickin' tunes both new and old.

My friend introduced DJMAX to me back in 2007, I brought DJMAX TRILOGY when it came out. Now DJMAX Respect V. Excellent game. Never disappointed. Definitely going to play more often now.
A little pricey but it's a very addicting game. It's fun and you can change up the game by changing how many buttons you want to use.

It's okay, it's definitely a DJMax game.

AIR mode is a trap, made me buy two extra DLC's because I stumbled upon songs I liked on it.
(basically a mode that lets you try out songs picked at random)

The DLC's I bought came with their own main menu themes, which was great. Not sure if ALL the DLC's are like this, if they all do come with their own themes, that would be awesome.
(they also came with their own noteskins and stuff)

Online mode has you fighting bots on lower ranks because no one plays online anymore at lower ranks. When you DO find a real human to fight with, you get rekt because then you remember the game is filled predominantly with koreans who can basically Max Combo the hardest songs in their sleep.

There are also online Open Rooms you can join where you can play with people without affecting ranks, but do too well and there's a 90% chance the host will kick you off the room just for being too good. So, try to miss at least one note on these rooms so you don't hurt their feelings. You also need to have bought the DLC if the host chooses a DLC song, or else you're stuck in Observe Mode twiddling your toes.

You also now can't disable the FEVER sounds like you could in Trilogy, you can now only lower it to 50% which annoys me since I just want to enjoy and hear the damn music by itself exclusively without those damn exploding sounds on EVERY DAMN FEVER. At least it doesn't have the whole audience screaming and clapping sounds like on Trilogy, but then again, you could disable it on Trilogy anyway unlike on this one.

Also, everytime I play it, I'm always reminded by the sad fact that this is PENTAVISION and one day this game will disappear forever just like how DJMax Technika Q was shutdown without any sign of further offline support.
(can't even play this one offline at all like you could in Trilogy, it's basically following in DJMax Technika Q's footsteps, which is a bad sign)

Play it while you can before it inevitably dies forever too.

Look, I can come to terms with always-online DRM on PC since this platform really is the most pirated out of all of them BUT PLEASE, I know this is wishful thinking, but if time comes and you finally pull the plug on this game, PLEASE give it offline capabilities. DJMax Trilogy is already 10+ years old and I STILL play it to this day (well mostly because of the longer gear space, actually that's another thing, why is the space for the notes shortened even further it's like 30% of the space is being consumed by the gear skin itself like WTH).

This game is art to me, and like all pieces of art, I would want it to last for as long as I would live. Seriously, please don't let it die the same way as DJMax Technika Q did.

PS: I also find it funny how the theme of the game is on a graveyard with epitaphs showing the names of the now dead games they've shutdown in the past, it's as if they knew they're doing this and they're just rubbing it in. Also "Press Any Key To Pay Respects", classy.

The DJMAX series is one of the OG rhythm game series out there alongside the likes of IIDX, DDR, etc. It has a long history and pedigree, and DJMAX Respect V is most definitely the best game in the series by far.

The presentation is sleek, the BGAs are beautiful, and the gameplay is top tier. What sets the DJMAX series apart from other rhythm games is the fusion of gameplay and art with the detailed BGAs as well as the attention to detail (e.g note SFX being actually sampled from audio tracks instead of generic SFX). The gameplay itself is accommodating to players of all skill levels, and the process of starting out as a beginner in 4B mode and slowly practicing and mastering your way up to the hardest difficulties in 8B is extremely fun and rewarding. I've gotten pretty good at rhythm games for over a decade now (IIDX, SDVX, etc) and I still find the hardest songs in DJMAX Respect to be fun and challenging.

If you've ever been curious about the rhythm game genre, then DJMAX Respect is the perfect game to get hooked on. For those who are already familiar with the genre, this stands as one of the genre defining games and is highly recommended.

Finally, DJMAX is back on PC!

..............aaaaaaaaaand it's very expensive, but DJMAX was never a mid-tier rhythm game anyway. The concept of a AAA rhythm game definitely sounds weird, but when you think of it, this game has a ton of effort and polish put into it. From the keysounding to individual BGAs for every song, as well as UI animations and many tracking features for a rhythm game.

The song setlist is comprised of original Respect songs as well as a selection of legacy songs from the Portable series of DJMAX games. Other songs are available as DLC packs (but again, they're prohibitively expensive) and they contain from additional songs for Respect V, collaboration from other rhythm games, as well as legacy DJMAX song packs.
Genre wise, the variation is complete, from your usual EDM varieties, to rock, hip-hop, pop, and even RnB and jazz. There's something for everyone!

In terms of gameplay, notes seem to be perfectly synced but this may vary per build. Performance wise, this is *not* the fastest running rhythm game by a long shot. Due to the amount of UI elements it has going for, it may hurt your FPS. I also run from stuttering issues and RTSS FPS limiting seems to cause a few crashes. So, you actually need a pretty decent rig to enjoy this game a bit, which is kind of a shame.

The game has multiple game modes to play:
- Air mode which allows you to play *any* songs even ones that you haven't purchased (good for a test drive), however they are on rotation so you can't choose what song you have to play
- Free mode which allows you to choose and play songs that you want, as well as a continuous chain/combo allowing you carry over the previous combo you have from the previous round, stacking up to 9999999 (there's even an achievement for that)
- Mission mode which challenges the player with a fixed set list and conditions to fulfill, good for training and easing into the game
- Online mode which has open matches and league/ranked matches
It also has stat tracking and profile card customization via Collection mode.
In terms of lanes, it has your popular 4K mode (4B), as well as 5B, 6B, and 8B which uses 2 "effector" buttons similar to Sound Voltex. The default keybinding is weird though so you probably want to adjust it.

I mentioned the price quite a few times in this review, and it really can't be ignored. AAA pricing for a rhythm game as well as DLC packs that cost from 10 dollars to a whopping 30 dollars is very eye watering. However, considering the polish this game has from the individual MVs, custom UI, and gear skins as well as additional missions, and the base song library which comes up to roughly 1 dollar a song, it's a pretty fair pricing. Still, it's a lot to ask just for a rhythm game and I highly suggest you buy this on a sale. But otherwise, this is the most premium experience you can get from a rhythm game.

IT'S DJ -FU**ING- MAX ON PC, AGAIN!!! AND IT'S SO LOADED WITH SONGS, old and new.
Specially made for those old-time fans, it has a bit of every game so far, plus new songs. Also, it has a fu*kload of DLCs if you want the absolute best DJ Max experience.

The gameplay is smooth and delicious. The soundkeys are back for vengeance (except on some collab songs, bummer), and they're here to f your perfect score, enjoy your 99.99% jud b*tch.
It has an online mode for the tryhards, it has the Collection to enjoy the deliciously made MVs, which by the way were retouched to look better and not PSP quality anymore. It has AIR mode to chill. Missions are back to f you and of course, Freestyle is open from the very beginning. Unlocking songs is still a "chore" if you don't like to play games, and it even gives you the option to unlock them all for some shekels, go be a good goy if you hate playing your games like a normal human.

Lastly, it has a lot of space to keep growing, who knows who might want to collab with Neowiz in the future.

Pros:
Well-produced rhythm game; albeit it is a ported remastered version with some newer songs.

Good music & some really good collabs.

Cons:
DLC prices are expensive and a scam; IDGAF if it was from the limited edition, 29.99 USD for what amounts to extra cosmetics and not gameplay does not feel worth spending money on. There is also unlock songs which is meaningless because you can unlock all the songs by playing to 99 or using AIR mode to play/listen to songs, but at the end of the day every new pack gets prices fairly expensively which I understand is necessary to pay artists etc. but after a while especially if you're considering buying the game and wanted to play more songs, you have to choose between what, 8 DLC packs all ranging from 10-25 USD. That will add up to a whole new game, and while they do release some free songs, they tend to be more sparse. (For reference,  they add in LOTS of DLC songs to keep you interested, possibly amounting to the songlist being 300-350 songs. I don't recommend buying anything w/o good sales)

Secondly; the game changed online features. At the time of this review, if you owned the DLC pack and tried to play with your friend, they are forced to listen instead of being able to play the song. This really sucks because I wanted to actually play with friends but being limited to the base game + whatever free DLC songs they've given out is less appealing. What's the point of multiplayer if it became a glorified listening session? There doesn't seem to be local multiplayer either, so guess that's out the window.

Family share also does not let you have access to the DLC. If a family member wanted to play the game, they don't get to have the DLC too.
Also there does not seem to be an offline mode? If you have spotty internet it could be a problem.

I enjoy the game, but I cannot recommend people buy it at full price. Wait for sales.

[NOTE: If you are having input lag issues, scroll down to the last paragraph because I talk about how I fixed mine. It's easy if your issue is the same as mine and there is a TL;DR if I'm too wordy.]

I played a TON of DJMax Respect on PS4 and was happy to see it come to PC, though I didn't really want to repurchase everything. I finally did and I can't say I regret it. I love this game. I'm not as good as I used to be since I haven't been playing nearly as often, but having to relearn to play on a keyboard (there is controller support, but keyboard is great!) has really gotten me back into playing. So, as for the game, it's great. It is my favorite rhythm game, along with Rock Band 4 and Project Diva. Playing on a keyboard feels awesome and getting a smooth 144fps @ 1440p makes a big difference.

First a couple of tips for new people: This game is hard, but once it clicks it feels great to play. Just start on the easy songs and progress as you get comfortable. Also, turn the note speed up. It's counterintuitive, but faster is better. Slower note speed leads to clutter on the screen that is hard to read. You need to learn to react to the notes without thinking about it. Trust me, it eventually feels natural. If you think you suck or it's impossible, don't give up! We all felt that way, this is a skill you have to learn. Start slow and you CAN get there. It clicks eventually.

For the PC version you can use whatever input device you have. Controller, keyboard, fightstick, whatever. Have fun. I have many hours on a Dualshock 4 and thought the Xbox One controller felt horrible for this game, but when I tried keyboard I fell in love. You absolutely should remap the default input to whatever you are comfortable with. Find something that has your hands in a natural position and will allow you to progress to different modes (4B, 5B, 6B, 8B) without much adjustment. I've been using WEF[spc], [num]489[rightarrow] where WEF489 are my 6B inputs and my thumbs hit spc or right arrow for 8B, pinkies on [CAPS] and [+] keys for side tracks (sticks on PS4). I keep WE, 89 for 4 button so my hand position never changes for any button mode. Do this early so you're not having to adjust down the line. Look online for other layout suggestions or just try stuff.

[EDIT: Second time editing this review. Last time was to note that the problems seemed fixed. This time is to report that the game is playing perfectly for me now. I haven't had an issue in a while, so I am deleting the lengthy complaint in this review because I don't want people to skim it and just pull out the bad. The game (seems) fixed (for me)!]

[EDIT2: Also, since purchasing this game they have added several new songs for free! Not sure how often they will do this, but it's a nice surprise to get free tracks now and then. Also, they finally added the ability to sort by star rating! So all 1 star songs, then 2 star songs, etc. Great for when you want to warm up gradually without having to search through.]

Okay, I'm putting this at the end to make it easy to find. When I first started playing I was failing out of 4 star songs. I could tell the note timing was off, but this game doesn't have a calibration tool. What it has is a note offset, so I started playing with that. I could not seem to find a setting that felt right. Part of it was not being used to using a keyboard, but the timing was definitely slightly off no matter what I did. I had the frame rate capped at 144fps in the game options, which matches my monitor's refresh rate. I found that when I capped at 60, the game felt fine. This isn't an acceptable solution, so I tried something else. I capped the framerate at 240 (there's no unlimited option) and used RTSS to cap me at 144. The game now plays perfectly and I get a smooth 144fps (EDIT: changed to 143 fps. Imperceptible visually but kept frametime smooth at 6.9ms rather than a 6.9ms-7.3ms variance at 144). Capping in-game was getting me an uneven 140-143fps and causing the timing to always be a little off. My system specs are 2080 Ti, i7-9700k, 16GB Ram and the game is on a quality SSD drive. I was reading some people were having lag issues with Nvidia cards.

TL;DR: Don't cap your framerate with the in-game limiter option. Cap at 240 (max limit) and use an outside frame limiter. I recommend RivaTuner Statistics Server (RTSS). My game works perfectly now.

The DJMAX series has long been king of the insane hardcore rhythm game genre (at least as far as I'm concerned) and this remains true.  While I am a fan of the series, I am not of this particular title, because how iterative it is, its bad music, and its overpriced DLCs.

Over the last decade, the presentation of DJMAX has barely changed; I can completely see Respect V running on a PS3. There's no notable new feature (edit: I just realized in game comment is a new feature, but... it's just commenting. It shouldn't really count), most of the songs are from old games, and honestly the devs barely had to do any work for this new title (besides porting the content between platforms, but that's not new content). Speaking of which, I have found that the vast majority of the music are only mediocre to decent. It seems to me like the composers did not work with the goal of making the music good, but rather making it have lots of notes so that it is difficult to play. Of course music is completely subjective, but I have to wonder if anyone liked the song that's just lots of synthetic dog noises (besides as a joke).

I also found the number of DLCs and their pricings to be excessive. Not only is there just a lot of them, but there are also two pricing policies: some song packs are $13, whereas others are $26 because they bundle the music download along with access to them in game. Suspiciously my favorite game in the franchise is in the more expensive camp. I don't know about the community's opinion but for me those are the best tracks in the series, and if the devs are deliberately charging more for popular tracks that's a really scummy behavior. And even if this is just a coincidence, taking choice away from the customer is still inherently anti consumer.

Probably the most in-depth, well made, and up to date Mania-style game available on PC. Extremely satisfying gameplay, plenty of customization, and a lot of collectibles for the completionists out there. This game has more songs than any other rhythm game I've played on Steam, and each one is charted in a way that's incredibly fun to play.

There is however, a very crucial issue with timing on some computers. This may have a workaround fix by turning VSYNC off in-game or through your GPU directly. Some of the DLC is also a bit expensive, but in my opinion the experience and hours you can get out of this game is all worth every penny.

Another thing to note, the game cannot be played offline. To most people this shouldn't necessarily be a huge problem since people on Steam typically have internet access. But this does mean if the server goes on maintenance of any kind you will not be able to play during that time. This also unfortunately means if they decide to shut down the servers you will likely no longer be able to play this game you paid for.

In the end of the day, this is still a very good game that I personally love. If you have the money and enjoy games like these, please do yourself and the rhythm game community a favor and pay for a well-made game like this instead of supporting a f2p game with stolen content.

I have never in my life had to make a recommendation with so many caveats but sometimes life sneaks up on you. I played a ton of DJMax Fever and then moved on to playing Portable 1st, 2nd, and 3rd on a jailbroken PSP about a decade ago. Hearing that there was going to be a localized DJMax game in the States in 2020 was a dream come true and, in a lot of ways, this game delivers on what I would want from it. The UI is snappy, the new songs are all bangers, mission mode supplies a ton of challenges, and AIR mode brings some of the best features of modern rhythm games into the fold. 

However

It is hard not to feel like DJMax Respect / V is a vector for more monetization down the road. There is a lengthy process to unlocking all the songs in the base game... unless you want to buy an unlock key from the store for real money. If you want to play certain songs from the older games (like the NB Rangers tracks) you'll have to grind through levels to obtain them. The DLC that was added into the PS4 version of the game from years ago is still being resold in V for full price. The release schedule of these catch-up DLCs has been thankfully brisk, but it doesn't change the feeling of the game being unfinished. Like the version you paid $50 has only half the songs available and the other half is going to be worth more than the game itself. 

If the plan is for V to be a platform that will eventually contain the complete collection of DJMax's history, remastered and updated for the modern era, it is understandable that paying out all that licencing takes a bit of extra cash. I think that's an understandable situation. However, it is hard to recommend jumping into the game when you are constantly reminded of what your full price entry fee does *not* get you access to. 

Also, the menus only have HUD elements for keyboard with no toggle to show versions for navigating with controller even though this is a port of a PS4 game. Just a weird little nibble there.

DJMax Respect V is like a well-polished version of DJMax Respect for PS4. They replaced Arcade mode with Air mode, added a new 1v1 ranked game mode, and now you can play with up to 6 other people together in one party online!

The songs are amazing and the genres are very diverse, and one of the biggest things about DJMax is that most of the songs have "keysounds" so you can really hear what you're playing which can really help.

I mainly recommend this game because of the addictive gameplay. You can play by using 4 buttons/keys, 5, 6, or 8 so It's great for beginners to the genre, but it's also really enjoyable for rhythm game veterans because the skill ceiling for this game is extremely high. They also have a difficulty called "SC" (stands for Super Crazy) which is of course, pretty crazy. On top of that there are tons of "effectors" and other ways to keep increasing the difficulty if you want

As a casual rhythm game player who has played and enjoyed most of the Guitar Hero games, some Rock Band and Tapsonic World Tour on mobile I was lured into purchasing DJMAX Respect V on pc. I have to say, I am quite disappointed and really wish that I had not wasted my money on this game. The interface is ok and the custom videos that play in the background are nice but that's about it.

I have two main annoyances with this game. Firstly, there is no difficulty setting, you cannot choose to play any song and then set it to easy, normal, hard, expert like you can on their mobile game 'Tapsonic World Tour'. The only thing that you can do is increase or decrease the tempo which does not help in making it easier to hit the buttons as you still need to hit the complicated layout of buttons. Unfortunately, it seems that this game is aimed towards relatively high skilled players/younger people who have quick reflexes. Therefore, if you would simply like to progress through the missions then you are out of luck as very early on it gets quite difficult and you will run into a wall, unable to progress. I really don't understand why Neowiz did not add a difficulty setting, to me it makes the game too hard, ruins the experience and makes it near unplayable. 

Secondly, if you are a low skilled player like myself and want to play the 'online' mode using 4 buttons then good luck finding another real person to play with. Every time I have attempted to play online I am always matched against a bot called D.Penguin or C.Penguin. Only once was I matched against a real player and their skill was clearly above mine, making the matchmaking system seem unfair and pointless. 

To conclude, even if you are quite a good player on Guitar Hero, Rock Band or rhythm games on mobile I would be extremely about purchasing this game, DJmax is very difficult compared to other rhythm games. Being able to change the difficulty setting is a very basic function that nearly all rhythm games have but for whatever reason, Neowiz failed to implement this basic feature.
