Previously I noted that this was a "Brilliant return of the DJMAX Franchise on PC, if I say so myself!" And while I am still happy that they've returned, playing since release and seeing the quality drift slowly downward with each update is rather alarming.

We have had at least half a dozen updates that would cause the game's FPS to become choppy at best. Anyone whose played a music game knows that framedrops are the absolute worst thing that could happen. And this happens every. Other. Update. 

Additionally, the game's DRM requires it to be constantly online, and is to say the least, a notoriously bad DRM. One that really ought to be left out like it was in the PS4 edition. 

As someone who had played the PS4 version and loved it to bits, only to see various functions get chopped in light of this version releasing, it has made my viewpoint on the developers slowly but surely drop as well. While this is the closest to true arcade-y Beatmania-esqe gameplay you can get on the Steam store....the instability of the game alongside the need to constantly shell out money for new songs gives it a very shaky lifespan at best. Grab it while it's on discount but don't expect it to be the best thing ever. 

Now that being said, I do still enjoy the game, but...I'm losing hope in it. Not to mention they changed the already substantial judgement timing so now I can't even play music half as accurately as I used to. Songs I'd get S rank on are barely hitting A rank now, amongst the fact my RTX 2070 somehow doesn't give me full frames after some updates. The optimization is a major issue, as well as a removal of functions that're EXCEEDINGLY important to quality of life, such as audio tuning. 

Moving on....online gameplay is exceedingly unstable. I also tried playing ranked matches only to be ALWAYS matched up against a bot. At any rate the game might as well be offline besides the times where I can play online without glitches reminiscent of the DJMAX Online (2004) days...if you can't outdo Osu, whom of which is free, why even bother bringing DJMAX back to PC anyway? 

Aaaaaanywho, that's how my stance is nowadays. I previously gave this game a glowing review, but after seeing everything that's happened to it, it makes me wonder why the hell did they did to a game that launched in a perfectly stable fashion.

There's a huge inconsistency in gameplay experience between songs that are keysounded and those that aren't. For me, it's super easy to get disoriented by mistimed keysounds that play even when you hit the note perfectly. Most notes are short and only require a single input, but musical notes vary much more especially with reverb or intensity. What I found is that if you lift off the key too early, it stops the keysound playback completely which causes notes that have reverb to sound hollow, and results in the music sounding unnatural or off-tune/time. There's no real way to figure out how long to hold down those keysounded keys for other than to keep playing it over and over until you figure it out. The problem with this is that it was my first time hearing many of these songs and I don't know how long to hold the key down. This basically led to me just holding down each note as long as I possibly could which also affected my ability to hit subsequent notes accurately. Ultimately the presence of keysounded notes is a rhythm game mechanic I find more disruptive than immersive. I looked online and have read that some people are actually a fan of this, but I am not one of those people.

Among other many other rhythm games, I used to play EZ2DJ at the arcade for years as a kid, the DJ Max titles on PSP and later grabbed TapSonic and the other DJ Max titles for mobile devices. I'm happy to have this on PC too, look and feels superb.

As a long time fan of this game on PS4 I can say that the game in it's current state is a contender for best rhythm game on PC. It was lacking a bit of polish and features on launch, but almost all of the problems have been ironed out to match the console version. It's a very straight-forward rhythm game with few gimmicks, but the core gameplay is solid and the steady progression of unlocks is enough to want you to play more songs and do the challenges (which get quite difficult later on). My only complaint is that, like the console version, the DLC is quite expensive and some of the best songs are locked behind it. New features like a keyboard-specific difficulty level and the fun community-driven AIR mode make this a great purchase even if you own the console version.

Initially I gave this game a bad review but they patched the game.
The game runs smoothly with no major hiccups.

With the removal of many game-changing features, which as the essential audio adjust feature (which worked SIGNIFICANTLY better), from the PS4 version, the future of Respect V's features are in jeopardy. Necessary features for rhythm games to be deemed "competent" such as a means to combat audio/visual latency, can now vanish without a word of warning. The new half-baked "audio adjust" (if you can really call it that) mechanics and the absence of fast/slow notifications in V were probably warning sign for things to come. Random M/V in Collection Mode being removed from PS4 means that Air Mode on V could be on the chopping block any day now. You can no longer "try before you buy" songs and DLCs with friends via online. There's no certainty that even songs that YOU, the CLIENT (not consumer), have already paid for being around forever, as they might just decide one day that keeping the Clazziquai licenses aren't worth the trouble anymore.

The content culling from the PS4 version not only destroyed nearly 3 years of good faith from the community, but it makes the future of V uncertain, since I have no doubt that speed mods, BGAs, and keysounds are also at the mercy of patents. The plug could be pulled on many features, and maybe a few years down the line, the game itself. Content can be purged without a moment's notice. PURCHASE AT YOUR OWN RISK.

The game already felt incredibly polished, and they just pushed an update further eliminating latency. This is honestly an amazing game, and I'd fully recommend it to anyone.

v492: I have not found this version to significantly improve the input delay, despite their attempts to improve it specifically in this update. I still find it to be within 50-100ms, which is not different from it was before. However, I do appreciate the devs' effort in looking into the issue. Unfortunately, much of the problem stems from the standard ways of playing sounds on the Windows OS, which is why this problem is so hard to fix.

v162 AND LATER: The input delay definitely has been improved significantly as stated in the patch notes. I would say it's around 50-100ms, which equates to about a 16th beat on most songs. This is much more manageable, and I think many experienced rhythm gamers will not have a problem with it. However, there is still room for improvement; DJMax Trilogy, a decade-old game, had practically zero input delay on its hitsounds, and I want to push modern rhythm games to achieve that standard again.

EA RELEASE REVIEW: The input delay of hitsounds on this game is unplayably frustrating on higher difficulties. It is in the magnitude of hundreds of milliseconds, and if you can hear your keyboard or controller in the slightest bit you will be able to tell that your keypresses are happening a beat or even two beats behind the music. I would not recommend this for rhythm game experts, or anyone who considers themselves remotely a hardcore rhythm gamer in general.

For casual players who like chilling to lower difficulties, this game is very polished and contains a trove of classics and newer hits built up through the long history of the DJMax series.

Okay let's get the first get one thing out of the way - the price tag.

TL:DR; Game is fun, but it really is quite expensive.

It is HELLA high. Not even considering that each music pack dlc is at least 25USD, but usually much higher. I haven't done enough research in terms of the cost consequences of it being a music game - Licensing, Commission for artists, etc, but the game as a game is really expensive.

So let's talk gameplay. The actual music gameplay is what it always has been if you've played Djmax. Some songs have fun songsheets to play through, and the existence of 4 keys, 5 keys, 6 keys, and 8 keys for each song means your favourite song will continue to have depth through the difficulties. I could go on and on about how fun this core gameplay loop is, but if you're considering buying this game purely on whether the songs and gameplay is fun - then you can stop reading here and buy the game. 

So let's go into why I'm hesitant to ask you to buy this game. Since it's a music game, your preference in song choice will largely determine whether the game is fun for you or not. This is where the price of the game comes into play again. From my experience, each DLC has had maybe 5-7ish songs that I really liked (depending on the size of the DLC as well), and it doesn't seem to me that each DLC has a very specific genre it's pulling from, it's usually just a collage of songs from a previous DJmax game. So paying 30 bucks for 5 more songs to play sounds reasonable to some, but I can definitely understand why most wouldn't enjoy that pricetag. 

Normally, i'd say DLC isn't very important to a game anyway, but this music pack DLC can be important because it could contain a song that you've played (and enjoyed) in the past, or just a song that comes highly recommended by the community, or just a song that you really like and wish to play - and people will say 'ah but if its expensive just don't get it' but I don't think that's really valid. You might end up with feelings of an incomplete game, or just 'i really wish i could play that song', and so on and on. 

Lastly, I think the peripherals that you unlock (i.e. gallery images, gear skins, note skins,) etc. are a nice addition but don't really contribute meaningfully to the gameplay experience, except some gear and note skins. I won't really go into the different modes of gameplay, since I think they just boil down to different ways to play the songs included in the game. 

To conclude, yeah this game is fun. Get it, but only if you either really like rhythm games or if you have a disposable income - even after enjoying it I feel like I can't justify this price tag to a newcomer to the genre or to someone who isn't earning too much.

Expensive as hell, and the timing adjustment options need a huge overall, but it's still a good ass game with a ton of good music, and fun to play.

Update: The sync gets worse with each update. Don't play competitively if you don't want to be frustrated.

If you ever played the old DJMAX games on PSP or are interested in Beatmania or other similar games, this game is excellent.  It has all the songs from the old DJMAX games, but only the songs from 1 & 2 are included alongside a set of new tracks for this game.  The rest need to be bought separately.

If you never played the older games in the series, this game is still definitely worth picking up if you like rhythm games at all.  Almost every song is keysounded (exceptions including a few western licensed tracks) and the engine is tuned for PC.  The soundtrack is mostly K-Pop and other stuff you've likely never heard before if you're not already familiar with the series, but there are some real bangers on the OST with even more available through the DLC.

The price tag may be a little bit on the high side for Rhythm games available on Steam, but it's seriously worth it for the wealth of content and continued support the game has received.

DJMAX RESPECT V is essentially a port of the PS4 game "DJMAX RESPECT" with a few minor alterations and a new competitive multiplayer mode. The core rhythm game works extremely well and there are no missed inputs or noticeable delay in timing.

Pros: 
- Many difficulties for every song, so the game can be enjoyed by newcomers and experts alike
- The song selection is varied and has music for everyone
- Every song has an animation in the background and they are all high quality

Cons:
- The game uses DRM which requires a constant internet connection to play
- The unlocking process is extremely slow and requires a lot of grinding, which was clearly done to try to get players to pay to unlock everything early
Only for you

DJMAX Respect V is an incredibly fun rhythm game, featuring a very wide variety of music, from rock to electronic, a bit of reggae and even some K/JPop (there's a lot more genres than these alone)! DJMax is a vertical side-scrolling rhythm game where you hit a key to the beat of the music. It's a forgiving game in terms of accuracy (seriously, you have 1, 10, --> 90, 100% and then misses) and you can play with 4 keys, up to a maximum of 8. I admittedly have played it once on my phone, some years ago, but it pales in comparison to a console version. Admittedly, the one thing I have against it right now is that ladder matches will put you up against bots (they will be D.Penguin, C.Penguin, etc) if it can't find anyone to match you with.. Spending 15 minutes in ladder matches easily put me at gold 4 just due to this alone. Honestly, I recommend it, it feels very worth the base price. I'd also recommend picking up a few DLC packs as they will expand your library, and let you live that nostalgia of some older songs in the series as well.

[h1]Summary[/h1]

I must say I did not expect to be so addicted to this when I bought it. It feels incredible playing this, even though it is hard at first until you get the hold of it. Even though I knew about only 4 or 5 songs in the game, all of the songs present are pleasant and lovely to play. The game challenges you to how quick can you fail.

Notes about other reviews:

[b]Game overpriced?[\b]
No. DJMAX RESPECT V is not overpriced. We must get out of the shell and realize that using such songs, even though DJMAX does own some of the songs in it, costs money to them as copyrighted content. So, part of the money you pay in this game should go to the original content creators. If you find this game to be expensive, get it on sales.

[b]Game takes too long to detect pressed notes?[/b]
As an instrument player, I can say the game DOES NOT HAVE ANY LAG at all. In fact, it has one good timing about how precise are your hits. Things like these you can pick up by ear and just accept that you missed it.

Overall rating is 9.5

[h1][b]Rating[/b][/h1]

[table]
    [tr]
        [td]Engine[/td]

[/table]

[h1]Engine/Smoothness/Gameplay[/h1]

As I said before, I found no lags or bugs at all.

The gameplay is simple but awesome at its finest. Within a few days (or hours) of playing, you should already see you improved a lot, enough to take on harder levels. When DJMAX says the song is hard, it is, believe me. Even though I'm new at this, I'm loving it.
One issue I have however, are the flashy BCA (Background animations) which can get you quite on a surprise. Please, DO NOT PLAY THIS GAME if you have epilepsy backgrounds. DJMAX RESPECT V does give us the chance to disable the background animations at any time, which is nice.

DJMAX gives us a giant set of difficulty customization which ranges from speed to quantity of things happening at once. Find the most suitable for a start and keep improving.

[h1]Graphics[/h1]

The animations of this game, while not common, are well put. You might get confused at first with a lot of things happening at once when you're playing but, once you settle in, you'll find that all the information that they give is actually useful. 

[h1][b]Final rating[/b]:   9.5 [/h1]

It's DJMax Respect, a brilliant must-have rhythm game, but for PC. With its huge variety of music, wide difficulty range, and different playstyles (4/5/6/8 button modes, plus the option to use keyboard or controller), there's something for rhythm game fans of all music tastes and skill levels.

Overall: Excellent recommendation for beginners and experienced players alike. Love being able to see all of my old favourite songs back on the PC. Can be a bit grind-y to unlock all songs, but you start with like 30 available (1 level = 1 unlocked song), but I was able to level quickly (likely related to difficulty). I mostly play FreeStyle mode.

My Pros:
- huge song selection & many different genres, as it's a collection of most of their previous DJMAX games
- great control over difficulty: most songs will have an easy/medium/hard/extreme in addition to number of keys needed to play (minimum 4) and the speed of the notes approaching the screen
- each note played corresponds to a certain sound within the song (ex. drums, melody) rather than a generic hi-hat noise
- menu music and animations are killer (overall visual design is suiting; clean)
- can "preview" music (listen to part of the song) before committing to play it
- customize-able notes & gear (the playing area), as with all DJMAX series
- all "modes" available in the Menu have their own unique, great music. Even getting a "Game Over" isn't bad and I never feel like I "lose", even if I don't do as good as I want
- the introduction song (Boom!) has great animation. Can't take my eyes off it. (though I hear some people don't like the song... I don't mind it, personally)
- able to adjust "brightness" unique to each song (MusicVideos play in the background while you play), or you have the choice to turn MusicVideos off.
- seizure/photo-sensitive warning upon startup of game, I'm glad they brought attention to that
- they feature/collab with a few better-known artists (ex. Porter Robinson, Marshmallow, K/DA League, Guilty Gear)

My Cons:
- minor: some of the difficulty ratings can be misleading (ex. one song may be 13/15 difficulty and seem easier than a song with 11/15 difficulty [that's exaggeration and I can't name a particular example rn but along those lines])
- minor: featured song when entering FreeStyle cannot be changed (but occasionally updates to a different track anyway)
- upon first play, the playing area is set in the middle. Do yourself a favour and move it to the left (or right) to see the Music Videos
- probably controller, but that ain't my problem. They recommend keyboard anyways sooo
- minor: can be initially difficult to adjust to a dead front-faced play-area (if you're previously used to music mobile games that incline the play-area)
- if you're into downloading playing-maps/other songs... go somewhere else.

I really want to be able to recommend this game. DJMAX is a great series with fun gameplay and it's a shame I feel like I can't recommend this title. Having to always be online is absolutely ridiculous when all you want to do is play some songs and the inclusion of Xigncode3 is disappointing. It's such an invasive software that has basically no regard for your privacy, so if you download this game keep that in mind. If you really want to play DJMAX, you should play on a Playstation. If you want a better alternative, osu!Mania is the way to go. If these things change, I'll gladly recommend this game, but as it stands now, I recommend you stay away.

The game is great, i like the presentation and the polish on all of it, the music is fun and i found a surprising amount of it jammin enough to rock my head to. there are a lot of difficulty options and ways to play, this is great so that anyone can play the game and feel good about how they are doing.

unfortunately my praise ends here. the game uses an invasive anticheat DRM called XIGNCODE 3. hey, what gives? it stops cheaters from flooding the leaderboards with 999999 score entries and all that right? how is it bad? well this system operates at what is called the "kernel level" where most things, including the exe the game itself runs at the "user level", which means more privileges and priority to the inner kernel level. this system is one of the first things to load up as you turn your computer on. in other reviews, you can see issues people have that this DRM is causing... causing to legitimate, paying customers that just wanted to play the game, and if you are able to play as expected, the DRM may still take up resources that could go to the game, impacting your performance or causing input delay (in a rhythm game!!) 

also you need an internet connection to play the game at all times, regardless of what you're doing, so sorry if you wanted to jam real quick on your laptop on public transit. all this to stop some cheaters... and what do we get for paying for a product we expected certain things from? it is even risky to have installed and launched the game once... you're worried about cheaters, what about hackers that are looking for security vulnerabilities to get into things they shouldn't (and would have one less possible avenue if not for this anticheat system) so if you played on this past free weekend in the middle of may and bought the game in earnest, and learned these things afterwards... well

where it counts, this is a fine game and i was genuinely enjoying my time playing it. invasive anticheat DRM needs to stop trying to become a thing. us paying customers are not getting what we deserve with these invasive systems that don't even work most of the time (there are still cheaters in riot's valorant and they have a very similar anticheat system in their game) plus you can see how many denuvo games get cracked, sometimes before they officially come out

I would love to overturn or delete this negative review for this game, i hate to see so much great art and hard work and talent go out with the bathwater... perhaps someday if XIGNCODE 3 is removed.

DJMAX Respect V is the latest in the DJMAX series. It plays like your normal mania game with the addition of side notes (2 extra keys to watch out for). 
If you want to play a mania game on a controller, most of the charts are made for that (ps4 port), however if you're used to keyboard the maps will seem fairly simple. "SC" is the difficulty made for keyboard and a lot of the charts in that range aren't as high quality. The main pitch for the game is in the exclusive videos to songs you may like.
Some of the main issues that stuck out to me are:
-Lack of a friends leaderboard
-No custom chart support officially, that could be a pro or a con depending on player.
-Always online DRM that installs itself as a system driver, very invasive.

After trying it on the free weekend i decided to buy it, if you'd rather a more casual mania game it can be pretty fun. AIR mode especially is easy to just hop into to play random songs. If you're looking for a game with a higher skill ceiling i'd have to recommend checking out the alternatives instead.

Solid Game. I‚Äôm a 4K player, so the main gripe I have over the game is the lack of content for price.

Some people complain about xigncode3 and the always online DRM. Although I share the sentiments about always online DRM (some people have had server connection issues which made the game unplayable), xigncode is not as evil as others claim it to be. Yes, it runs on kernel-level access. But what anticheat doesn‚Äôt run with those permissions nowadays? Assuming they want to maintain some semblance of ranked integrity (though I doubt people really care about ranked), they would be using some version of anticheat (there are worse offenders that exist).  Kernel level anticheats do deter a significant amount of easily-made cheats. They do work, but they aren‚Äôt flawless either.

Yes, it sucks that you have to download it to play.
Yes, you‚Äôre free to make the decision to not download the  game if you don‚Äôt agree with their practices
But, I‚Äôd like if people stopped the continual fear-mongering that I keep seeing in the review section.

More than likely, you‚Äôve already given an anti-cheat that you don‚Äôt know about kernel access.
Have Valorant installed? 
How about Apex Legends, Fortnite, or PUBG?
Chances are, you already have a ring 0 ‚Äúrootkit‚Äù already installed in your computer.

If you don‚Äôt like the company‚Äôs practices, that‚Äôs fine. Just don't spread blatant misinformation. For those who don't understand, educate yourself. 

Find out what Xigncode3 does and then compare it to all other existing kernel-level anticheats. You'll see that a similar amount of "privacy" and "danger" concerns exists in all. 

Unlike some other anticheats, xigncode does not continue running after the game closes and seems to actually be less impactful on the games performance than a lot of others.

In the end, 99% of all decisions boils down to trust. Do I trust this program enough to install it onto my computer? The answer is usually a questionable maybe, but with more and more multiplayer games adding "invasive" anti-cheats to their products it becomes unavoidable. 

Know that those who passionately despise anti-cheat will voice their opinions 10 times as loud as the general playerbase.

Fun Rhythm Game with lots of content. Here's some Pro's and cons

Pros:
+ Large and Varied Soundtrack. 
+ DLC Packs have great tracks as well.
+ Graphics and Eye candy are mint
+ Multiple Game modes and key modes to accommodate most playstyles and allows learning of other ones as well. 
+ Multiplayer is fun.
+ Many Cosmetics and personalization options. 

Cons: 
- Always Online. Shouldn't say more to be honest. Any time logins don't work or the servers are down, nobody can play. 
- Offset options don't work according to multiple other players. +0 works fine for me but it doesn't for everyone and it alienates those people. 
- Even if Offset did work, there's no offset wizard or other ways to test your offset. Stepmania, Osu, Crypt of the necrodancer all have that feature.
- Side Buttons aren't toggleable. I just think it would but a fun way to relive the classic DJMAX gameplay.
- Invasive Anti-cheat. Many games are taking this route but I'm still not a fan of it personally. Just something to consider
- Ranked placements are done against bots. Big miss

Also Disclaimer. Don't buy the unlock pack. Like others said, you can Idle Air mode for XP.

TL;DR A must have for anyone who claims to love music games. Love it or not, if you enjoy pushing buttons to music, this game is a worthy addition to your resume, but purchase it with trepidation as there may be one or more technical flaws that can ruin the fun.

Pros:
-Quality music and videos spanning a much wider base of genres than is typical for most rhythm games
-Quality and consistent note charting
-A wide library of content spanning multiple generations of platforms including Playstation, PC, and the Arcade dating all the way back to 2006 with new content planned for the future in addition to backlogged DLC from the PS4 version as of this review.
-4 different button modes to suit your preference

Divisive: These "features" you may love or hate
-Keysounding. The "Emotional Sense" tagline of games past stems from the interactive keysounds, which trigger when you press notes and are reflections of actual sound samples used in the song. We're not talking generic Guitar Hero biffs, you can actually improvise music while playing if you get creative with it.
-DRM and Always Online play model. Most people don't care, but some people are very sensitive about whether or not they're being spied on. This game requires you to install Xigncode, an anti-cheat and product authentication application which has access to deep levels of your computer and could plausibly be used to send information you would rather keep private to other people. Additionally, at this time you are unable to play this game if you don't have an internet connection, as all your gameplay information and preferences are stored online.

Cons:
-Synchronization issues: Because of the keysounded nature of the game, Respect is sensitive to DPC latency. Your hardware and drivers may cause audio lag which is, as of now, unfixable. Keysounds *cannot* be disabled or muted and the added "Sync Offset" option causes more problems than it solves. If your device(s) experience lag, you're just SOL.
-Sharing - Or lack thereof. Family Sharing only allows users to experience the base game and its 170-ish songs. If you bought the DLC, your mom and dad can't play it on their account. If you play online against other players, you'll need to own the DLC for the song being chosen or you'll be forced into Observer mode, which is unlike the PlayStation 4 counterpart that allows players to "share" content they own with someone who *doesn't* own it.
-No local multiplayer (yet).

The price tag threw me off at first, but after playing I'm convinced it's absolutely worth every penny.

The UI is absolutely gorgeous, the music selection isn't bad at all, and it has something for everyone from super casual players in Air Mode, combo/score chasers in Freestyle, or more structured play in Mission Mode.

My favorite mode is probably Air mode, where songs are automatically selected for you one after another, messages from players are shown in the background video, and you're allowed to stop at any time to write a little message or take a quick break while the game continues to autoplay for you. Scores don't matter, you aren't ranked or scored outside of keeping a combo, and it's perfect for just relaxing and tapping out some charts.

The PS4 version of this game is fantastic, and along with Project Diva: Future Tone, among the best console rhythm games. This PC port has some issues that mean I can't recommend it.

There is no option to automatically configure timing offset/input lag. You have to set this manually through trial and error, which can be very difficult.

If you have to adjust this setting so that the note charts match up with the song audio, the game becomes unplayable, as hitting notes triggers in-game audio samples (notesounds), which aren't adjusted by the options. This means that these sounds are out of sync with the rest of the game. I have the offset at +100ms, by which point these sounds are so out of sync with the rest of the track that the songs become a mess.

I've tried various diferent in-game settings, graphics card settings, troubleshooting on forums, emailing the devs (no response), but as of yet there doesn't seem to be a solution to this.

Started the series on the Online version waaay back in the 2000s, gone through Portable 1 and 2, CE + BS, Portable 3 through high-school, and a few others afterwards (even the controversial Tune, Tap Sonic and mobile games).

After the devs finally caved in on the numerous suggestion to bring over DJMax on Steam (glaring at you Trilogy), finally at my age of 30 I get to see my dream rhythm game reborn from the ashes of obscurity. So yes, I am reviewing this game as a fan, so take from it what you will.

The game and UI is well polished (those lovely crisp HD graphics *mwah*), but certain nitpicks do come to mind.
-Some songs (especially the older ones) have weird volume mixes, like vocals being too quiet compared to the rest, or effect notes being a tad bit too loud that it deafens the backing track, etc.
-Notes coming down at very high speeds still have that after image problem (so it looks like 2 notes are falling at the same time). It's less noticeable than Trilogy, but still present.
-XignCode (though, many Korean MMORPGs use it as anti tamper measures so i can understand why they chose it)

Other than that, the game is what I wanted, which is a PC version of DJMax reborn, with many of my nostalgic tunes added in the game, and many other songs available as DLC.

If you're an old fan like me, you will not regret buying the game. If you're new to the series, and was in the market for a decent rhythm game, check some gameplay videos and the OST. If you like what you see and hear, you know what to do. If you think the MVs are corny as fuck (don't worry, I do too), no worries you can turn those off.

The PS4 version of this game is hands down the best way to get into hardcore rhythm games, especially if you wait for a sale on the DLC. Good variety of music written specifically for the game, good range of difficulty levels, and a Mission mode that gives you a semi-guided way to gain XP and improve at the game. Lots of DLC, but this is due to this game's goal of integrating content from the entire series into one entry.

The PC version, while having exclusive content, makes several missteps that make this version difficult to recommend. EDIT: with the introduction of the Respect V DLC to the PS4 game, the only content exclusive to the PC version are the keyboard-specific SC charts and the expanded Multiplayer systems.

Air mode has completely replaced Arcade mode rather than being an additional mode. Air mode chooses songs 100% randomly, but with Nico Nico Douga-style pre-recorded comments scrolling across the background. It's interesting if you just want to throw some music on in the background. But Arcade mode used to be the most reliable way to play songs you haven't unlocked yet - you are given a list of 30 or so randomly chosen songs and can pick which one to play. This made having to grind XP to unlock songs permanently much more palatable, as if there was that one song you really wanted to play, you could finesse your way into it. Now if you don't like the starting song list, you're shit out of luck.

New songs were made for the PC release, but implemented as $20 DLC you have to buy separately. Honestly if you just made the base game more expensive and included these songs, the game would be a much easier sell. Customers nowadays are VERY wary of launch day DLC and opening with $80 worth of DLC for a $40 dollar game raises serious red flags.

Finally, the game uses the infamous XIGNCODE3 DRM often seen in Korean MMOs. I don't have much knowledge of this DRM personally, but from what I've seen online it is FAR more invasive than average, so those concerned with keeping their computer usage private may want to do some reading before installing this game.

I was ready for this game to come out of early access so that I could wholeheartedly recommend it as the face of modern Asian Rhythm Games, the presentation is just so top notch. But they've introduced so many little gotchas into the new player experience that unless you're already a nutter for the genre I can't guarantee you'll enjoy the game enough for it to be worth the effort. It's a god damned shame, I tell ya what.

Simply put, it's one of the best rhythm games there is and easily my favorite one. It's probably also one of the toughest at the higher levels. That said, it has a great range of difficulties and modes for people of all skill levels. 4 Button normal mode is a great place to start for new players. As you get better, you'll be sure to notice and be able to move up to 5, 6, or maybe even 8 button modes. 

It is so satisfying to nail a song, get a full combo, or get on a hot streak of perfectly timed notes. If you remotely enjoy rhythm games, this is a great one to play.  And there are so many songs, even without buying the DLC.

You can play with controllers (Playstation is recommended, generally) or keyboard.
If you like beat matching games, like Guitar Hero or Rock Band, you'll enjoy this. If you've ever been into Beatmania (like me), you'll absolutely love it. Plenty of content for the price.

Let me preface this by saying DJMAX was one of the most important things to happen to me. I started playing with Technika in 2009, and met a majority of my best friends playing it. Without DJMAX I wouldn't be the person I am today. I can't understate how important those friendships were to me. I picked up all the PSP games, and bought and played Respect and all of it's DLC on the PS4.

I had multiple level 14 Perfect Plays on the PS4 version of the game, and had a good number of top 50/top 25 scores. I was extremely excited for the PC release of DJMAX Respect! All of the announcements relating to Respect V sounded amazing between some Porter Robinson licenses and ranked matchmaking! However when the game launched into early access the game felt unplayable. There was no timing adjustment setting and the game felt unplayable on my PC, but I gave the developers the benefit of the doubt because the game was in early access. However, a month or so passed by and my prayers were answered! The devs patched in a timing adjustment system, meaning I should be able to play!

Unfortunately, the SOLE reason I cannot recommend this game is because the timing adjustment system DOES NOT WORK. The way the system works is it adjusts the position of the notes forwards or backwards, but the game has keysounded notes, meaning the sounds made by hitting notes on time is now offsync with the backing music. The game punishes you if you need to adjust your timing windows to fit your preferences, yet other keysounded games can get away with having timing adjustment without ruining the music. I cannot repeat this enough: THE GAME IS UNPLAYABLE IF YOU CAN'T GET USED TO THE VANILLA TIMING. THE TIMING ADJUSTMENT SYSTEM IN THE GAME DOES NOT WORK. I have been holding onto the idea of posting a review here because the game was in early access, and I was giving the developers the benefit of the doubt because the game was in early access. The game is no longer in early access though, so that excuse doesn't hold ground anymore.

tl;dr: If you're a seasoned music game player, do not bother picking up this game. The timing adjustment system in the game causes the keysounds to be offsync with the backing music, making the game unplayable unless you can play without adjusting your offset, which is a crapshoot because everyone's setup is different.

Possibly the best rhythm game on steam to date. This was my first entry in the DJMAX series so it took a while to jump from 4 buttons to 8, but the progression is such a journey. We already have to work hard to clear harder songs, but the complexity of 6B and 8B give the game a whole new flavor. It feels good to get better results, and many of these tracks are challenging but force you to sharpen your skills. I also wasn't too familiar with the track list, but 4 days in and i had plenty of favs. Try this out if you love a good challenge.

As someone who played DJMax since its Korean releases on PSP, This game is pretty much what you get, a collection of songs across DJMax library (90% keysounded or so, 10% are newer stuff and licenses) with DLC from releases to become a catalog to respect the franchise.

Graphics: Looks great, plays great, but I've notice some tearing on linear notes due to differences in frame rate to monitor refresh, I've used this monitor for other games like musynx and tapsonic and this is the only one I get it on. Mods that effect visuals looks spot on, and I think sharpness is higher than its PS4 counter part.

Gameplay: You get 4 modes, (4/5/6/8k) and your looking at around 100 songs or so from the base purchase. Difficulties are varied for all skill levels to enter. Ladder mode is not popular but removes the fever system for a purely accuracy level of points (score is still a winner, so breaks vs 90's do effect the outcome.) Open lobbies allow up to 7 players to play (or spectate) lobbies and you can play whatever key/difficulty chart for the song selected [YOU must own it, no DLC sharing like on PS4]

HOWEVER, the PS4 was a specific spec so timing is spot on, this version seems to have widened them a bit to account for the multitude of system configurations available. This means that once you've reached a level of mastery, you'll be throwing 99.9X's all over the game. People pretty much can PP any song on demand and those who've mastered tighter timing windows should probably avoid this game unless you love and support the game and the music.

Air mode plays songs in a somewhat ABC order, free style lets you play whatever you want, and missions shake up the game so your playing upside down with fog and every lane on its own speed.

Enjoyment: I love the game, the music is good but I've heard it for 20 years now. New content has something for everyone. DJMAX has been one of the big series in the classic rhythm game industry (or as people call it, mania-like games) and this is their third return to the PC platform, after DJMAX Online and DJMAX Trilogy. 
If you were a fan of the series, and you do not have a PS4, this game should be a must buy to try it out. If you already own the PS4 version, you might want to consider first before buying this game.
If you are new to the classic rhythm games (mania type), or just a casual player, I would argue that this game is a perfect place to start with because it is easier than other more hardcore games out there. (IIDX, O2Jam, EZ2DJ, etc)

Anyway, on to the actual review of the product. It is important to note that this game is currently in early access, and is also a direct port of the PS4 version, which is why I mentioned that PS4 owners that already own this game on PS4 may want to reconsider buying this again, because you will be getting similar experience. Since the game is in early access, some features such as online play, missions and arcade are currently missing.


Pros:
+ Large library of songs to choose from. The base game contains all the songs from DJMAX Portable 1 & 2, as well as new RESPECT original songs. I believe there are 154 songs in this base game. For the early access price, its around 30 cents per song. Songs from other series such as Trilogy, Portable 3, Clazziquai/BlackSquare and Technika will be added on as DLC in the future, so buying this game will allow you to play all your favourite songs from (almost) every DJMAX game. DJMAX Online songs and DJMAX V extension pack are out now, and they do contain amazing songs.
+ As a series that has been out for more than a decade, the gameplay is solid. There are keysounds for almost every songs, and the fever system is satisfying.
+ AIR Mode is a nice addition. When it was initially announced, I was not sure what was the point of this; After using it I'm beginning to enjoy it. You can leave the game with AIR Mode in the background to use as a radio, and when you hear a song you want to play, just switch to the game and start playing. It allows you to play this game without pressure, casually while doing other things.
+ It has difficulties that cater to everyone, including beginners to veterans, except for the top tier players. If you have played other more hardcore games like EZ2DJ, IIDX, O2Jam, and you are really good at them, this game might feel easy for you. The judgement is less strict compared to those, and the patterns aren't nearly as crazy. However, this is good for new players, and I would recommend this as a first title to get if you are looking to try out classic rhythm games (mania-type). The SC Patterns and level 14/15 patterns are still challenging enough for 95+% of the population out there, and there are hundreds of patterns ranging from level 1 - 13 that allows beginners to slowly train themselves. If you feel like you are up to the challenge, you may challenge yourself against others in the ladder mode, where you will even get to experience stricter judgement (in case of tie or game 3).

Neutral:
* The cost might be a bit jarring for people who think that this is expensive for an early access game. I just want to mention that this game is polished, and it is 3 months away from launch with more than half the gameplay features already out.
* The input lag has been fixed mostly, but there is still a small slightly noticeable input delay. Now there is a sync option added in, it can help mitigate this issue. As someone who plays other rhythm games as well, the small input delay wasn't that hard getting adjusted to. The loose judgement of this game actually helps in this regard as well.

Cons:
- This game uses Xigncode anti cheat, which people may not be comfortable with. I guess it is to protect the integrity of the ranking & ladder. Its more intrusive compared to the other anti cheats out there.
- As this game is a direct port of PS4 version, there are small parts of the gameplay that might feel out of place. The side notes (big green long notes) is one such example. Since most patterns are directly ported over from the PS4 version, some of them may feel easy, but obviously this is only a concern for veteran/die-hard players. If you are a new/casual player you don't need to worry about this. The SC difficulty patterns are the ones specifically made for the PC version, so you can play those if you need to.

[h1] Best DJMax Game [/h1]
[b] Loads of Content [/b]
The amount of content in this game is staggering, with lots of good songs of all genres. The song list includes tracks from past DJMax games, as well as a good number of new songs, including some from popular artists like Marshmellow.  There are also a few different modes to try out, from freestyle to ranked matches.
[b] Fantastic Controller Support [/b]
If you are using a controller, the key mapping is exactly as it was on the PSP. Although some functions cannot be called using the controller, and still requires a keyboard, you should have no trouble playing through the majority of the game using only a controller, which is nice. Critically, there is zero lag from controller input.
[b] One and only Downside... [/b]
Some of the ratings are seriously misleading. Ghost Voices by Virtual Self on 4B normal has a difficulty level of 4 stars. This is the hardest 4 star song ever...could give some 6 and 7 star songs a run for their money. Try it!
[b] Conclusion [/b]
Hands down the best DJMax game to date, would highly recommend to anyone who likes rhythm games. 10/10

Full Release Update: The Developers have said they are not planning to make this playable  Offline in the future, and the game has severe loading issues due to the fact that it their ONLINE-ONLY SERVER is buggy, and the anti-cheat software Xign-Code is causing performance issues. The PS4 did not have any of these issues.

Buyer Beware:
As of right now there is no way to play this game without being constantly connected to the internet. The game will not even start unless you are always connected to the internet, and if your internet is ever disconnected the game will immediately crash. I want to recommend this game since it has a stellar soundtrack, graphics, and a promising online mode, but requiring every player to have a constant connection gurantees that  this game will have a short lifespan. I hope they have an "offline" alternative when doing their full release, but as of right now I can't recommend this game to prospective buyers.

Irreplacable experience and outstanding production quality. This is definitely the best rhythm game currently available on steam. Each song comes with unique keysounds, MV and a lot of difficulty levels for each key mode. UI is simple to understand and beautiful. Neat and stylish animations and designs. And around 150 songs.

They have changed the regional pricing after release and triggered many people who bought it in EA stage for, like x2 - x3 of current price.

That said, with all my love for the game, there's something I have to say about it. And sadly, there's a lot to understand before buying:
[list]
    [*]There's no offline mode and game always requires you to stay online in order to play it. 
    [*]So, obviously, until they add "offline mode" this game can be considered as "service game". It's a big deal, because at some point in the future they could turn off the servers and you won't be able to play it at all. You should understand this before buying.
    [*]Anti-cheat can scan files on your PC.
    [*]In order to unlock all songs you need to spend a lot of time. Or... buy DLC. Yep. Let's make a problem in our game and then offer a solution as DLC. Bad practice.
    [*]Developers have some issues with business decisions and communicating with community. Community was asking for offline mode since EA, and it seems they don't plan to add it. This game should be playable offline. Losing all this work and effort of developers would be just utterly sad.
[/list]

Review 2 written on 12/27/2019, after a few patches. Please read the first review below for context.

I have to avoid 8B for now, until I buy an NKRO keyboard. There's no way I can find 8 keys that I can press simultaneously on my cheap 2KRO one.

A recent patch removed the option to choose monitor. I still don't understand why they just can't get display settings right, but it seems said patch resolved my freezing issue. I can now freely switch between windowed, borderless fullscreen and fullscreen, and nothing will freeze. You can also work around the inability to choose monitor, by:
1. switch to windowed mode
2. drag window to desired monitor
3. switch to fullscreen again

Since most things now work (my dumb keyboard excluded), I can finally recommend this game. They ported Respect charts into Respect V, which were intended for gamepads, but also add new SC charts intended for keyboards. Initially I didn't like that, because most Respect charts are way too easy for keyboards, but with the way they define difficulties they can have Respect V properly support gamepads, while still setting clear expectations on what you should and shouldn't touch while using them. That's kinda clever, actually.

I now intensely look forward to the much hyped online modes. Please don't disappoint us!

First review written on 12/18/2019, 1st day of Early Access. I will keep this review up to date as the game is being updated.

After 11 years, almost 12, one of the best rhythm game series on this planet finally returns to PC. Sadly the current version has a plethora of major issues, so I can't recommend it yet. Let's give them time; Neowiz is the company that turned TAPSONIC BOLD from a mediocre mobile port to a full-fledged PC game in a few months, and I have faith they can do the same kind of miracle makeover with RESPECT V.

Issue: switching from fullscreen to borderless window freezes my entire PC. When this happens even Ctrl+Alt+Delete does nothing. Respect V seems to be built in Unity, which should handle display settings pretty well, so I have no idea how this can be an issue at all.

Workaround: Open properties of the main executable, go to compatibility settings, and disable fullscreen optimizations.

Issue: the default key mapping is horrible. I don't know how the devs intended us to assign fingers to the default keys: thumbs on C< and index fingers on DL, or index fingers on C<, thumbs on space and middle fingers on DL. If former, my thumbs are too close to the index fingers and my hands hurt badly. If latter, who the heck uses middle fingers for the innermost lanes? Either way I hate the default mapping. Also cheaper keyboards can't register more than 2 simultaneous key presses if ; or ' is involved.

Workaround: my current setup is WERIOP for regular lanes and VM for LR lanes. This is the best mapping I can think of, that still uses index fingers for the innermost lanes, and all 6 regular keys can be pressed at the same time. To press all 8 keys I probably need a better keyboard.

Issue: Air mode is advertised as a radio mode, but I don't think it's an actual radio. From what I observe I think the game chooses songs locally, and downloads other players' comments from the past. It's completely asynchronous.

Issue: the anti-cheat software that comes with the game, xigncode3, doesn't sound too friendly. I heard it's essentially a rootkit?!

Issue: no way to adjust timing. Devs seem to imply there are patents on this?!
The best rhythm game on PC. It's expensive, but you get what you pay for.

Tl;dr below.

DJMAX Portable 2 was the game I played the most on PSP years ago. I loved it so much that I bought this game in expectation of new content. Old tracks were obviously in the game. Art? It's aesthetically pleasing. But new tracks? Lacking. None of the new tracks have sound effects bound to the keys. For a massive "rhythm game" franchise, DJMAX Respect V delivers absolutely NOWHERE near "unrivaled rhythm game experience"; one might as well call it a duplicate of old DJMAX games with a sprinkle of new songs and designs. Moreover, this game comes with an anti-cheat program, a.k.a 'XIGNCODE3 ROOTKIT', which undermines your security system. And to top it off, DJMAX Respect V is poorly optimized for competitive gaming. In other words, if you are playing it on a non-gaming laptop/desktop, don't expect smooth performance during ranked games. 

DJMAX Respect V is just a heap of pre-existing tracks and a few new ones (void of sound effect) slapped together sold at a disgusting price of 50 US dollars. Why should anybody play this game when they could revisit the old DJMAX series or even better, play OSU which is free? This is a harsh review for an early access game but for Respect V to meet its price value, it should put more effort into new tracks and better the optimization and "anti-cheat program". 

Tl;dr - Bad computer/laptop or concerned with XIGNCODE3 ROOTKIT? Don't buy. 
           Played all DJMAX series and expect something fresh? Don't buy.
           None of all above? Buy only during sale.

Update 13/3/2020:
After seeing the full release of the game and the pricing of DLCs, I am going to change the review from "positive" to "neutral". The DLC packs are really expensive and I am not sure if they actually worth that much money with that amount of content. I am more doubtful that Neowiz is turning this game into a money-grabbing microtransactions-infected game.

The game is alright, just as what you would expect from a DJMAX game.
It comes with 4/5/6/8 buttons mode, each with at least 1 (usually at least 2) and at most 4 difficulties.

The real problem is the "Unlock Song Pack" DLC

Although the game has a lot of free songs (162 songs as of 6 Jan 2020) and the dev seems to add new songs to the game quite frequently, not all the songs are available to play right after you purchase the game.
You will need to put time on playing the game and unlock these songs (98 songs to be precise) with each level up.

Some people argue that this DLC saves their time, and also I know that this DLC exists in PS4 as well. But this kind of "create a problem and sell you the solution" is exactly why I may hold off recommending this game to everyone.
You've already paid 40USD for this game and I see no reason on why charging more to unlock what we, as a consumer, should be entitled to.

I am more than happy for song pack DLCs, those require additional efforts for the developer to create and I am glad to pay for their hard work (also DJMP3 DLC when), but the "Unlock Song Pack" is really unacceptable to me.

Think of this as Beat Saber in 2d without the hand controls. It's absolutely a strong part of the lineage of music games that gave rise to Beat Saber.

This is an easy buy, at full price, for any lover of rhythm/music games. First, know that it's part of a long series of games with a lineage more than 20 games deep (portable systems, mobile, arcade, pc) and you don't make it to 20+ games without doing something right. What is it they do right? The music.

The mechanics are fine, hit buttons in time to the onscreen notes, lots of difficulty levels to add more notes and special modifiers, lots of "gear" to equip to give power ups (or power downs for extra points)

But the music is where it really shines. This series has always had a great track record in picking catchy music, often with strong inspirations from a variety of genres including pop, kpop, funk, grunge, metal, and even classical (and more) though there is a bit more of a bias in the kpop direction: don't worry, they're catchy, addictive, will take over your mind and become many of your favorites. Being a late-stage entry into the series, they also have a deep back catalog to draw on. In addition to plenty of new entries, the game is sprinkled with many of the best entries from prior games. 

I hesitated to buy, even at 20% off, because I wasn't quite in the mood for a music game at the moment, but I dove in nonetheless, having spent hundreds of hours in prior editions in the series and so nostalgia and excitement for new modes and songs drew me in. I'm deep into rhythm land now, but I had to stick my head above water after an hour or so to share a review and make sure others knew just how much they should buy this game, especially while it has a reasonable discount.

DJMax: Respect was arguably the best console rhythm game to come out in the past few years. It featured challenging charts with loads of songs and content to keep you playing. The only real downside to the game was that it required a PS4 to play!

Seeing this game finally break through in a Steam release is almost surreal. Sure, the early access is missing a lot of the content that the PS4 version has, including Online and Missions, but provided that NEOWIZ is able to keep the promises they have made for DJMax Respect V, this may just be the version to own.

Seriously, if you're an avid rhythm gamer of any sort, buy this game. Sure, it has some bugs and stuff that need worked out, but in its current state, it's super enjoyable!


EDIT:

After seeing the game in its release out of early access, a couple of my main gripes with game are gone. Mission mode is here, both Ladder and Open Matches are available, and a lot of nice under the hood tweaks were made. I currently have close to 80 hours in this game, and I can't wait to put many more into it.

Sure, the game still has a couple minor issues, including some wacky freezes here and there, a nasty anti-cheat program that needs serious replacing, no way to play the game offline, and some really early timing, but the game is still an absolute blast to play! I stand by my previous statement. If you like VSRGs, you'll probably love this game.

Ya'll whiners stop complaining about the game be thankful that a great produced rhythm game has been added to Steam/PC. you guys are talking about XignCode (Anti-cheat) and the DRM (Always Online)

XignCode - Since this game is made in South Korea most online games that's made in that country use Xigncode so surprise surprise of course they will use it.

DRM - *NO OFFLINE? REALLY? ITS ALREADY 2020 WHY DO YOU PLAY OFFLINE GET OUT OF HERE!* Its always online because of the ranking/ladder system plus to avoid hacking scores and what not during offline aside from that the game has a rank / multiplayer system.

REVIEW
-Since launch to the PS4 I've been wanting a PC release and it happens. (due to pro-long the game series)
-If your into oldschool (falling notes) rhythm game format with a twist this is for you.
-Super clean sleek UI. (Soon you can have a different UI designs depending on what DLC you have)
-Variety of ORIGINAL songs plus new songs and collaborations.

Even if the first weeks of early access were a bit rough, the game improved a lot and the new features are great, we finally have a full-fledged rhythm game on steam. It's DJMAX so i believe it needs no introduction, the gameplay works as you expect it to, the new tracks and SC charts are a lot of fun and the online lobbys add a new way to hang out and discover songs in a group. Ranked was a bit wonky in the beta but i'm hoping it will work as intended after launch.
If you want to get into rhythm games this is a great game to start, and if you want a challenge the higher difficulties are ready to destroy your fingers. I you feel interested in the game i would totally recommend you to give it a try.

On a side note i want to thank the developers for listening to the community and adding regional prices to both the game and the dlcs.

It's a solid rhythm game with a decent selection of songs and terrible default keybinds.

I use ASDF JKL; for TRACK actions (DFJK for 4 button, SDFJKL for 6 key etc.), V for L SIDE TRACK, and N for R SIDE TRACK. These work so much better than having to stretch to reach shift for side tracks but might not work if your keyboard has bad ghosting. 

Also, they finally added audio offset which is nice but has to be done manually which is not nice.

If you like rhythm games there no reason why you shouldn't get this one. One of the earliest rhythm games where you can actually feel like you played music. Excellent tracks and amazing style. You also can play up to 8 players with strangers or you buddies. Friday night DJ Max gatherings are insanely fun.

Like others have said, the anti cheat engine is really bad, and having it always online is an awful choice since if the servers ever go down I just can't play at all, not even casually playing songs and not trying to compete on the leaderboards. Also some music videos have really obnoxious screen flashing, but you can turn the music video off for those songs and it's not too common anyway.

Other than those, the game is amazing. Probably the best rhythm game on PC or at least on Steam. TONS of options to play how you like: 4, 5, 6, or 8 button modes, different difficulties, able to choose speed of the song, can choose the placement and design of the note highway, fully customizable controls, and "offline" mode on your own or online with friends / random players. Really well polished game overall with plenty of variety in the songs and difficulties to have some nice stuff to listen to and be able to push yourself to get better and better.

If you are a fan of rhythm games then this is a must buy, especially if it ever goes on sale. Now I'm just hoping they'll eventually add in workshop support so we can play even more kinds of songs (please add this Neowiz!)

The game plays very fluidly and has no lag for me and the songs are top notch as always. If you have never played DJMax this is 100% a must buy though.

Before I begin, I must confess that I bought this game for the nostalgia; I have been playing the DJMAX series since its first iteration on the PSP, and seeing this appear on Steam was an absolute no-brainer, I just had to get it.

Like its predecessors, RESPECT V offers a sleek, neat and modern GUI, with a significant selection of music both new and old from earlier versions. This particular version has also been branching into more contemporary/mainstream (notably English) music, which is a nice addition to what DJMAX can offer to the diverse audience on Steam. 

RESPECT V comes with controller support; I have tested both PS4 and the 360 controllers with no problems (I would not advise using the 360). Ideally, you would want to master the keyboard as the most difficult music scores will have patterns that are near impossible to execute on console controllers. Keybindings are also adjustable for those who want to.

While the game comes with multiplayer and ladder matches, I have paid little attention to those features. Given the current public opinion, it might be best to just wait until they ironed out the kinks before attempting them.

In terms of community, a big chunk of the community is Korean, and quite adept at DJMAX, if not music-rhythm games. Do not let this dissuade you from playing, as you will be spending most of your time solo to unlock content, which is both rewarding and fun.

My only and biggest peeve with RESPECT V so far is with the use of Xigncode 3. Not only is this darn thing so invasive, it has blocked me from playing for the past 2 months as my antivirus kept flagging it despite being whitelisted.

For those who are new to this genre, I would recommend trying out the well-known F2P titles first. Even though RESPECT V is arguably a good place to start, the price, bugs and issues combined make it difficult to justify. Those experienced however, should give this a go whenever possible, or just wait until it comes out of Early Access. At least by then we can expect some DLCs to be released, and match the size of the repertoire available on RESPECT (an earlier version on the console).

TL;DR ( You like pressing a lot of buttons quickly to catchy tunes? Then buy this game!!!!)

As a massive fan of the DJMAX series, every song is so memorable that you will find yourself humming along to a tune or two before playing another few rounds. As a rhythm game, the game does not disappoint in giving the end user a euphoric desire to FC or even sing along to some of what the game has to offer. 

Along the same veins as Guitar Hero, this game series follows the rhythm game format of O2Jam, Beatmania, and Pop'n Music where button inputs will give a specific instrument or voice dependent on the section of the song giving the player to have the feeling of "playing" the music. From the wide variety of music that can be found on the soundtrack, there are so many that you can fall in love with. From Hello Pinky, For the Ikarus, Starfish, Fentafest (from the old titles), to Groovin Up, U.A.D., Don't Die. and Killer Bee (from the Respect made songs), there is definitely a song that will get in your head for days on end. 

Of course there are some things that need to be mentioned before you make a purchase like this. Currently the song list that comes with the PC version of DJMAX Respect is much shorter than that of the console release (including all DLC) to a total of 99 songs. This will hopefully change in the next few months since the release has only been for about a month. Next unlocking songs, even for a seasoned veteran of the series, is tedious and massively grindy since song unlocks at every level up to Lvl. 99. 

However, if you are a massive fan of the series without a console, or a newcomer wanting to make this game their first entry into the series, you will be thoroughly entertained for days even weeks.

Been playing the DJMAX series for almost 15 years. Started my adventure from Portable 1 up to Portable 3. Played DJMAX Technika in our local arcades and became a platinum member because of that game.

i've heard of DJMAX ever since playing S4 League way back when, and I have played its latest mobile spinoffs (Tapsonic W.C. / Top), but this is my first time playing something of the "main series". and as a newbie, this game is a total blast to play! 
having so many different styles of play (4b for newbies, 6b as a step up, 5b as an oddball hybrid, 8b for advanced play), with most songs having several difficulty levels for each style, has been great to help me build my skills. timing windows are pretty relaxed as far as what counts as a hit, letting me continue combos even if i just catch a note at the last moment (perfect-play runs can come later on, after all!) air mode lets me mess around in higher-than-usual difficulty levels, with no risk of game-overs & the ability to just watch & listen along in autoplay mode if I so choose. also doubles as a crash course in hangul!
recommended for people who enjoy other rhythm games. the pricetag may look high, but rest assured, there is a lot of high-quality content here to match. my main warning would be to adjust the keybinds away from the default, as I found them pretty uncomfortable, especially when trying to break into 8b play.

Coming from my last DJMAX mainline game, Trilogy, this is a HUGE step-up in terms of music quality and selection, performance and graphics. The fully unlocked songlist will keep you busy for a long, long time, and the charts for most of the songs are brilliantly fun and satisfying.

With some kind of offset adjustment tool this will be an incredible entry into the DJMAX series and it's not even out of Early Access yet!

24/1/20 EDIT: They have released an offset adjustment tool within the options menu that fixes the sync problem!

As a rhythm game, Respect V is the best you can get right now... but it's not without it's flaws.

If you're a hardcore DJMAX Player like myself (10 years now) this game is easy. It is a PORT of the PS4 version and only the SC charts are for keyboard players. Even then, 99% of the SC charts are INSANELY easy. The judgement window, is the easiest it's EVER been, EVEN EASIER THAN PORTABLE 3!! !

Online mode is fun, but lacks substance, and grinding is as annoying as it was on PS4.

That being said, it's still a good game. However, for those who have been waiting for a return to formula DJMAX Game, with hardcore patterns and insane difficulty spikes, this isn't it.

In my opinion this is about the best rhythm game you can get without having to buy an expensive controller. There's other better ones, but they mostly require a $100+ controller investment. 

This game is a tad expensive but I got it on sale for $40. You'll definitely get your money's worth if you're a rhythm game fanatic. If you're not idk why you'd buy this game anyways. 

Feature wise, the game has everything you'd want. Freestyle is your standard mode, pick a song, play. Air, I've heard some people badmouth it, but I find it nice to just play random songs, though I find the chat to be annoying and I would prefer an option to disable it. For that matter I wish there was an option for a more minimal UI. The new mode allows for multiplayer lobbies where you can play along with others and try to beat each other's score. 

One thing I will complain about is the fact the game doesn't separate Korean and English players. What that means is you get a bunch of Korean chat in both Air and multiplayer, and I'm sorry but I CAN'T READ KOREAN! So yeah, an option to only view English chat in Air and only be matched with English players in lobbies would be great.

Pro: I like a lot of the tracks in this game, I like the art, the online multiplayer and all the work that was put into it.

Con: I do not like that you cannot set a global static scrolling speed, which results in lots of weird accuracy and timing inconsistencies. Why did they keep this weird "side track" and red note stuff? Trilogy was a regular 8K rhythm game. I can't get used to this after years of other rhythm games, I would have to rewire my entire brain and start basically from scratch to relearn. On the other hand 4K and 6K is snooze-fest even on the hardest difficulties (maybe this gets better in unlocked songs, I don't know).

Refund for now, will probably rebuy on sale. Please make a proper 8K mode like in DJMAX Trilogy!
Nothing like online multiplayer to put you in your place.

My Early Impressions of DJMAX: RESPECT V aka DJMAX: FINALLY ON PC

The GOOD:

-The same great addicting, precise, challenging and beautiful DJMAX gameplay we've come to expect from Neowiz.

-Much like the Portable games, TONS of unlocks. BGA's, Art, Gear, Notes AND Songs with(hopefully) even more tracks as DLC.

-Possibly the most diverse set of songs i've seen in a DJMAX game, with the addition of the Portable 1/2 songs you have a really great selection of Hip Hop, Dubstep, Trance, Rock, Classical, and so much more that Respect has on its own.

-Great for newbs, great for pros. All difficulties and button sets to cater to everyone's play-style and skill level. 

The MEH:

-Grind. While i love the amount of stuff to unlock, and the fact that EVERYTHING can be unlocked just by playing, it takes FOREVER to level up to earn more songs. I don't remember the PSP games being this slow to unlock music. I get that it's for the ones who've never played and by the time they get to the late game music they will have built up the skill to play them, but dammit i wanna play HAMSIN without having to GRRRRIIIINNNND to get there. With that being said....


The BAAAAAAD:

-Microtransactions. Great for getting new music, preposterous for unlocking everything. Yes some of us want all the songs from the get go but creating the grind only to sell the solution with a microtransaction puts me off.

Overall, despite the cons its still DJMAX on PC and for Rhythm game fans, it's just what we needed.
Game of the year

The second King of rythmn games (IIDX being the first King) is back on PC with new features and songs. DJMax RESPECT was originally released for the PS4 and it finally made it's way to PC with the new RESPECT V version.

Featuring 164 songs (at the time of EA release) with about 160 of these songs having custom keynotes, meaning that the notes of the song only play if you hit them.

Sadly there's no Arcade mode since it has been replaced with the new AIR mode wich is quite honestly a mixed bag.

Overall there's content and songs for everyone, from classic music to dubstep, and with the Multiplayer mode coming this week. The Mission mode will be added at a later date and new songs and DLC's coming soon.

An absolutely solid rhythm game if you're willing to deal with online only DRM and be open to different styles of music.
The game has amazing granularity with it's difficulty offering 4, 5, 6 and 8 buttons. With each track typically having 2 or more difficulties.
Its a better DJMAX Trilogy

I have played almost all DJMAX games, including the PSP versions, DJMAX Online, DJMAX Trilogy, Technikas and Respect. Sadly, I am very disappointed with this game for the following reasons:

-Poor graphic performance. Of course, this game has a performance improvement over the PS4 version, but note scrolling is not smooth yet, even playing at 144Hz. At highest speeds notes present ghosting / skipped frames, especially if you select a rectangular note pattern, and this effect is worse when increasing the speed of the notes. Many patterns look weird and barely playable when speed is over 3.5 or 4.

-x5 speed limit. I think developers don't know how to implement a proper smooth note scrolling, and this must be the real reason behind the speed limit. This is a serious problem. Do you remember when we were able to x6, x7, x8, x9, x10, x12, x15 and even x99?

-Serious lag and sync issues. It is not possible to set the audio delay. (Forget to play this game in anything other than a good PC monitor)

-Most of the new Respect V songs lack keysound. Are you serious? Do you think I can always hit a 100% and I don't care about keysounds? Licensing issues? This is ridiculous. Worst of all, it seems this is becoming a trend and they won't do anything about it. This is a big disappointment.

UPDATE: Here the list of songs I've identified as no keysounded:

-Alone
-Always*
-Bleed
-Ghost Voices
-Kingdom
-POP/STARS
-Riot Games
-Sad Machine
-So Happy
-Tok! Tok! Tok!*
-Void*

*: Songs available in PS4 version

[h1]Respect V is basically the original PS4 version of DMR, with a promise of introduction and enhancement of multiple Online modes in the future.[/h1] 

[u][b]The changes:[/b][/u]
-Arcade mode is gone, not that the original is great in any way, because the progression of DMR is tied with achievements instead of levelling, you barely get anything meaningful with arcade. Although it is one of the series' signature mode, I don't miss it really. 

-Air mode replaced Arcade in DMRV, but really, although I'd say it's a bit better than Arcade mode, it's still pretty wack. First of all, I'm not sure why would anyone want to chat during the gameplay, other players can't see your gameplay, there aren't that many stuff to comment other than the music video. However, I think Air will be much better if it features other player's gameplay if you put it on auto.

-Not sure why they removed the mission mode, but it will come back surely based on the trailer, it's the meatiest part of DMR's gameplay.

Everything else is pretty much the same as usual...

[u][b]Some cons so far:[/b][/u]
-The game is also incredibly loud and its volume can't go under 50%, glad to see one of my loudest PS4 game maintain its title on the PC platform.

-Default keybind feels off, I think left/right shift is not a good binding for songs with tons of spaghetti notes (K/DA, for example, that song is the definition of spaghetti notes). I think this may be the first time I prefer PS4 controller over a keyboard on MUG.

-Game is too pricy for what it offers at this stage, without mission mode and online mode, DMRV is pretty much just an OSU, all it got is a free play mode, no story, no mission, no PVP, no nothing.

-With the expectation of enhancing PVP aspect I thought they'd make song unlocking easier as well, [strike]but I guess they have to sell the song unlock DLC[/strike]. It will take some dedication to unlock everything.

[u][b]Some pros if you are not familiar with the series:[/b][/u]
-This is probably one of the most hardcore/high-quality music game in the market. With tons of original songs and music videos to enjoy.

-Unlike maybe 99% of the music games in this generation that use generic notes sound, this game's notes' sound effects sampled from the song you play, so you can actually "play" the music.

-It even runs on final destination mode, items, combos and special effects does not grant extra scores, it's all about the note accuracy. The pros of this are that it helps to keep the game fun when you are playing against a high-level player since all songs/difficulties have the same max score of 300,000 (without counting fever). But that's a pro for multiplayer mode... Which the game does not have at this stage.

[u][b]Summary:[/b][/u]
Overall its quality surplus most of the music games out there, DMRV feels like something more professional compare to other mobile music game ports on steam. So if you interested in music game its simply a must buy, there are nothing like it, nothing ever come close to it in the long history of MUG.

For fans, if you got a DMR on your PS4, maybe wait for a while until they release more modes. Although it is quiet excited to see Djmax again on PC, it's basically a worse version of the original for now.

DJMax Respect V is more of the same DJMax Respect awesomeness many of us have come to know and love on the PS4. Even if you already have this title on PS4 you should pick up Respect V for the sheer amount of extra stuff it has.
This also applies to the PS4 version, really DJMax Respect is a game best enjoyed with both versions since each is its own unique experience that pays homage to DJMax's history on both PC and console and you really need both for the full experience.

The only major downside at the moment is the inability to sync your leveling progress between the PS4 and PC versions which can make regrinding for all the songs a bit annoying but at the very least you can DLC your way out of it now like you could on PS4 (and is my prefered way of doing things since the song unlock system in Respect quite frankly sucks)

Either way, Respect V is very much worth your time
