DJMax is a lesser known but long-running rhythm game franchise that has had some experience in PC, but never at an international level like this (and with less hoops to jump through to play).  While Respect has been out on PS4 for some time now, this version for Steam brings a lot of its own reasons to buy, including a few new songs as well as being able to play with a keyboard again!  Even in early access while there's a couple less modes at this time, it offers a TON of content being only second in track selection with recent notable ryhthm games to the monstrous Project Diva Future Tone.  With well over 100 songs and tons of different note charts, even offering a quick but useful tutorial to get new people up to speed, this is a must purchase for anyone into rhythm games, and likely even if you own Respect on PS4 (as did I).

This game is an almost direct port of DJMAX RESPECT for the PS4, with a few new welcome additions such as new modes, songs, and the availability of harder, keyboard-specific charts. Don't let that price tag scare you: as a rhythm game, it's one of the most high quality and polished experiences available on the market, with [b]over 160 songs[/b] (without even counting any DLC), background videos and several charts for each song, and tons of unlockables. The game is also really fun to play with controller.

It's one of the few games that uses actual keysounds for its songs (which means you're playing the actual instruments of the song as you play), so although you will hear your failures much more than in other games, it becomes much more satisfying to clear a song perfectly making it sound correctly.
The sound and input sync aren't 100% perfect right now but it's close enough that if you wear headphones the latency should be unnoticeable. A few modes are also missing with it being Early Access and all - mission mode and online are expected by the time of the full release. Developers have been very responsive to fixing bugs in a timely manner so far. An interesting point is that although steam cloud support is not shown, the game syncs your scores to its own cloud so you don't have to worry about losing your progress.

All that said, there are two major points about this game you should be aware of before buying it:
-This game uses [b]Xigncode3[/b] as anti-cheat. The full implications of this software are up to you to research, but if you were hoping on running this on MacOS or Linux, you're out of luck for this reason.
-This game uses [b]Always-Online DRM[/b]. What this means is not only that you can't play offline (which is extremely inconvenient as it is, given that the game should work just fine offline like the PS4 version does), but also that the company behind the game (NEOWIZ) is in full control of one day closing the servers (or banning you), in which case you'll be left with absolutely nothing, as the game you paid for won't work at all. This is actually something that already happened many times in the past with NEOWIZ's games.

To wrap up, the game is amazing, and if you love rhythm games it's absolutely a must-buy. Just keep those two points in mind, though.

First played DJMAX P2 back in the PSP days, was never really into consoles after the handhelds died off so I was excited to see a PC version. Picked it up right away seeing it was on sale.  

I have to say it did not disappoint, the song selection is pretty broad and the game play is smooth. However, in its current early access state, it does not have missions or multiplayer, which might be a turndown for some, but I mostly stay in freestyle so it wasn't a big deal for me.  

Songs can be unlocked by simply leveling up and the grind is not too bad, as you can open up AIR mode and leave it in the background which will let you level up. You also have the option of buying the "Unlock pack DLC", which is a nice option for those who don't want to grind at all.  

Definitely recommended for DJMAX fans and those who are looking to get into rhythm games. However, for owners of the PS4 RESPECT title, IMO this is somewhat similar so you might want to think twice if you are looking for something different.

Lastly, I hope they add songs from Blacksquare and Clazziquai so I can have a one stop game for all my nostalgic needs.

This is shaping up to be the replacement for DJ MAX TRILOGY I was hoping for. A bit light on features at the moment but there is a lot of songs to play though. This is going to have your rhythm game needs covered for a long time and is a must if you are into Asian art scene.

Instead of telling you how awesome this game already is, because you know that already...I will instead give you some tips on how to enjoy playing this awesome game:

Regardless of which key mode you go with, always remember to relax your arm and fingers while lightly resting them on the buttons of the keyboard.

You will know you are playing the game wrong when you arms and fingers tense up to keep up with the faster bpm songs...pause the game, take a deep breath, relax and then resume or restart the song.

Don't worry about missing notes while playing in a relaxed manner, with practice you will eventually pick up technique and start strumming those keys with ease as you relax your way to a max combo.

So just remember to relax, loosen the arms and fingers, don't stress the key presses just lightly depress, relax and enjoy. That's the best way to play DJ Max Respect.

With that, peace out and enjoy yourself.

Sure the content isn't officially 100% available yet, but it gives me something to look forward to. I've also fully acclimated to playing on keyboard, so I'm capable of rolling through 8B mode at 3X speed and nabbing up some Max Combos like I could with a controller. Feels great!

This is DJMAX Respect for PC. After spending a couple hours playing 8B mode on the keyboard I actually find myself struggling to go back to a controller, even if I'm still coming to grips with this new method (for me personally, since I've played all DJMAX titles in the past with a controller). If you love rhythm games this is an absolute must-buy, especially for the price. It runs buttery smooth and I can now say I have DJMAX in 4K, so honestly I see this as an absolute win. It's also worth noting that the new exclusive jams added to this version are rather solid. 

Here's the Marshmello song they added as an exclusive to this version... I am still coming to grips with playing on a keyboard so bear with my kinda average performance, but honestly this is also a good look so you can judge if you feel the game is for you: 
https://youtu.be/NPkB5L9OZcw
Straight jams.

Most of the game is a great continuity of preivous releases for other platforms, controls requiere fine tune to be in your best experience and to reach new highs thats a great thing, the AIR concept is cool but they need to improve it and create a multiplayer competitive experience in real time. With all the flaws I recommend it to continue the legacy of DJMAX!

Yeah, there are many missing features, but there's enough content to last you for over 50 hours, and a ranking system that is very fun, addictive, and rewarding that is based on how well you're doing on the songs in Freestyle mode.

Pros:
- Huge song list.
- Fun and challenging charts, with the new addiction of SC charts. I play rhythm games all the time, and I had to retry a few of the most difficult songs to pass them. They are challenging enough in my opinion.
- Ranking system based on letter grades and max combos.
- The new background animations are beautiful.
- New songs being added for RESPECT V only, and many of them are well-known songs from musicians such as Marshmello, Porter Robinson, etc.
- 8K mode is a unique and exciting experience for advanced rhythm game players.
- A ton of collectibles, achievements, and the level system makes the game fun and interesting.

Cons that won't be changed:
- In 8K, the side notes are a bit clunky and uncomfortable to play. They occur sometimes uncommonly and took me a long time to get used to.
- Some backgrounds are pretty bad, with one that flashes black and white intensely that made me want to quit the song because it got really annoying.
- Have to play easy charts in order to get 100% master rating for rankings, but the "easy" charts are not too tedious in 8K mode.

Cons that can be changed:
- Lack of ranking system mode and missions
- There isn't a way to organize the large quantity of music by music artist, difficulty, etc;
- Freestyle mode defaults to 4 Button Mode every time no matter what mode you played previously. It also resets to "Normal" difficulty every time you change songs, which can get annoying.
- A handful of the songs are badly out of sync including the Marshmello song which is almost a full beat out of sync for me. There is also no way to adjust your song offset.

Overall, it is a very fun game and I've spend a lot of time playing it. It was well worth the money. 8.7/10

If your looking for old school DJ max Portable 1 & 2 this is it, though is missing a few song this has a still a great selection of old song and new ones. Worth a try if you miss the old school psp djmax portables.

The best of the best... except it has an intrusive rootkit installed for anti-cheating that can gather information about your computer, scan all of your files, etc, without your permission.

Another bad thing is that all charts are downloaded from the internet each time you play them, meaning if the makers ever decide to stop supporting the game, it will be unplayable.

It's the best rhythm game ever if it weren't for these two things, so if you can live with it, buy it.

I don't usually write reviews, because let's face it, interacting with the community? Bad! I hate it!

But I have to say a few words about DJMAX.

I've been playing these games since high school, when I picked up a used copy of Fever for my PSP. I played that every day and every night. Then came Portable 3, Technika Tune, and those mobile ones - plus Respect PS4. 

Now, finally, DJMAX hits PC in the West for the first time (it's been a PC series in Korea for years.)

It's impossible to overstate how good this game is. It has absolutely flawless rhythm gameplay, a tracklist that offers something for truly everybody, and an addictive leveling and unlock loop to keep you hooked. But there's something that's always elevated DJMAX for me, and that's in its music videos. There are dozens upon dozens of self-contained little stories here - ones that often stick with me, even being only around two minutes long. Parts of this game and its predecessors have become an ingrained part of my consciousness that I carry with me. How many games can say they offer that?

Anyway. As a lifelong rhythm gamer, DJMAX is as good as it gets, and Respect V is a stellar version of an already-great game. With promised post-launch support, I have faith that this thing'll only get better.

this game is in early access for a reason. Several of the features touted are not available.

The game includes Xingcode3 Rootkit anti-cheat, which installs and scans files without you agreeing.

The game suffers from bad input delay on a case-by-case basis and the devs say they are working on a fix, will update review when or if it ever happens. (Sync issues apparently have been addressed, but not hardware issues so this might be a problem depending on your setup.)

I find the current price to be too high knowing from the ps4 version that most of the game's content is going to be coming as paid DLC. The total content is not going to be worth the total price in my opinion. The game also currently has much less content than the ps4 release.

I would wait for full release to purchase.

I discovered the games through the Technika 3 Arcade and since then, I've loved DJMAX, I really do. 

But there is this thing that bugs me, you have to know that this game has a rootkit installed in it; it's called Xingcode 3. Basically, it's an anti-cheat/hack that forces you to be online at all times to play and compiles info about your PC, it can even scan files in your computer without your permission as well. I won't dawdle about what it does specifically because there are a few reviews explaining it. Please, [u][b]remove it[/b][/u], if you do so, I'll gladly change this review.

About the content, it's almost the same as vanilla DJMAX Respect on PS4 with the selection of songs, there are a few more for this release and some other free songs planned for the future. But this version doesn't have the missions, arcade mode and the online mode (yet). Besides, the new AIR mode isn't motivating to play or a great feature, I played like 10 songs and then left it in autoplay to unlock illustrations and such, never cared about it again.

Also, I think it's really pricey for an early access game, it's the same as the vanilla one and doesn't even have the same features. I suggest you buy it on sale for at least a half with the current state of the game or wait for the full release, if they remove the rootkit that is.

All said, this is a genuinely good game in general, it may be the best rhythm game in my opinion and I'm truly optimistic about the future of this game, I just hope the developers listen to the people who are not happy with the anti-cheat intruding their privacy. 

Now, excuse me, I need to grind my 999999 combo on my PS4 version.

DjMax Respect V is a simple rhythm game with 4B, 5B, 6B and 8B playstyle .After 11 years, finally made it back to PC and stronger than ever. With over 150 songs and future collabs. This rhythm game won't dissapoint but if you want a GOOD rhythm game for free, go play Osu.

The game offers (Early Access):
-Freestyle: play any playstyle and stack up combos infinitely and see how far you can reach.
-Air Mode: play an endless playlist of songs that are picked randomly with the playlist and difficulty of your choice.
-Collection: See how good you're performing, how far you've reached and all the achivements and unlockables you can get by playing the game.
-Ranking: See your ranking vs others on each song or world-wide per playstyle.

Pros:
-Every song has keysounds with responsive feedback.
-The songs have a lot of different genres and a lot of them have catchy beats that you will like and replay.
-If you're an old fan, all of the MVs, music and keysounds were remade to sound up to date.
-They'll be adding songs and updates for free as improvement goes on.
-The game doesn't demand absurd asian skills to play the game. It's one of the most accessible games on the early and late game. Practice makes perfect.

Cons:
-(During Early Access) The game is missing futures like Online and Mission Mode. It'll be added once its released with even more unlockables.
-There's a few desync issues but they can be fixed in the options.
-There's no offset option for now.
-The game will be plagued with DLCs sooner or later. If you wish to support the game, spend it.

Extras:
-A very welcoming community full of rhythm-game-lovers willing to help and answer questions:
-You can ask quesitons to the Devs and accept feedback during the development, don't be salty.
-It's community is very accessible to multiple countries, be friendly.
-Here's the discord if you'd like to know more about the game: https://discord.gg/eJSTz8J

Don't let the price fool you, even if it's "way to expensive for a rhythm game, there's a bunch out there for free" you can expect top-quality from these developers. They've shown it back in the PSP market and on a PC market. Have in mind that their target is mainly Koreans / Asian market but they also make it super accessible for the western audience.
An excellent port. highly recommended.

While writing this review I keep looking at my collector‚Äôs editions of DJMAX Portable 2, Hot Tunes, Portable 3, Technika Tune and Trilogy.

Glory Days and Boom upliftingly attacks my feelings to bring a tear to my eye.

Thank you again for introducing me to Yukika‚Äôs Neon, the retro effects of the MV is so beautiful. 

---Review like stuff---

Personally, the new UI with less graphically rich branding was a right move.

The latest music and accompanying animation show how far the game has come.

The current build of the game does not appear to hide any really juicy content behind hard to complete requirements.

Depending on the difficulty, some of the song might have a disjunction that tosses off your tempo with notes you will play.

The wide variety of available music allows you to look for and find other songs that build you up to tackle the more difficult parts in others.

DJMAX Trilogy on PC was punishing in that aspect, giving limited content that help you learn demanding patterns.

Airplay is another fantastic way to learn songs, you will not instantly fail and get to enjoy the music.

Another intriguing feature about Airplay is how the music is automatically chosen.

The social aspects of Airplay appear to allow you to interact with players currently on the music station online.

On my PC, Trilogy had an issue with micro-stuttering that would completely ruin the experience at times.

Respect has only been smooth.

----End---

I look forward to seeing how this game evolves as it goes towards the official release.

My wallet is ready for some of the songs I‚Äôve been missing from the previous games.

I've loved rhythm games forever and DJ Max even more so ever since I picked up DJ Max Portable 2 on the PSP.

This is anyone's dream who has been a fan to the DJMAX series, but it does have its flaws. At the time of review, this game is still in early access, so NEOWIZ still has time to optimize it and I'm excited for what they've promised. I don't know about multiplayer in rhythm games, but that's what i'm looking forward to the most.

Pros
- the amount of songs, you'll definitely have a lot to play
- using a controller feels very good to use
- the general aesthetic looks incredible
- online leaderboards without having to enter codes into a browser? Sign me up!
- AIR is incredibly fun to play in since you can kick back from time to time and enjoy the music after playing a bit

Cons
- some of the visuals are heavily outdated for the songs from the portable games, so those can drive away new players
- no button indicators for controller (at this point, it's still early access)
- the lack of color difference between the buttons in 6B mode and forward. It can get confusing whether or not you're hitting the right button when pressing 'D' or right dpad or 'L' or X. (Xbox controller for reference)
- the keyboard timing is slightly delayed

Regardless of its issues, I am 100% on board for this game and cannot wait for its full release. NEOWIZ definitely nailed this one.

I put over 500 hours into the PS4 game and was pleasantly surprised to see this game come to PC. While this game allows for keyboard play, I personally think the charts that were brought over from the PS4 version are still more fun to play on a DualShock 4 than on keyboard (fortunately, the game has DualShock 4 support right out of the box!). However, I am happy to report that the new charts that were made to accommodate both controller and keyboard play are fantastic to play on either one! The new SC difficulty charts exclusive for keyboard are also very fun to play as well! 

As an early access game, it offers a pretty healthy amount of content with a lot more to come. While also still being an early access game, there are still some bugs that need to be addressed and some significant framerate drops that happen randomly during actual gameplay (not very often though). Personally, I find the sync to be on-par with the PS4 game (which is a little early, but I tend to hit fast in every rhythm game that I play) and there is no offset adjustment in this game unlike the PS4 version, so please be aware of that.
Recommended

Yep. It's back. DJMAX is back. One of the best VSRG that defined the genre is back, in Early Access form, of course. Do keep in mind that the game itself is already on PS4 for quite sometime.

It's one of the best (if not the best best) rhythm game on Steam right now. No quirky controls. No gimmicks. It's a straight DJMAX game. However, there are some points that you should know before buying:

 - The charts are made to be played with a Dualshock in mind. There's the SC difficulty that is made with no controller limitations in mind, but the majority of the game could feel too easy with a controller. On the plus side, You can play everything with a controller (except SC charts, of course).

- The whole game is made with a controller in mind. To select things, you might have to press some weird keys that made no sense. You cannot use a mouse to select anything. This is not a complaint or a negative side, just something to bring up.

Now let's go with the positives:

+ The gameplay is straight-forward. Notes come down, and you press the keys. No gimmicks. no nothing. It is extremely satisfying to play. It is also very easy to pick up.

+ The songs are key-sounded, meaning that when you play, certain sounds and instruments are muted and hitting the keys will make the muted sounds. This allows for a more immersive gameplay, and adds the fun into trying to hit the notes.

+ There's a sense of progression. Songs, skins and collectibles are locked behind achievements. You play to unlock those.

+ Air mode is quite novel. It is the "free-roam" mode on this game. You select the difficulty and key mode that you want, and you get to play nonstop. A novel concept, and a fun one too.

There are also negatives, of course:

- The game is in early access, meaning that certain features are being worked on. Multiplayer is a big one.

- The price is steep. It's almost as expensive as new AAA games. The game is already on PS4 years ago, and it's still in early access. I bought it with a -20% discount and I still feel like it was expensive. Maybe if it's on sale for %50 it would have been reasonable.

Overall, it's a very enjoyable game to say the least. I would advise anyone picking this up at a later date when the price is right.

As a long-term fan since DJMAX Portable on the PSP, I'm pleased that the series can be enjoyed by a larger audience, especially given that the prior PC release title, DJMAX Trilogy, was geographically limited in release and required a physical USB verification key to play.

There are currently minor hiccups here and there in the current iteration of the Early Access version, and the game could definitely use more features, however I'm confident that these can be ironed out over time.

After more than 10 years since Trilogy, DJMAX series comes back home to PC with DJMAX Respect V. 

PROS:
- Loads of content for early access game, doesn't feel barebones at all
- Great port and optimization, which runs very well up above 60 FPS
- Flexibility in control; you can switch between keyboard/joystick and even remap each button to suit your style

CONS:
- Xigncode anti cheat measure which is unnecessary for a Steam game and supposedly a rootkit that scans your PC without permission
- Note calibration which screws your accuracy, but at this point of writing a patch came out which greatly fixes some of this issue
- Continuing the above point, no note offset to compensate your playing style
- Side note mechanic feels okay on joystick but awkward for keyboard user. For this PC release I'd prefer to have this feature removed
- Pretty hefty price tag for a exact port of a PS4 game that came out years ago
- AIR mode feels underwhelming
- No Arcade and Mission mode

I've played Respect on PS4 and Trilogy on PC so I compared my experience playing this game to the former two games. Overall, Respect V is doing pretty okay by providing tons of content while adding regular content coming forward. Some issues mentioned above have hampered my confidence in trying to hit the notes properly, but if the first patch is the indication then I think we're in the good hands.

If you're still feeling hesitant because of the price tag and all the other problems above, you won't miss anything by holding your horses until the game launches officially. But if you're not bothered with them, then by all means please enjoy Respect V.

Great original songs, great presentation, great variety of charts, the four button modes gradiate the difficulty curve excellently as well as providing you lots of ways to enjoy the very large amount of songs, PC port runs well and supports 144Hz for that smooth feeling. I really have no complaints, this is an exceptionally high quality production and possibly the best commercial music game currently on PC. A Respectable Game.

The current version of the game lacks an offset setting it desperately needs as I, among other players suffer from heavy sound desync. The desync is not consistent, but it's present on all songs I've tried so far and at its worst it means hitting 60% on something that should be a 100%. This is running the game at 240 fps on a 144hz "1 ms" latency display that works fine for other rhythm games such as Osu! and DDR. As such I can't recommend this game in it's current state.

Been a massive fan of the series for a long time and always went out of my way to get it imported in or play roms since the originals where never readily available where i live. 

For an early access game this is pretty well fleshed out, tons of songs to play and choose from (including loads of classic songs from the old games and new), all the button modes in tacked and couple of other features which a interesting. 

Air mode is kind of a quote unquote live radio channel? I think its the games way of adding a social element by either just pressing auto play and sitting back and watching the songs and comments go by (or even add a comment yourself) or playing through the random songs... If I'm honest i haven't dabbled with this element much which seems to want to be the main show since its the very first option on the menu.

What i have been playing for my first hour is really freeplay mode; pick a song, pick a button mode and play to your hearts content. You level up depending on how well you play the songs which unlocks new songs, new overlays for the notes and play screen, as well as other things. You get a good selection of songs to start with and the list of playable tracks to be unlocked is huge. If I'm honest, i wasnt expecting so many songs for an early access title. 

There is a rankings mode, which I think is the games competitive element? but i havent really poked around in that yet.

Only con I have is playing on keyboard, the menu and button layout takes a couple of sections to figure out how to navigate and control. Also a weird issue I had, which was easily fixed by rebinding the buttons in game, was to start with one of the buttons said it was a certain key but when pressed did nothing. When the game was fresh the track which it shows you is bound to ' actually is # or when the left tracks line up nicely (A, S, D) the right was more like (L ; #) rather then (L ; ') which is what it shows you. Though like I said it was easily fixed by going into the button options and reassigning it.

Otherwise I am enjoying the hell out of the game and can't wait to get back in and play some more.

[u]Initial thoughts:[/u]
This is an Early Access review for DJMAX RESPECT V which covers personal thoughts and opinions about the current state of the game. As an avid fan of DJMAX Portable 2 and the DJMAX series, I was delighted to see a DJMAX PC port when I stumbled upon it while viewing social media. Priced CDN$45.59 at time of purchase, it seems blatantly fair for such a huge library of music. I will have to judge the prices for the DLCs in future to see if they are worth getting them or not.

[u]Nostalgia:[/u]
DJMAX RESPECT V has the largest DJMAX library in the series, with over 147 songs from Portable 1, Portable 2 and Respect. Some might deem this as reusing content from previous games, which is true, however I can overlook this premise because I find myself taking a trip down nostalgia lane while playing the same songs a decade ago.

[u]Setup:[/u]
Since I've played Portable 2 on the PSP, I'm more accustomed to playing DJMAX with D-pad and buttons. As such, I went to link my DS3 controller to my PC. There are [url=https://www.reddit.com/r/SteamController/comments/90dqov/guide_dualshock_3_on_steam_windows_only/] guides [/url] online teaching driver downloads to enable DS3 for Steam's Big Picture. Setting up took about 10 minutes before I was comfortable with the configurations in Big Picture controller options.

[u]Gameplay:[/u]
I have never touched DJMAX in a long time, so I'm pretty rusty to say the least. I found myself testing out 4B for the first hour, whilst moving on to 5B and 6B in 3 hours time. It took me quite awhile to adjust to the speed of the notes after not playing rhythm games for years. Overall, the graphics and handling were pretty good when I ran the game at Full Screen 1080p 60fps. 

I have tried AIR Mode which was something new to me. I love the player interactions for songs due to the ability to comment on them. I recommend this mode for players who want to kick back, relax and chill to the music because auto-play can be switched on. However, a little gripe for me is the inability to earn progress after the completion of songs in this mode.

Freestyle Mode is probably what people buy to play DJMAX for. As usual, players can unlock cosmetics and new songs after leveling up through playing songs. Here, you can choose your favorite music and play them at 4B, 5B, 6B and 8B modes. I personally feel rewarded for unlocking MVs after getting MAX combos for songs. I might be nitpicky at this point, but I do notice a strange empty feeling after getting a MAX combo. This could be because I was used to the comment 'MAX combo, what a crazy mix!' from Portable 2 and 3.

UI, animations in the lobby and loading screens are pretty slick. It has that aesthetic, professional feel when selecting a game mode.

[u]Final Thoughts:[/u]
DJMAX RESPECT V is a game that I've purchased in a heartbeat mainly due to nostalgic purposes. Highly recommended to people who have played previous DJMAX games and know what DJMAX is all about. It [i]can[/i] still be a great game for newcomers, but with a price point of more than $50 and other cheaper rhythm game options like Osu! and Beat Saber, DJMAX RESPECT V might have troubles captivating new audiences into the rhythm game genre.

[u]TL;DR[/u]
[b]8.5/10[/b] - [i]score heavily influenced by nostalgia[/i]

DJMAX has been part of of my life ever since DJMAX Portable 1 on PSP. That game introduced me into an entire world of rhythm that had been existing in Asia for over a decade. As I branched out into other rhythm game series, I consistently returned to DJMAX. Their original songs stood out from other games and the slick presentation has always been a staple.

In DJMAX Respect V, the grand return to PC since 2008's DJMAX Trilogy, the developers have managed to capture the entire franchise into one beautiful package. I have been playing Respect on PS4 since it launched (two and a half years ago), and the amount of passion and detail that has been put into painstakingly remastering and upgrading old songs into the modern era is impressive. The game truly lives up to the "respect" subtitle in how the huge promise to eventually release every past DJMAX song as DLC has slowly, but surely, being fulfilled.

Respect V has launched with early access and is a slightly different beast than Respect (with some new modes, songs, and a brand new focus on competitive multiplayer), it does not have any of the DLC at launch that Respect on PS4 has. It will come soon, and I hope it will catch up to PS4 in less than a year. Even without DLC, it contains over 150 songs (the entire setlists from DJMAX Portable 1 & 2 included), a great progression system with cosmetics to unlock, an incredibly detailed stats and collection corner, and tons of modes and difficulties.

Respect V has performed very well on my Asus Zenbook 2017 (without a dedicated graphics card). I look forward to multiplayer, Porter Robinson, ironed out bugs, achievements and cards (confirmed coming soon!), and more when the game graduates from Early Access in early 2020. DJMAX Respect and Respect V are games I never thought would exist after the DJMAX brand died years ago. The thematic elements of the intro video and menus represent how all of us felt when DJMAX died and how we felt when it was brought back from the grave in the most spectacular way. These two games will remain the definitive editions of the franchise in my mind and I'll never forget the few tears that blurred my vision as I watched the first teaser trailer for Respect.

I played over 100+ hours on DJMAX Portable 2, so when I heard Respect V was coming to PC, I knew I had to get it.

Pros:
- Great graphics that are seamless and are consistent throughout the game 
- Songs are from older DJMAX games which I appreciate greatly
- Variety of difficulty choices
- Can play on controller or keyboard and can swap between playing on either immediately
- Easy to understand controls

Cons:
- Every time I switch songs, it puts the speed back to 2.0 even though I want to keep it at a higher speed
- Input lag 
- Missions can only be seen in Collection mode but I would like to refer to them in FreeStyle so I know what I have to achieve
- Not all game modes shown in the commercial is out (but this is early access)

Personally, I love the game and can see myself playing it for a while, but there are problems. If it was easier to see the missions to unlock certain songs when hovering over the song, it'd be convenient or just see in general how I can unlock my favorite songs rather than just aimlessly playing then going back to collective and back the FreeStyle. The only mission I have trouble with is keeping a combo over 50K+ (which continues to go up I'm assuming), because I think an average rhythm game player might see that as intimidating and think "No way can I do that." Playing that much is exhausting, but at least when you restart a song, your combo stays where it was.

Advice tho: if you're not used to playing with a controller, please take a break. You can start feeling cramps in your hands when playing on controller for a long time. 

Overall, love the game but hope UI gets adjusted for an easier time to know what the player has to do to unlock songs.

I wish there was a way to add a middle-ground review without saying "Yes" or "No" entirely. For an Early Access game, it's definitely expected that there's going to be things not working as expected, like missing features, bugs, etc. At it's current state, I wouldn't think that $50 is a worthwhile purchase especially since the game is missing a lot of stuff that won't get added until later. Coming from the original DJMax Respect on PS4, there are certain things that I liked about the game that aren't available yet.

Pros:
-Good number of tracks to start (not sure if DLC will be included or available for purchase later)
-AIR mode is pretty cool, an endless queue of playing tracks
-Freestyle mode is there
-Ability to customize keybindings

Cons:
-Missing Arcade mode in current state, one of the fundamental modes of any rhythm game
-Lack of offset calibration, leads to frustratingly inaccurate note hits
-Currently no controller support yet for gamepads or even 3rd party rhythm game controllers like the EZMAX. Key bindings for the controllers are mapped completely incorrect.
-For EZMAX (or other DJ controllers), currently you're only allowed to configure one direction of the turntable, so no scratching allowed, just continuous rotations in one set direction
-EZMAX controller has a bug where the track list continuously scrolls up. Only affects this section and doesn't affect the menus at all.
-AIR mode is really cool, but your songs don't get graded (S,A,B,C,etc). You have to play Freestyle mode to get those.
Respectable

Feels like an extremely solid port from the PS4 version!! Getting licenses such as Porter Robinson is HUGE! Cannot wait for the Online Functions to release! I've been waiting to play in 8-player lobbies ever since the original PC version! Thank you NEOWIZ for all your hard work!

As someone who played the DJMAX games since the PSP era and hasn't stopped playing them I can say that this entry will not dissapoint. The game has plenty of tracks to start off with which get unlocked as you keep playing and achieving new milestones. The song variety is also pretty good, you can find all sorts of tracks with every track having multiple difficulty levels for every kind of player. Every song also komes with its own music video that can range from something emotional to straight up goofy.
The tracklist will also expand with DLC that adds most of not all the tracks from the older games eventually making this game the definitive edition in the franchise.
However at the moment of this writing the game is still in early access and taht also comes with bugs and the like so be warned.

TL;DR
+ Alot of music
+ Variation in genre
+ Music video with every track
+ the complete frnchise package through DLC

- some minor bugs (as of the moment of writing this review)
- No arcade mode (it seems to have been replaced with the new AIR mode or will be patched in in the future)

I think this is probably the sort of game that doesn't need a lengthy review. If you're a fan of rhythm based gaming, DJMAX is one of the best. If you've dropped cash on discount rhythm games and ended up disappointed, this is probably the one you want. While the level of content available in early access will definitely feel sparse to anyone coming over from the Playstation 4 version of this game (which has had years of support and tons of DLC released for it)...yeah it's "missing" a lot of songs, but for everyone else, 150+ songs out of the box for this price is pretty high value.

For new players, people without a PS4, people that want to play on a keyboard for accessibility reasons: Buy this
For players coming over from the PS4 and have no accessibility issues: Buy this if you want to continue supporting DJMAX / NEOWIZ, or if you really don't mind spending a good amount of cash for a few exclusive songs and content.

It's finally the PC's turn to see how great DJ MAX RESPECT really is. I do recommend buying this, it feels like a complete game right out of the box. I do see that it may be missing local and online MP, hopefully this gets added in soon, as well as controller button icons.

It's DJMAX, the best rhythm game there is. Is this port perfect? Not really. Doesn't support Ultrawide monitors (would would have let you have the gear completely off to one side and have the full video on the screen at once, a missed opportunity), there are modes seemingly missing that makes it kind of annoying if you've been playing the series for a long time like Arcade or Mission (I'm guessing they are coming later), but the new changes are awesome. Air Mode where it just makes nonstop music for everybody with comments and the ability to switch between auto-play and actual play on the fly is an awesome idea. There's also a ton of songs right out the gate, which is awesome.

Biggest change that's up for contention is the addition of, "side tracks" which replace the spin notes of the previous games. Problem? Left and right side tracks which require you to hit your buttons of choice (left and right shift by default), which turns like a 6 button song into an 8 button, and an 8 button into a 10 button. Do you ever hit Right Shift? I don't. My pinky can't handle it.

But in the end, it doesn't matter. Absolutely amazing gameplay, 160+ songs without DLC spanning the history of the series; there's just nothing to not love here. This game is a must-have for any fan of the franchise and if you're into rhythm games you owe yourself to check this one out.
